div.p: A General TREATISE OF THE DISEASES OF Maids, Bigbellied Women, Child-bed-Women, and Widows, TOGETHER With the bet Methods of Preventing or Curing the ame.
By J. PECHEY of the College of Phyicians in London.
LONDON, Printed for Henry Bonwick, at the Red-Lyon in St. Paul's Church-Yard, 1696.

div.head: THE PREFACE
div.p: WOMAN of all the Creatures is the Fairet and mot Beautiful, kind Nature having betow'd on her a delicate and fine habit of Body, and deign'd her only for an eaie Life, and to perform the tender Offices of Love; whereas, he compos'd Man of more robut Principles, that he might be able to protect the Woman, to delve and manure the Earth, and to undergo the other Toils of Life.

But by reaon of this Curious Frame, the Fair Sex (as other
fine things are) is ubject to many Injuries, for beides the common Calamities, there are many great and dangerous Dieaes peculiar to Women ariing from their Contitutions, monthly Purgations, Pregnancy, Labours and Lying in.

Their Contitution dipoes them to Hyteric Dieaes, which reemble almot all the Dieaes Mankind is ubject to, viz. An Apoplexy, Epilepie, Palpitation of the Heart, Coughs, Violent Vomiting, Colick, Stone in the Kidnies, and many other. Pains and ometimes Swellings in the Jaws, Shoulder Hands, Thighs and Legs accompany thee Dieaes. Nor can the Teeth free themelves from this Dieae: but the mot
cmomon Pain, is the Pain of the Back. A dejection of Mind alo accompanies this Dieae continually.

A Suppreion or Immoderate Flux of the Coures, caues many diorders in the Body, o alo does their Flowing before their due time, or their taying longer than they hould, and their complication with other Dieaes renders the Cure difficult.

All the time their being with Child, which is a nine Months Sicknes, they are inclined to Naueounes, Vomiting, to Pains of the Back, Reins, and Hips, violent Coughs, Swellings of the Legs and Thighs, Piles, and many other Dieaes, and upon ome Indipoitions of the
Body to Micarriage, which is the wort and mot dangerous of all. When they are in Labour, and when they lie in, they are encompaed with many difficulties and dangers, viz. an ill poition of the Child, uppreion of the Lochia, Floodings, Fevers, after Pains, Apotemations of the Breats, and many other Dieaes. So that if Nature had not wiely tacked an Appetite to things neceary, we mut conclude, the Preervation of Individuals and of Species too would not have been near o well provided for as now it is.

The following Treatie is a Collection from Rodericus a Catro and others, that have wrote well of Womens Dieaes, and I judge
it may be erviceable to Ladies and Gentlewomen, who charitably dipence Phyick, and give advice to their poor Neighbours in the Country, where there is no Phyician near; and it may be alo of ue to Phyicians, Chyrugeons and Midwives, it being a general Treatie of Womens Dieaes and the Methods and Medicines contained in it, being approved and frequently practied by the mot Renowned Authors of each Phyical Province.

closer.dateline: From the Angel and Crown in Baing-Lane, London June the 16th. 1696.

div.head: A General TREATISE OF Womens Dieaes.
CHAP. I.
Of the Hyteric Dieae.
div.p:
THIS Dieae proceeds from a weaknes and confuion of the Spirits, and is not only very frequent, but alo o wonderfully various, that it reembles almot all Dieaes Mankind is ubject to: For after hard Labour, or ome great diturbance of the Mind, it occaions an Apoplexy, which ends in a Palie of half the Body. Sometimes it produces violent Convulions very like the Falling-Sicknes, and thee are commonly call'd Mother-fits. Sometimes it poees the outward part of the head, cauing
violent pain continually fixt in one part, which may be cover'd with the top of the Thumb, and violent Vomiting accompanies this pain. It alo occaions ometimes a great Palpitation of the Heart, and ometimes the Woman coughs without intermiion, but pits up nothing. Sometimes ruhing violently upon the region under the Heart, it caues violent pain much like the twiting of the Guts, and the Woman Vomits exceedingly, and cats up a green Matter, and ometimes Matter of an unuual Colour; and often after the Sick have been almot detroy'd by the aid pain, and the reachings to Vomit, it is at length carried off by the Jaundice tincturing the urface of the Body like Saffron. The Sick is much dejected, and Depair as certainly accompanies this kind of Hyteric Dieae, as the Pain and Vomiting above mention'd. When this Dieae falls upon one of the Kidnies, it plainly repreents by the pain it caues there a fit of the Stone; and it is difficult to ditinguih it from the Stone, unles perchance ome unlucky accident diturbing the Womans mind a little before he was taken ill, hews that it was an Hyteric Dieae. Nor is the Bladder free from this fale Symptom; for it does not only caue pain there, but it alo tops the Urin. Sometimes falling
upon the Stomach it caues continual Vomiting, and ometimes a Loones when it is ettled upon the Guts, but no pain accompanies either of thee Symptoms.

And as this Dieae afflicts almot all the inward parts, o ometimes it eizes all the outward parts, occaioning pain, and ometimes a Swelling in the Jaws, Shoulders, Hands, Thighs, Legs; but the Swelling of the Legs is plainer een than the ret, and contrary to Swellings in the Dropie, is mot in the Morning; nor being preed does it leave a pit, and mot commonly it wells only one of the Legs. Nor can the Teeth free themelves from the aaults of this Dieae, tho they are not hollow; and tho there is no apparent Defluction, that may occaion the pain, yet it is no whit gentler nor horter nor eaier Cured. But the pain of the Back is mot common, which mot certainly all feel, how little oever they are afflicted with this Dieae. Moreover this is common to the foreaid pains, that the place whereon they were, is tender and akes as if it were oundly beaten, but this tendernes goes off by degrees. And this is worth oberving, that often a notable coldnes of the outward parts makes way for thee Symptoms, which for the mot part does not go off till the fit ends; which coldnes is almot
like that wherewith a Carcas grows tiff, yet the Pule is good. Moreover all Hyteric Women complain of a dejection and inking of the Spirits, and ometimes laugh exceively, and at other times cry as much, without any real caue for either. But the mot proper and almot ineparable Symptom, is a Urin as clear as Rock-water. Sometimes ill fumes are belched up, and ometimes the Wind that comes from the Stomach is ower jut like Vinegar: But their Minds are more affected than their Bodies; for an incurable Deperation is mixt with the very nature of the Dieae.

A day would carce be ufficient to reckon up all the Symptoms belonging to this Dieae, and I think Demetrius reckn'd pretty right, tho he mitook the caue of the Dieae, when he aid, in an Epitle to Hippocrates, that the Womb was the caue of Six hundred Mieries and of innumerable Calamities. The external caues of this Dieae are either violent motions of the Body, or which is much oftner, vehement diturbances of the Mind; to thee diorders of the Mind which are uually the occaion of this Dieae, is to be added emptines of the Stomach by reaon of long fating, inmmoderate Bleeding, a Vomit or Purge that works too much.
In order to the cure, I order that eight Ounces of Blood be taken from the right Arm, and that the following Plaiter be apply'd to the Navel.
Take of Galbanum diolved in Tincture of Cator and train'd three Drachms, of Tacamahaca two Drams, mix them, make a Plaiter.
The next Morning let her ue the following Pills.

Take of the Pill Coch-major two Scruples, of Cator powder'd two Grains, of Peruvian Balam four drops, make four Pills; let her take them at five in the Morning, and leep after; repeat them twice or thrice, every Morning, or every other Morning, according to the Womans trength, and as they work.

Take of the Waters of Black-Cherries, Rhue, and Compound Briony, each three Ounces; of Cator ty'd up in a rag, and hanged in the Viol half a Dram; of Fine Sugar a Sufficient quantity, make a Julep, whereof let her take four or five Spoonfulls when he is faint, dropping into the firt doe, if the fit is violent, twenty drops of the Spirit of Harts-horn.
After the Purging Pills jut decribed are taken, let her ue the following.

Take of the filings of Steel eight Grains, with a ufficient quantity of extract of Wormwood, make two Pills, let her take them early in the Morning, and at five in the Afternoon, for Thirty days, drinking upon them a
draught of Wormwood Wine. Or if he like a Bolus better;

Take of the Conerves of Roman Wormwood, and of the yellow peel of Oranges each one Ounce, of Angelica and Nutmegs candied and of Venice Treacle each half an Ounce, of candied Ginger two Drachms, make an electuary with a ufficient quantity of Syrup of Oranges.

Take of this electuary one Drachm and an half, of the filings of Steel well rub'd eight Grains, make a Bolus with a ufficient quantity of Syrup of Oranges, to be taken in the Morning, and at five in the Evening, drinking upon it a Glas of Wormwood-wine.

Take of choice Myrrh and Galbanum each one Drachm and an half, of Cator fifteen Grains, with a ufficient quantity of Balam Peru, make twelve Pills of every Drachm; let her take three every Night, and drink upon them three or four Spoonfuls of Compound Briony Water through the whole coure of this proces.
But if thee Pills move the Body, which ometimes they do in Bodies that are very eaily purged, the following may be ued intead of them.
Take of Cator one Drachm, of Volatile Salt of Amber half a Drachm, with a ufficient quantity of extract of Rue, make twenty-four mall Pills, let her take three every Night.

But Steel Medicines, which mut be noted, occaion ometimes in Women great diorders
both of Body and Mind, and not only on the firt days, which is uual almot in every body, but alo all the time they are taken: In this cae the ue of Steel mut not preently be interrupted, but Laudanum mut be given every night for ome time in ome Hyteric water that they may the better bear it.

But when the Symptoms are mild, and it eems the buines may be done without Steel, I think it ufficient to Bleed and to Purge three or four times, and then to give the altering Hyteric Pills above-mentioned morning and evening for ten days, which method eldom fails, when the Dieae is not violent, yea the Pills alone Bleeding and Purging being omitted, do often a great deal of good.
But ome Women can't bear Hyteric Medicines, and are much injured thereby, therefore they mut not be given to uch.

If the Blood is o very feeble, and the confuion of the Spirits o great, that Steel ordered to be ued according to the method precribed is not ufficient to cure the Dieae, the Sick mut drink Tunbridge-waters or the like, for they cure Dieaes more efectually than any preparation of Iron; but if in drinking of them any Sicknes happen that belongs to Hyteric Symptoms, the Sick mut forbear drinking them a day or
two, till that Symptom that hindred their paage is quite gon. And it is to be noted, that Purging mut be avoided all the time the Woman drinks thee waters. But if this Dieae does not yeild to Steel-waters, the Sick mut go to the Bath, and when he has ued the waters of it three mornings following, the next day let her go into the Bath, and the day following let her drink them again, and o let her do by turns for two months, for in thee and others of what kind oever they are, the Patient mut perit in the ue of them till he is quite well: Venice-treacle ued often and a long time is a great remedy in this Dieae. Spanih-wine, with Gentian, Angelica, Worm-wood, Centory, and other trengthening things infus'd in it, does a great deal of good, ome poonfuls of it being taken thrice a day, if the Woman be not thin and of a cholerick habit of Body. And truly a large draught of Spanih-wine taken by it elf at bed-time for ome nights has been very beneficial to ome Women. Jeuits-powder alo wonderfully comforts and invigorates the Blood and Spirits, a Scruple of it being taken morning and evening for ome weeks.

But if the Remedies above-mentioned don't well agree, which often happens in thin and choleric Contitutions, then a
Milk-dyet may be ued, for ome Women (which one would wonder at at firt) that have been a long while afflicted with Hyteric Dieaes, and could be relieved no other way, have been recovered by Dieting themelves for ome time only with Milk; and epecially thoe that Labour with an Hyteric Cholick, which can't be appeaed by any thing but Opiates, to which repeated Women are much accutom'd, the pains returning as oon as the vertue of the Opiate fades. But riding on Hore back or in a Coach every day for a long while is the bet remedy.

This is the general way of Curing this Dieae, which is apply'd to the original caue, namely, the weak contitution of the Blood, and o is to be ued only when the Fit is off, therefore as often as the Fit comes join'd with any one of the fore-aid Symptoms, if the Dieae be uch or o great an one that it will not bear a Truce till it may be cured by Medicines that trengthen the Blood and Spirits, we mut preently make ue of Hyteric Medicines, which by their trong and offenive mell, recall the diorderly and deerting Spirits to their proper Stations; whether they are taken inwardly or melt to, or outwardly apply'd, uch are Aa-faetida, Galbanum, Spirit of Sal Armoniac, and latly whatever
has a very ungrateful and offenive mell.

In the next place you mut take notice, that if ome intollerable pain accompanied the fit, or violent Vomiting, or a Loones, then beides the Hyterics abovementioned, Laudanum is to be ued, which is only able to retrain thee Symptomes. But in quieting the pains which Vomiting occaion we mut take great care that they are not mitigated either by Laudanum or any other Opiat before due evacuations have been made, unles they exceed almot all humane patience. Therefore in luty Women and uch as abound with Blood a Vein mut be opened, and the Body purged, epecially if they have been lately eized with the fit. But if weak Women and thoe of a quite contrary Contitution labour with uch a fit and pain, and have been afflicted with it not long ago, it will be ufficient to cleane their Stomachs with a gallon of Poet drink taken in and ejected by Vomiting, and then to give a large Doe of Venice-Treacle, and a few poonfuls of ome Spirituous Liquor, that is pleaing to the tate, with a few drops of Liquid Laudanum, to be taken preently after. But if the Sick has Vomited a great while, and there is danger let by a further provocation by Vomits the Spirits hould be put into a rage, and the Sick too much weakened, in this
cae you mut give Laudanum without delay, and uch a Doe that is ufficient to vanquih it.

But here two things are to be chiefly noted, firt that when you have once begun to ue Laudanum after due and neceary evacuations, it mut be taken in the ame Doe, and mut be often repeated till the Symptom is quite conquered: only uch a pace mut be betwixt each Doe, that we may know what the former has done, before we give another: and then when we treat the Dieae with Laudanum, we mut do nothing ele, and nothing mut be evacuated, for the gentlet Gliter of milk and ugar is ufficient to poil whatever has been repaired by the Laudanum, and to occaion a return of the Vomiting and pain. But though the Pains above mentioned are apt to overcome the vertue of the Laudanum, yet violent Vomiting indicats the larget Doe of it, and that it hould be very often repeated, for by reaon of the Vomiting, the Laudanum is cat up before it can do any good, unles it be given afreh after every time the Sick Vomits, and chiefly in a olid form, and if it be given in a liquor the quantity mut be o mall that it mut but jut wet the Stomach, o that by reaon of the mall quantity of the matter it cannot be cat up, for intance, ome drops
of Liquid Laudanum in one poonful of trong Cinnamon-water, or the like; and the Sick mut be admonihed to keep her elf quiet preently after taking the Laudanum, and that he keep her Head as much as is poible immoveable, for the mallet motion of the Head provokes Vomiting more than any thing ele; and when the Vomiting ceaes, and is as it were tam'd, it is expedient to give a Doe of Laudanum morning and evening to prevent a relape, which alo ought to be oberved after a Loones, or Hyteric pains.
And becaue frequent mention has been made of Liquid Laudanum in this Chapter, and it is much ued in other Dieaes Women are ubject to, I will here et down the bet way of making it.

Take of Spanih-wine one pint, of Opium two ounces, of Saffron one ounce, of the Powders of Cinnamon and Cloves each one Drachm; let them be infued together in a Bath for two or three days, till the liquor comes to the conitence of a thin Syrup; train it and keep it for ue. The Doe is ixteen or twenty Drops, to be taken in a mall draught of Beer, or in ome ditilled-water.

div.head: CHAP. II.
Of the Green-Sicknes.
div.p: THE Green-icknes is an ill habit of the Body proceeding from Obtructions, it is accompanied mot commonly with a beating of the Heart, difficulty of breathing, and a longing for aburd things, and an unfitnes for motion, and other Symtoms; the Face and whole Body are pale, and ometimes of a leaden and green colour, there is an inflation, and as it were a welling upon the Eye-lids; the Legs alo well, epecially about the Ankles; there is a heavy and often a lating pain of the Head, the Pule is quick, the Sick are drowie, and have an averion for wholome food; latly, the Dieae increaing and the Obtructions being multiplied, a uppreion of the Coures at length follows, which hews the Dieae is confirmed.
This Dieae mot commonly is not dangerous, but if it be neglected too much, it occaions great Dieaes, as hard Swellings, a Dropie, and other grievous Dieaes, which at length kill the Patient.

When the Dieae is mall and chiefly aries from Obtructions of the veins of the Womb, it is eaily cured by Marriage in
young Virgins. Thoe that have had this Dieae a long while are either Barren, or bring forth Children that are Sickly and hort lived.
The Cure is to be perform'd by the ame Method and Medicines propoed in the foregoing Chapter for the cure of the Hyteric Dieaes.

div.head: CHAP. III.
Of Women that never had their Coures.
div.p:
THE flux of the Coures is an undoubted ign that a Woman is mature, yet there are ome Women that never had them, tho' they have had converation with their Husbands, and ome of them have had Children, and others not; ome of them have enjoyed good health, and others have been ickly: the caue of this defect is in general two-fold, the firt is common to the whole Body, namely, becaue a Woman is flehy, laborious, and her parts are o dipoed that every Member takes up and expels what is convenient for it, o that there is no room for a mentruous purgation, thee are of a hot Contitution and uch as are termed Virago's, they are of a
brown Colour, of a compact Body, and their Loins and Buttocks are large, o are the Breats and Shoulders, they have a great voice, are trong and hairy, and this Contitution tho' it be the reaon that Women are in health, yet it is contrary to their Sex, and the Coure of Nature; and therefore to be accounted vitious. But other Women are ickly upon this account.

If this Dieae proceed from an hot Intemperies of the Womb, it may be known by a great pain in the part, and by the heat of the whole Belly: a dry Imtemperies may be known by long Fevers going before, and a thin habit of Body, but in time they grow Gros and Cachectical by reaon of the want of this evacuation. If it proceed from an ill Formation, there are wellings of the Belly, pain and a weight.

If it arie from a hot Intemperies, as it doth mot commonly, it mut be Cured by four kinds of Remedies, firt by cooling Diet, they mut eat Chicken, Veal, or the Broth wherein hath been boiled cooling Herbs, as Endive, Sorrel, Lettice, Spinage, and the like; Oranges are alo good, and roated Apples, and tewed Prunes; their Drink mut be mall Beer; their Sleep and Exercie mut be moderate; for violent Exercie and frequent walking are plainly injurious, and o are diturbances of the
Mind. Secondly they mut Bleed twice or thrice a Year in the Foot, and for ome days they mut take uch things as are proper to qualifie the hot and bilious Humours, as the waters and yrups of Purlain, Succory Endive, Violets, and the like, and let them be Purged with the following Medicines.

Take of the bet Rhubarb two Scruples, infue it a whole night in four ounces of Endive water, train it in the morning, and add to it an ounce of Manna, or of the pulp of Caia, and an ounce of yrup of Roes olutive.

Thirdly, let them ue uch things as leiurely attemperate the heat of the Humours and Part; as Conerve of Roes, or of Violets, with Endive-water, or a Ptian before Meals, or Goats-milk in the morning with the flowers of Violets and Borrage: But the ue of Cooling Apozems is much praied in this Cae.

Take of cleaned Barly three pugils, of the Roots of Borrage and Succory, each Ounce, of the leaves of Burrage, Succory, Endive, Fumitory and Sorrel, each one Handfull, of the Cordial Flowers, and of the Cold Seeds, each one Pugil, of Annieeds one Dram, of Prunes Twelve, of Raions one Ounce; Boyl them in a ufficient quantity of Water to one Pint and an Half; to the trained Liquor add a ufficient quantity of Sugar, make a clear Apozem, aromatize it with a Drachm of the Species of the three Sanders.
But if you intend to have it Purge a little, add towards the latter end the Leaves of Senna, and of the Pulp of Tamarinds, each one Ounce, and after it is boyled, three Ounces of Syrup of Roes olutive, or of Succory with Rhubarb
Fourthly, Topicks mut be applied to the lower part of the Belly.

Take of Oyl of weet Almonds (wahed with the Waters of Barly, Gourds, and Roes, each a like quantity) one Drachm of Hens-fat, Butter, and Goats-milk, each half an Ounce, of the Juice of Gourds, Endive or Violets, each ix Drachms, with Wax make a Liniment, Oyntment or Plaiter, as the Woman likes bet. But it will do mot good, if the Part be Fomented before with a Decoction of Lettice, Violets, Marh-mallows, Fumitory, Mallows, and the like; and to open the Paages, add the Leaves of Maiden-hair, Mercury and Mugwort a Bath may be alo made of thee.
Night Gliters alo wonderfully Cool the Womb and the whole Body.

Take of Chicken-broath altered with the foreaid Herbs ix Ounces, of the Oyl of Sweet-almonds and Violets, each two Ounces, of Suggar one Ounce, Yolks of Eggs two, mingle them, let it be retained, if he can all the Night; and when the Heat is very much, tuff the Chicken for this Decoction with Conerve of Roes.

If the Dieae proceed from Drynes, it mut be Cured with moitning Meats of
good Nourihment, and with Drinks; and the Woman mut walk often, but not o much as to tire her elf, and Frictions mut be ued above the region of the Womb, that the parts may be dilated o that the mentruous Blood may be allured to the Womb. Baths are alo proper, and Oyntments made of mucilages of the Seeds of Pyllium and Quinces and the like; and Glyters alo do good.
Take of the Decoction of Marh-mallows, Mallows, and Violets ix Ounces, of freh Butter three Ounces, mingle them, make a Glyter.
But all Evacuations mut be avoided, for they increae the Drynes.

If the Dieae proceeds from an ill Formation, Medicines are mot commonly unprofitable; and therefore you mut endeavour to leen the Blood, if it abound, or to divert it another way; therefore you mut Bleed three or four times a Year in the Arm, or in the Foot, if Blood eem to abound in the Womb. But if the trength of the Woman cannot bear Bleeding, then he mut ue a thin Diet, and frequent Exercie, and Frictions all over the Body, epecially early in the Morning, for o the Blood may be turned from the Inner Parts to the Outward, and part of it dicued. Baths moderately hot are alo good, and
thee things may be ufficient for Married Women, which by converation with their Husbands are omewhat dicharged; but they will not be ufficient for Maids and Widows; and therefore it will be neceary to provoke the Hemorrhoids or to open Iues. But if the Dieae proceed from obtinate Obtructions, it mut be treated as is propoed in the Chapter of the Suppreion of the Coures.

div.head: CHAP. IV.
Of the Coures breaking out by places not Natural.
div.p:
THE Mentruous Flux happens to break out by contrary wayes, upon two accounts; for either Nature providing for the afety of the Womans Body, when he knows there is any Impediment in the Womb, and the Veins of it, that hinder the Blood from paing, eeks another paage, whereby he may be unburthened, and the health of the Woman preerved; or forgetting the Natural paages, he either accutoms her elf to another, or wandring about, he ometimes ues this paage, ometimes that; for in ome the mentruous Blood is dicharged by the Mouth,
in others through the Notrils, by the Eyes and Bloody Tears, by the Dugs and Piles, alo by the Fingers and Urine, and ometimes by a Rednes in one of the Cheeks, and if there be an Impediment in the Womb, that hinders the paage of the Blood that way, it is better it hould flow thee ways than not at all, for o ays Hippocrates, Mentruis deficientibus anguinem e naribus erumpere bonum est.

The caue of this Dieae is mot commonly ome violent Paion of the Mind, or ome great diturbance happening when the Coures are near flowing; it comes alo from Obtructions of the Womb, or by reaon of violent Pains, and great Dieaes of the upper Parts, alo from the weaknes of them, when the VVomb and lower Parts are trong; for the weak Parts always receive what the tronger put upon them. It alo comes from ome external Caue, as by drinking cold Water uneaonably, or by wahing the Feet and Legs uneaonably, or by the ue of Vinegar, when the Coures are near.

The Scope of the Cure is Two-fold, the Firt is the Evacuation of the Blood abounding, the other is the Recalling of it to the lower Parts, which is chiefly done by Cooling the upper Parts, and by Heating, Moitning, and Opening, the lower
Parts; but both may be well anwered by Bleeding in the Foot three or four days before the Blood flows, and by applying Cupping-glaes to the Thighs Legs and Hips, ometimes Dry, but mot commonly with Scarification, and alo by provoking the Hemorrhoids, by Frictions, by Walking, by hot Baths natural or artificial; by Fomentations made of opening Herbs, by Unctions, Pearies, and uterine Gliters. But ee more of this in the Chapter of Suppreion of the Coures. The two following Remedies are peculiarly proper for this Dieae, viz. Bleeding in the Foot for everal Months at the times we have mentioned, and the Bath-waters wherein the Woman mut be Bathed early in the Morning, and mut continue a while in them; but this mut be noted, that the Waters mut not reach above the region of the Liver, and in the mean while the upper Parts mut be
anned.

div.head: CHAP. V.
Of the Coures coming before their due time, and of taying longer than they hould.
div.p:
IN many Women the Coures flow before their accutomed time, and ometimes they tay longer than they hould; and this anticipation and delay are ometimes orderly and ometimes diorderly. The Caues are either the Vice of the Womb, as the ill Figure of it, or a Solution of the Continuum, and ometimes a hurt on ome other account; as a Vitious humour that irritates before the time, by reaon of plenty of Blood, or the thinnes or harpnes of it; the quantity of humours occaioning it may be known by the dulnes of the Body, by the anguine habit of the Woman, by a edentary and idle Life, by exces in eating and drinking, or by ome other Evacuation topped or leened. The Acrimony of the Blood may be known by the Heat, Eroion, and Pain in the Excretion, or by the Vitious habit of the Womans Body, and the coure of her Life foregoing, or by the Diet he was wont to ue, and the like. But if it come leaurely,
and without pain, the retentive faculty is weak; it may alo be occaioned by a blow or fall.

If it proceed by reaon of the Loones, and fault of the retentive faculty, it mut be trengthened by proper Remedies; if it come from a plenitude, it mut be remedied by a paring Diet and moderate Exercie, and by taking away o much Blood as is agreeable to the trength in the middle of the Month, or a little before the Coures flow. Frictions alo in the Arms, and in all the upper parts of the Body are proper; the Woman mut abtain from Wine, and all Strong-waters, and intead of them Chalybeats mut be ued; and if thee things do not do the buines, he mut be blooded in the Arm; but if it proceed from the Acrimony of the Humours, he mut eat freely Meat of good nourihment, and mut exercie a little, and uch Medicines mut be ued as attemperate the humours, and he mut be purg'd, and Uterine Gliters mut be injected made of two Ounces of Oyl of Violets, and four Ounces of the Decoction of Mallows; but care mut be taken that the Coures be not quite topped, becaue it is dangerous. Latly, if a blow, a fall, or difficult labour occaion this dieae, the following Cataplam mut be applied to the Womb and Neighbouring parts.
Take of the Powders of Dragons-blood, Frankincene, Matich, and of the greater Comfry, each two Drams, with a ufficient quantity of Turpentine make a Cataplam.
If the Woman be of a hot Contitution, apply the following Plaiter.
Take of the Powders of Roes, Myrtles, and Balautins, and Matich, each one Drahom, of fine Flour one Ounce, with the Whites of Eggs make a Plaiter.

The Coures tay beyond their time by reaon of age, when they are about to go away, or by a vice of the whole Body or of the womb: If it proceed on the account of age, you mut only endeavour to prevent thoe inconveniences which are wont to follow, epecially the Gout, and a pain in the Hip, which may be done by a pare Diet, much exercie, and by bleeding yearly, till Nature has been accutomed to the want of the mentruous Purgation: But if it proceed from a Vice of the whole Body, it mut be treated as a uppreion of the Coures. If it proceed from a peculiar diorder of the Womb, it requires a peculiar Cure, and is a Symptom of the kind of the vitiated action of Excretion, either becaue it is hindred by the ill Formation, or a gros Humour that Obtructs. The Caues therefore are thee three, which are contrary to the anticipation of the
Coures, viz. the weaknes of the Faculty, the fault of the Humours, and the dulnes of the Sene. The impotence of the Faculty is occaioned by the frigidity, or moiture of the Temperament, or by the depraved Figure of the Intrument; the Humour is faulty upon the account of its thicknes, iccity and clammines: The Sene is rendred dull mot commonly by moiture abounding. The weak Faculty by reaon of Frigidity, is known by the Womans perceiving a weight and diturbance after the time of the coming of her Coures is pat. The fault of the Intrument may be known by what went before, as by hard labour, a tumour, cicatrix, leaping or a fall, whereby the Womb, or a part ubervient to it is diplaced, or the figure of it deformed. The fault of the Humour may be known by thoe things that are evacuated by the Blood, as if it be whitih it may be een, if it be gros and clammy, a edentary life, and a gros and flegmatic Diet went before; the Woman is of a oft, pale and leaden habit of body, and is fat; and by the Bloods flowing lowly, and by the long continuance of the Coures ometimes, and by their ending in a lime. If when they tay a long time before they come, the Woman does not perceive any diturbance in the Womb and neighbouring Parts,
the Sene is dull. If the Dieae arie from a thick and clammy Humour, as it does mot commonly, it mut be cured according to Galen, with three orts of Remedies; Firt, by a thin and heating Diet, by moderate exercie, and frictions of the Legs: Secondly, by attenuating and heating Potions made of opening Roots of Calaminth, Fennel, Saxifrage, Burnet, Hyop, and the like, Saffron and Cinnamon being added to them, and the Cure mut be begun preently after the Purgation of the Coures. Let the Woman take every Morning five or ix Ounces of the following Apozem.

Take of the Roots of Smallage, Fennel, and Parley, each two Ounces, of the Leaves of Feverfew, Cat-mint, Penny-royal, Maiden-hair, each one Handful and an Half, of the Seeds of Anie and Fennel, each one Drachm and an Half; boyl them in a ufficient quantity of Water to a Quart; in the trained Liquor diolve of the Syrups of Mugwort and Maiden-hair, each three Ounces; the Syrup of Hyop, or of the Five Opening Roots made without Vinegar is alo very good, being mixed with the Waters of Fennel, Cat-mint, Penny-royal, and Parley, and other things may be ued which are mentioned in the Chapter of the Suppreion of the Coures. 3dly, She mut be Purged with Agarick Trochicated, or with the Pill of Matick, Or,

Fourthly, Thoe things which draw the the Blood downwards mut be ued, as bleeding in the Foot three or four days before the accutomed time of the Coures; thee things being done, the Legs and lower Belly mut be fomented with a decoction of Fenugreek, Camomile, Dill, Melilot, Fennel, Parly, Daucus. And while he is bathing let her take one of the Tablets called Diacalaminth; afterwards let the Parts be fumed with Spices, and ue Frictions and Ligatures to the Legs, and let Cupping-glaes be applyed to the Claves of the Legs without carification; and if the Coures do not yet flow, let the Woman be purged every third day with four or five of the Pills mentioned before. Let the lower Belly be anointed with the Oyls of Capers, White Lillies, Dill, Cinnamon, and Saffron, and let Uterine Gliters be injected made of four Ounces of the Decoction of Penny-royal, Hore-mint, Thym, and Crees, with two Ounces of Oyl of Rue, or of Dill, which wonderfully rouze the dull ene of the Womb.

div.head: CHAP. VI.
Of the Coures corrupted, or uppurated.
div.p: THE Coures may be corrupted four everal ways; Firt from drawing a putrid quality from the whole Body: Secondly, from the mixture of ome putrid humour in the paages: Thirdly, by a long uppreion: Fourthly, from an intemperies in the Womb, or from an abundance of putrid humours contained in and about it, and are coloured and diordered according to the nature of the humours; they are White, Pale, Livid, Green, Black, Skinny, Fibrous, Membranous, Windy, Fetid, and they have Sand and Worms in them.

The Cure is in a manner the ame which is propoed for the Cure of the Whites; for an exact coure of Diet being ordered, the Woman mut be purged with Agarick trochicated, or with the Pill of Matich, if a Phlegmatic humour abounds; if a bilious humour be the caue, let her be purged with Rhubarb, as

Take of the best Rhubarb, four Scruples, of yellow Myrobalans one Drachm and an Half, infue them a Night in three Ounces of Succory
Water; to the trained Liquor add of Syrup of Roes Solutive, and of Manna, each one Ounce.
If Melancholy Humours abound,
Take of Senna one Ounce, of the Seeds of Annie one Drachm, infue them in four Ounces of Fumitory-water; to the trained Liquor add of Pulp of Caia, and of Syrup of Roes Solutive, each one Ounce.

If the Coures are uppurated, uch things mut be ued now and then, as evacute a dut and Cholerick humours, which may be eaily prepared with Agarick, Rhubarb, and Senna; and ometimes Gliters mut be ued, and moderate exercie, which purge the Body and Womb; and if the Stomach abounding with Flegm be the caue, a Vomit ued by Intervals is proper, that what is daily heapt up there may be purged off before it enters the Veins.

Thirdly, Such things mut be ued as are able to eradicate the Dieae, and if the Humours are cold and gros, udorifics mut be ued, as a Decoction of Saraparilla, Guiac, China, and the like. But if Choler or Melancholy be the caue, bathing is mot proper; but gentle Frictions and Pearies are proper for both, and anoint the Belly with the Oyl of Sweet Almonds, or with the Oyl of Violets, which
are alo to be put up the Womb. But if thee things do no good, an Iue mut be made in one or both the Arms, which is of excellent ue.

div.head: CHAP. VII.
Of the Complication of the Coures with other Dieaes.
div.p: THere is carce any thing that does diturb Phyicians more, and which makes them err o much, as the complication of the Coures with Dieaes; and this happens chiefly ix ways. Firt, When a Dieae happens jut when the Coures are about to come. Secondly, If by reaon of the invaion of a Dieae, the Coures come before their due time. Thirdly, If the time of the Coures and of the Dieae are complicated, o that they come together. Fourthly, If the Coures being uppreed, delayed or leened, a Dieae comes upon them upon an other account. Fifthly, If by reaon of a Dieae pre-exiting, a uppreion or delay of the Coures is the caue of the increae of the Dieae and its Symptoms. Sixthly, If when there is a Dieae, the Coures flow.

If therefore the Coures are jut about to flow, when the Dieae is beginning, or in the proces of it, we mut conider whether the Dieae be one of thoe, which is occaioned by the Womb, in which cae if the Dieae requires bleeding without any delay, we mut draw it from the foot, that it may be let out by a convenient way, that the Womb may be evacuated, and the caue expelled. But if the Dieae aries from the whole Body, or from ome principal member of it; that Vein of the Arm (mot affirm) mut be opened, which chiefly repects the part affected: but this opinion, if it be generally received, eems to me injurious, and we ought rather to ditinguih concerning the number of the days, the acutenes of the Dieae, and the plenitude of the Body; for if the Dieae be not acute, Blood ought to be drawn from the Foot, and epecially, if the Woman be within three or four days of her Coures, and in this cae he ought to be blooded in the Foot, although the Dieae be acute, and this both reaon and experience confirms; for Nature is to be evacuated that way he tends, if it be a convenient place; for if the Woman be blooded in the upper parts, we often ee that he becomes delirious, and that watchings, leepy Dieaes, difficulty of Breathing,
and at length Death it elf follow. But if there be eight days, or thereabouts, before the time of the Coures, and there is a great plenitude, and the Woman cannot be o ufficiently evacuated by the Foot, as the Dieae requires, then all agree that he mut be blooded in the Arm, epecially if the Dieae be acute; but purging Medicines, Vomits, and Sudoriicks mut be deferred till the Coures are over, or you mut ue thoe that are very gentle, let Nature hould be hindred, or diverted; for if o, the Blood may be uneaonably detained, or may ruh upon ome principal part, or increae the Dieae. But if it happen that the Womans Coures are procratinated, it is lawful to Purge; for ometimes we ee that Purging brings the Coures. If the Dieae be Chronical, it is bet to Purge eight days after the Coures are gon off.

But if the Coures come before their due time in Dieaes, which is the econd way of complication, nothing in curing Womens Dieaes is o difficult and dangerous, epecially at the beginning of the Dieae, before univeral Remedies have been given; for at other times if we do nothing, there is the les perplexity; but if at the beginning you Bleed or Purge, you hinder the mentruous Purgation, and if
you do neither, the Dieae increaes. Thoe things that are proper for the Dieae, top the Coures; and if they flow, they do not relieve the Dieae, becaue they are then Symptomatical; for uch an evacuation, is almot always pernicious at the beginning of the Dieae, for Nature at that time eldom promotes any ueful evacuation; wherefore we mut diligently conider what good or hurt comes from it, and from what caue the anticipation of the Coures in Dieaes proceeds; for in the beginning and in the increae, as we aid, it is full of danger, but in the tate and declination, the cruption of the Coures, if they flow eaily, is wont to be advantageous, by reaon of the fitnes of the Seaon for evacuation, if it be not complicated with ome other evacuations of Nature. The Anticipation of the Coures proceeds from many caues: but from whatever caue it come, if there be a plenitude, the Cure mut be begun by bleeding in the Foot. But if the Coures flow at their accutomed time, and happen to come at the beginning of the Dieae, you mut firt wait on Nature, and if after twelve hours the Flux is not, or is not like to be ufficient, you mut bleed in the Foot, to compleat the natural evacuation of the Woman; and moreover,
you mut take away o much Blood, as the Dieae requires, for we mut repect Cutom and the Dieae too, and this may be undertood of violent Dieaes; yet it is chiefly to be ued in mall ones; and therefore that they hould not grow to be violent, you mut incourage the Coures by all means, by Ligatures, Frictions, Suppoitories, Gliters, and other things, which are ufficient to provoke the parts near the Womb; and if the Dieae arie from a cold caue, you mut give uch Medicines as promote the Coures, and alo repect the Dieae: But if a Purge be neceary, you mut defer it till the Coures are over, let the Blood being moved and diturbed thereby, greater michief hould be occaioned.

But if the Dieae be one of the greatet, as a Quiney, Freny, Pluriie, or an acute Fever, you mut firt bleed in the Foot, afterwards the ame day, you mut bleed in the Arm; but in the mean while you mut apply Ligatures to the Legs whilt the Blood flows, and this is good Practice; for the Indication of the mot violent Dieae is always to be repected before that Indication which is taken from the Coures, and in the ame manner you mut proceed in the other Seaons of the Dieae, wherein you ought to defer Purging, Vomiting
and Sweat, if the Dieae requires them, till the Coures are gone off; for the Indication of the Coures is greater than the Indications of thee helps, unles a Sanies flow beyond the appointed time, which is not to be accounted at that time to proceed from fulnes, and in this cae, an Indication for purging being urgent, you may Purge.

The Fourth Cae was, when upon the Coures topt a Dieae came. In this cae we mut firt conider whether the Coures are but now topt, or whether they have been topt a long while; and moreover, whether the Dieae proceeds from this uppreion; for if it arie from hence, you mut without doubt bleed in the Foot firt, nor mut we Purge, Vomit, or Sweat before; and afterwards in the Arm, if the Dieae require it, epecially if it be four days pat the accutomed time of the Coures. But if the uppreion be new, and the Dieae not urgent, before you ue other means, you mut expect a while the flowing of the Coures, epecially if you do not undertand rightly the nature of the Dieae; for it is more ecure, the Coures being topt to bleed in the Foot than to Purge, Vomit, or Sweat. But if notwithtanding bleeding in the Foot, the Coures flow but lowly, you ought to
give uch Medicines as move them; and it will be proper to give them before they begin, if you upect that Nature will not do the buines throughly her elf.

But if the Coures delay, and the Dieae grows wore thereby, mot affirm that the Cure mut be begun by thoe helps, which the Dieae and its Caue require, without repect to bleeding in the Foot. But I am not of the ame Opinion; for in light Dieaes, and in uch as will bear a Truce, experience has taught me that it is bet to bleed in the Foot; for the indication from the Coures topt is more to be minded than a mall Dieae, and therefore they ought to be provoked, firt by Ligatures, Cupping-glaes, Frictions, and Medicines, and afterwards you mut provide for the Dieae: But if the Dieae be violent, as a Quinie, Pleuriie, or the like; then certainly thoe Remedies mut be given which the Dieae requires, without conideration of the Veins of the Foot.

But when the Coures hould come at the time of the Dieae, and are topt, by reaon of the Dieae and its Caue, without doubt we ought to bleed in the Foot, and to take away o much Blood, as the plenitude of the Womb requires, or till the Coures flow, and if there be occaion we may Purge gently, and not divert the
Coure of Nature. Latly, if when the Dieae is preent, the Coures flow by drops before their time, you mut proceed as in the econd Cae concerning the Anticipation of the Coures in Dieaes: Or, if it happen at their due time, you mut treat them as in the third Cae when the Coures happen with the Seaons of the Dieae; only the dropping of the Coures ignifies a greater oppreion of Nature, and therefore requires larger bleeding.

div.head: CHAP. VIII.
Of the Coures coming difficulty, and with violent Symptoms.
div.p:
THis Dieae is like a Dyury or adifficulty of Urine, for it is accompanied with Pain and a great diturbance, the Symptoms often come before the Coures, and ometimes with the Coures; the Blood comes by drops and is attended with violent Pain. This Symptom comes upon an Obtruction of the Coures, ometimes upon Solution of the Continuum, an Ulcer, Eroion, and painful diorders in the neighbouring parts, The Coures, as was aid before, come ometimes drop by drop, and ometimes plentifully;
ometimes by intervals, and ometimes continually; ometimes orderly, and ometimes diorderly.

It is mot commonly occaioned by the ame Caues from whence a uppreion of the Coures proceeds, but gentler; for there is not a total Suppreion, but an unequal Obtruction of the Veels of the Womb, by reaon of thick clotted, and feculent blood, which tretches the Veels, and Nature violently endeavouing to Evacuate it, a gros wind aries, which ditending the Veels, and the neighbouring parts, occaions the violent pain, which continues untill the clods are ejected. Sometimes the Blood flows plentifully, yet the Coures are counted difficult and leened; becaue tho a great quantity is evacuated, yet it is not anwerable to the plenitude. The econd Caue is an Ulcer, or ome preternatural Tumour in the Womb or neighbouring parts, which are provoked and hurt by the commotion of the Blood. The third is the acrimony of the Humours. This Dieae is known by a pain in the Head, a pain in the Stomach, Retlenes, pains in the Loins, and of the lower Belly, jut like the pains of Child-bearing, coming with the Coures, or eight days before. There is often alo fainting and convulions, and a palpitation of the Heart; and by thee you may know,
that the Blood is clotted or thick, and a mall welling is ometimes perceived in one or both of the Groins, by reaon of clotted Blood contained in it; and jut before the evacuation of the clotted Blood, the pain is mot violent, and at the ame time if wind be joined with it, it breaks from the Womb or backwards with a noie, and there are wandring pains about the Loins and Hips. If an Ulcer be the caue, Sanies or Pus is mixed with the Blood, and the Coures flow always with a fixed pain. This Dieae afflicts Virgins and thoe that are Barren. The Cure is two-fold, the firt repects the Caue, the econd the mitigating the Pain. If it proceed from feculent gros and clotted Blood, a thin Diet and moderate Exercie mut be ordered, and Medicines that caue Revulion and Evacuation, mut be ued. Blood therefore mut be drawn from the Arm if there be a great quantity of it, but if the quantity be mall, from the Foot; and the clotted Blood that cannot be evacuated, mut be drawn out by Cupping-glaes applied to the Thighs and Legs with Scarification, and by Ligatures upon the Legs, and the Humour may be turned by applying Leeches to the Fundament if the pain continue after the Coures are topp'd, but they mut not be ued before.
Secondly, Evacuation mut be ued with this ditinction, when feculent and grumous Blood is the caue, you mut Bleed; when an Ulcer, Wind, or an Acrid Matter, you mut Purge mot.

Thirdly, The Paages mut be Relaxed and Opened, and the Pain mitigated; wherefore, if the matter be thick, latulent, feculent, or clammy; a Dram of Venice Treacle, or of Mithridate mut be taken at Bed-time in three Ounces of Balm-water; and Baths mut be provided, and Lotions for the Legs made of a Decoction of Marh-mallows, of the Seeds of Flax, Fenugreek, Dill, Rhue, and Mugwort, and the Feet mut be bathed in it hot a while, and the vapours mut be received, and a Spunge dipt in it mut be applyed to the Privities, and the lower Belly mut be Fomented afterwards with Flannel dipt in Wine and Oyl of Roes, or with a Bladder half full of warm Oyl; but it will be better to anoint the Navel, and the region below it with Oyl of Saffron, of White-lillies, the Seeds of Flax, of Capers, of Yolks of Eggs, or of weet Almonds, among which or with one of them mut be diolved a Drachm of Treacle, a Peary dipt in the ame is alo is of great ue; or the foreaid Parts may be annointed with Hens-fat and Butter; or with Butter and ome of the foreaid Oyls.
The following Oyntment is alo very proper.
Take of the juice of Angelica one Drachm, of Oyls of Capers and of White-lilies, each one Ounce and an half, of White-wine half an Ounce, with Wax make an Oyntment.
The following Cataplam is alo very good.
Take of common Oyl, of weet Wine, and freh Butter, each two Ounces, of Bran three Ounces; boyl them gently, apply them hot and repeat them frequently.

But if acrid and eroding Matter be the caue you mut ue gentle Oyntments, and Fomentation of warm Water, or Purlain and Lettice Water with Emulions of the cold Seeds; and the Parts mut be anointed with the Oils of weet Almonds, of Violets and of Roes.

If the Dieae proceeds from an Ulcer, you mut endeavour the Cure of it, and you mut mitigate the Pain by injecting uterine Gliters made of four Ounces of warm Water; and if the heat be very much, the Water mut be weetned with Sugar, and you mut add one Drachm of the white Troches of Rhais. Or, the Gliter may be made with three Ounces of Allum-water, which is of excellent ue; or with o much Barly-water with an Ounce of Syrup of Roes; or with Milk-water with Sugar; or
with an Ounce and an half of Milk it elf, with the like quantity of a Decoction of the Leaves and Seeds of Plaintain, to which may be added half an Ounce of the emulion of the cold Seeds; and if the Pain and Heat is very violent, inject two Ounces of the Decoction of Henbane, or white Poppies. But if thee things will not do the buines, ome Opium mut be mixed with the Decoction before mentioned. Latly, if other remedies will not do the buines, an Iue mut be opened in the Leg.

div.head: CHAP. IX.
Of the Cloure of the Womb.
div.p: VIrgins labouring under this Dieae are aid to be Imperforate. This cloure is wont to be in three places, viz. in the mouth of the Womb, in the neck of it, and in the Privities. It is occaioned either in the firt Formation when a Membrance covers the Orifice of the Womb, or its Neck, or by a Wound, or Ulcer preceding, which growing together tops the Neck of the Womb, or joins the Lips, or it is occaioned by Humours, or a Compreion.

If the Cloure be in the Privities, it may be eaily known, but if it be in the Neck, or Orifice of the Womb, it is not found out till the Coures begin to flow, or till Women are Married; for at the time of the mentruous Purgation, Pains and Gripes are perceived in the region of the Womb at certain times, with a ene of weight, yet no Flux follows. Moreover, you may gues at it, if the Maid be of good habit of Body not Cachetical, and without Obtruction, the Dieae continuing the Womb wells, o that Virgins eem to be with Child, and ometimes the whole Body, which looks livid: But if the Neck of the Womb be cloed, it may be known in the firt Copualtion, becaue it cannot admit the Virile Member. Latly, if the Orifice of the Womb be hut, it is difficultly known, but it may be found out by the hand of a Skilful Midwife.
As to the prognotick, if the Cloure be in the Orifice of the Privities, it is eaily Cured by a mall Section: But if it be in the inner Parts, the Cure is much more difficult.
When a Membrane huts the paage, it is eaily Cured, but when the Cloure is from flehy Matter, as it happens after Ulcers, then the Cure is much more difficult.
The Cloure of the inner Orifice of the Womb is Incurable, for Chirurgcial Intruments cannot work upon it.

If the Cloure of the Womb be contracted from the Birth, it mut be opened by imple Section; but if it takes its rie from an Ulcer, as it often happens in the French-Pox; we mut conider, whether it be an Excrecence of Fleh that does not wholly top the paage; and whether it quite tops For if it be only an Excrecence, we mut endeavour (convenient Evacuations going before) firt to hinder the increae of the Fleh by drying and dicuing Medicines, and afterwards we mut leen the Fleh by Medicines made of Frankincene, Birthwort, the Bark of Frankincene, Roes, Balautins, Matick, Myrrh, Aloes, and the like; and if thee things are not ufficient, we mut ue burnt Allom, Unguentum, Aegyptiacum, and the like; or the Fleh may be cut off by that Intrument that is ued for extirpating a Polipus. But if the Neck of the Womb be wholly hut, we mut endeavour to renew the Ulcer, and to take off the uperfluous Fleh by the foreaid Medicines, or it mut be cut.
If a Tumour hut the paage of the Womb, it mut be removed by proper Remedies.

If it be occaioned by a Compreion of
the Neck of the Womb, that which caues the Compreion mut be removed, namely, a Stone in the Bladder, a Tumour of the right Gut, or the like.

div.head: CHAP. X.
Of Suppreion of the Coures
div.p: THere is aid to be a Suppreion of the Coures, when in Women of a mature Age, that neither give uck nor are with Child, the Evacuation of Blood by the Womb, which is Naturally wont to be Monthly, flows eldom, or paringly, or is wholly topt.

Becaue this Suppreion proceeds from Natural and Preternatural Caues, the igns of both hall be ditinctly propoed, let the Practitioner hould be deceived by Women being with Child by Illegitimate Coition, and o rahly precribe Medicines to provoke the Coures.
First therefore, Women with Child mot commonly retain their Natural Colour, and others do not.

Secondly, the Symptoms which do happen to Women with Child at the beginning, abate Daily, but on the contrary in Suppreion of the Coures, the longer they are top'd, o much the more the Symptoms are increaed.

Thirdly, In Women with Child after the third Month, the motion and ituation of the Child may be enibly perceived by laying the hand on the Belly. But in others the Swelling is not at all hard, nor is it always contained within the Limits of the Womb.
Fourthly, If the inward Mouth of the Womb be touched by a Skilful Midwife, he will find it not exactly cloed, as it is in Women with Child; but rather hard, contracted, and omewhat painful.
Fifthly, Women with Child are mot commonly cheerful; but on the contrary in a Suppreion, they are mot commonly orrowful and ad.
A Suppreion of the Coures is very dangerous, and many deperate Dieaes arie from it.

The Cure of this Dieae mut be varied according to the variety of the Caues, and firt, if it proceed from too great a quantity of Blood, bleeding mut be ordered in the Arm, and a large quantity of Blood mut be taken away; afterwards it mut be drawn downwards by opening the lower Veins about the time the Woman ued to have her Coures before he was ill.

If by reaon of want of Blood the Coures top, as after long Fevers, after great Evacuations, and when the Body is much wated, you mut not endeavour to provoke the Coures till the Body is replenih'd, and a ufficient quantity of Blood is bred, which being done they generally flow of their own accord; but if it happens that Nature forforgets her Office, he mut be rous'd up by opening the lower Veins, and by Medicines propoed in the Chapter of Hyterick Dieaes: But the quantity of Blood mut be moderate, let the trength hould be dejected, and the Sick hould fall into a Conumption. yet it mut be carefully noted, that every wating of the Body does not hew a want of Blood, but only that which ucceeds great Evacuations, and the like. For ometimes it happens that the
Coures being uppreed and detained in the Veins, occaion an ill quality, whereby the Blood is rendred unfit to nourih the Parts, upon which account the Body wats, tho the Veins are full of Blood, in which Cae large bleeding is required.

As to the uppreion of the Coures which happens by a prepoterous motion of the Blood, when it is evacuated by bleeding at Noe, by Vomiting, Spitting, or Hemorrhoids, and other parts, the Cure of it is perform'd by repelling the Blood from the parts through which it flows contrary to Nature, and by drawing it back to the paage of the Womb. The firt is performed when the Blood ruhes out of the upper parts, by wahing the Arms, Head, and Face, with cold Water, and by forbearing the exercie of thoe parts, epecially inging and peaking aloud. The econd is perform'd by opening the lower Veins, three or Four days before the Blood breaks out, and by Cuping-Glaes applied to the Thighs and Legs ometimes with, ometimes without Scarification, by provoking the Hemorrhoids, by Running, by Walking, Fomentations, and Baths made of opening Herbs; but the Bath water is epecially commended, and the Sick mut bath in them often a good while after Meals, but the water
mut not rie above the Navel, and at the ame time the upper parts be cool'd by fanning them.

If the Blood flow by the Hemorrhoids, the Cure is very difficult; for if you ue things to draw downwards, they bring them alo to the Fundament, and if you ue atringent things to it, they by nearnes of the parts, repell what hould be brought to the Womb; o that the only way of Cure is to apply uch things to the Womb as may allure the Blood thither, after you have ued uch things as draw the Blood downwards.

div.head: CHAP. XI.
Of an Immoderate Flux of the Coures.
div.p: AN immoderate Flux of the Coures comes either in Child-bed, or at other times, as to the firt that afflicts Women mot on the firt day after a difficult Labour, and is accompanied with a long train of Hyteric Symptoms; and as it happens only on the firt days o uually does not lat long, for if a thickning diet be order'd, it oon abates: The following Drink may be alo ued.

Take of Plantain water and Red wine, each one Pint, boil them till a third part be conumed, weeten it with a ufficient quantity of white Sugar, and let her take half a pint twice or thrice a day, and in the mean while the following Medicine tyed up in a rag, may be often held to her Noe.
Take of Galbanum and Aa foetida each two Drams, of Cator one Dram and half, of Volatile Salt of Amber half a Dram, mingle them: Or intead of it, Spirit of Sal armoniac may be ued.
But as to the Flux which happens out of Child-bed, you mut bleed in the Arm, and eight Ounces of Blood mut be taken away, the next Morning the following Purge mut be given.

Take of Tamarinds half an Ounce, of Sena two Drams, of Rubarb one Dram and an half, infue them in a ufficient quantity of Fountain water, in three Ounces of the train'd Liquor, diolve of Manna, and Syrup of Roes olutive each, an Ounce, make a Purging Potion, which is to be repeated every third day for twice. Every Night at bedtime through the whole coure of the Dieae give an Ounce of Diacodium mixt with two Ounces of Black Cherry water.

Take of the Conerve of dried Roes two Ounces, of the Troches of Lemnian Earth a Dram and an half, of Pomgranate peel and of
red Coral prepared each two Scruples, of Blood Stone, Dragons Blood, and Bole-armenic each two Scruples, with a ufficient quantity of Simple Syrup of Coral, make an Electuary, whereof let her take the quantity of a large Nutmeg in the Morning, and at five in the Afternoon, drinking upon it ix Spoonfuls of the following Julip.

Take of the waters of Oakbuds and of Plantain each three Ounces, of Cinnamon water hordeated and of Syrup of dried Roes each one Ounce, of Spirit of Vitriol a ufficient quantity to make it pleaantly acid.

Take of the Leaves of Plantain and Nettles each a ufficient quantity, beat them together in a Marble Mortar, and pres out the juice, clarifie it, and give ix Spoonfuls of it cold three or four times in a day; after the first Purge apply the following Plaiter to the region of the Loins.
Take of the Platers of Diapalma and ad herniam each equal parts, mix them and pread them on Leather.
A cooling and thickening Diet mut be order'd, only it may be proper to allow once or twice a day a mall glas of Claret to recover the trength.

div.head: CHAP. XII.
Of the Whites.
div.p: THis obtinate and lating Dieae may be cured by bleeding once, and by Purging with two Scruples of Pill Coch-Major four times, and by the following trengthening Medicines.

Take of Venice Treacle one Ounce and an half, of the Conerve of the Yellow Peel of Oranges one Ounce, of Diacordium half an Ounce, of Ginger candied, and Nutmegs candied each three Drams, of compound Powder of Crabs eyes one Dram and an half, of the outward Peel of Pomgranats, of the roots of Spanih Angelica, and of the troches of Lemnian Earth each one Dram, of Bole-Armenic two Scruples, of Gun-arabic half a Dram, with a ufficient quantity of Syrup of dried Roes make an Electuary, whereof let her take the quantity of a large Nutmeg in the Morning, and at five in the Afternoon, and at Night, drinking upon it ix Spoonfuls of the following infuion.

Take of the roots of Elecampane, Materwort, Angelica, and Gentian, each half an Ounce, of the Leaves of Roman Wormwood, white Horehound, the leer Centory and Calaminth
each one handful, of Juniper-berries one Ounce, cut them mall, and infue them in five pints of Canary Wine, let them tand in infuion, and train them only as you ue them.

div.head: CHAP. XIII.
Of Barrennes.
div.p: BArrennes proceeds from many caues, but they may be reduced to four Heads, according to the four Natural Operations which are required to perfect Conception. The firt is that the Woman in Copulation receive the Mans eed: Secondly, that it's retain'd a due time: Thirdly, that it is nourihed in the Womb: Fourthly, that the Woman afford due Matter for the forming and neceary increae of the Embroy; and hence four impediments of Conception arie.

Firt, The Reception of the Seed is hindered by many caues, as immature Age, when by reaon of the narrownes of the Genital paages the Woman cannot admit the Mans Yard, or at leat not without great pain, which makes her dilike Copulation; and Old Age has the ame effect;
for in elderly Virgins the Genital parts for want of ue, are rendr'd o trait, that they can't eaily receive the virile Member, and uch as are lame, or have their Limbs ditorted, or their Hips depreed, can carce lye in uch a poture as is neceary for a fit Reception of the Seed; too much fat alo tops the paages, and makes the Copulation incommodious: And latly, a cold intemperies of the Womb makes the Woman dull, o that he carce injoys any pleaure in Copulation, or is o flowly moved, that the inward Orifice of the Womb does not open eaonably to receive the Mans Seed. The Paions of the Mind alo are a great hinderance, epecially hatred between Man and Wife, whereby the Woman having an averion for uch pleaure does not upply Spirits ufficient to make the Genital parts turgent at the time of Copulation; nor does the Womb kindly meet the Seed, and draw it into its Cavity, from whence and from mixture of both the Seeds, Conception aries.
The Reception of the Seed may be alo hinder'd by Swellings, Ulcers, Obtructions, Narrownes or Ditorions of the Genital parts, or of the Neighbouring parts, or by a tone in the Bladder or the like.

Conception may be alo hindred by reaon
the Seed is not retained upon the account of too great moiture of the Womb, namely when its fill'd with many excrementitious humours, whereby being render'd too laxe it cannot be contracted, as it ought to retain the Seed received, but this chiefly happens by reaon of micarriage or hard labour, whereby the Fibres of the Womb and its inner Orifice are torn, but the Whites are the mot common caue of Barrennes.

Conception is alo hindred when the Seed is not ufficiently nourihed in the Womb, as when the Intemperies of the Womb is o very cold, that it extinguihes the Seed, or o hot as that it diipates it, or over-moit or dry.

The Age fit for Conception is from fourteen to fifty, and therefore thoe Women that are younger or older do not conceive, by reaon of a defect of Seed and mentruous Blood, yet it mut be confeed, that ome Women have conceived who never had their Coures.

A diproportion betwixt the Mans and Womans Seed is alo the occaion of Barrennes, tho there is no enible defect in either, and it happens ometimes that the ame Man has Children by another Woman, and the ame Woman Children by another Man, when together they were
Childles. It comes to pas ometimes that after a Woman has convered ten or more Years with her Husband, and has not conceived, afterwards he has had Children, the caue whereof is the change of her Contitution by time.

Having made frequent mention of Womens Seed, I mut here acquaint you that many Learned Phyicians and Anatomits deny that Women have any Seed, for ome Women end forth no humour as is called Seed, and yet they are Fruitful enough, yea ome after they have begun to emit uch an humour, tho indeed they took great pleaure in Copulation, yet grew les fruitful than before. 'Tis alo aid by ome that a eminal Air or Vapour ariing from the Mans Seed, and not the Seed it elf caues Conception; but paing by Controveries and nice Speculations, I according to my way of Writing, et down uch Methods and Medicines as are approved of for the Cure of this Dieae.

And Firt, the narrownes of the genital parts by reaon of youth, in progres of time will grow large enough, and therefore there is no need of any other Cure, but in the mean while Copulation mut be forbid, for by the too early ue of it, the natural contitution of the parts is diordered, but if it proceed from mall tature or age, it is incurable.
Over-fatnes may be corrected by a pare and proper Diet, and by convenient evacuations.
If Barrennes proceeds from a diorderly Diet, as from exceive eating or drinking, the Woman mut be reduced to a regular coure of Life.

Such as are robut and of a manly Contitution mut by all means be reduced to a womanly tate; that they may become fit for generation, they mut forbear trong Meats and Labour, and the Coures mut be forced, and by Bleeding and Purging and the like, the habit of the Body mut be rendred cold and moit.

But the mot frequent caue of Barrennes is a cold and moit dipoition of the whole Body and of the Womb, which the Whites often accompany, and for the cure in this cae, the Whites mut be cured by the method precribed in the Chapter of the Whites, and the following things mut be ordered, which are peculiarly proper.

And Firt the flegmatick humours mut be evacuated by Medicines that purge Sweat and force Urine, and revulion mut be made by Iues in the Arms, Neck and Legs, and the principal parts mut be trengthened by Treacle, Mithridate, Confection of Alkermes and the like.
Afterwards uch things mut be ued as are proper by a pecific quality to trengthen the Womb and to help Conception.

Take of the roots of Eringo and Satyrion candied each one Ounce, of green Ginger candied half an Ounce, of Hazel Nuts, Pine Nuts, and Pitachies each ix Drams, one Nutmeg candied, of the Seed of Rocket and Crees each two Drams, of the ahes of a Bulls Pile, of the Reins of Scinks and of the rapings of Ivory each one Dram, of confection of Alkermes three Drams, of Diambra and weet Diamoch each one Ounce and an half, of Ambergriee half a Dram, with the Syrup of candied Citrons, make an Electuary, let her take the quantity of a Nutmeg at bedtime, drinking upon it a glas of good Wine.
Some count the Secundine of a Woman dried and powderd very effectual, one Drachm of it being taken.
The Seeds of Bihops weed are alo much commended.

Many good Authors affirm, that if a Woman drink ix Ounces of the juice of Garden Sage with a little Salt, the fourth day of her Mentruous Purgation, and a quarter of an hour after has Converation with her Husband, he will infallibly conceive. And by the ue of this remedy Aetius ays, the Egyptian Women became fruitful after a great Plague.

It's aid many have conceived when their having Children has bin depair'd of, by thruting up far in the Privities Garlic heated with Oyl of Spike, and wrapt in a fine rag, for it powerfully forces the Coures, and cleanes and delights the Womb.

div.head: CHAP. XIV.
Of the Parts of Women that erve for Generation.
div.p:
THE Parts erving for Generation in Women may be divided into the Privities, the Womb, the Teticles, and the Veels that prepare and carry. That part is called the Privities which appears at firt ight without diection, it reaches from the lower part of the Os Pubis, within an Inch of the Fundament; it is les and cloer in Maids, than in thoe that have born Children. It hath two Lips, which toward the Pubes grows thicker, and meeting upon the middle of the Os Pubis makes that riing that is called the Hill of Venus; its outward ubtance is Skin covered with Hair, as the Lips are, which begin to grow in this place about the age of Fourteen; the inner ubtance of the Hill of Venus chiefly conits
of Fat, which makes it bunch up, which in Copulation hinders the bones of the Pubes of the Man and Woman to hit one againt another, which would by cauing pain abate the Venereal pleaure. A Mucle pringing from the phincter of the Fundament lies under this Fat. Its Office is to traighten the Orifice of the Sheath. The Nymphs and the Clitoris appear when the Lips are drawn a little aide: The Nymphs tand next the Urine, as it pouts out from the Bladder, and keeps the Lips from being wet; they are placed on each ide, jut within the Lips, they are two flehy and oft Productions beginning at the upper part of the Privities, where they make that wrinkled membranous Production, which cloaths the Clitoris like a Fore-skin: They are in hape and colour like the Thrils that hang under a Cocks Throat, they have a red ubtance partly Flehy, partly Membranous; within Soft and Spongy, compoed looly of mall Membranes and Veels, o that they are very eaily ditended by the influx of the Animal Spirits and Arterial Blood. They are larger in grown Maids than in Young, and grow larger upon the ue of Venery, and after the Bearing of Children; their ue is to defend the inner Parts, and to cover the paage of the Urine, and a good part of the Orifice of the Sheath in the upper
part of the Privity. Betwixt the Nymphs is placed the Clitoris; it anwers to a Man's Yard, in hape, ituation, ubtance, erection, and differs from it only in length and bignes. Thoe that are called Hermophrodites have it o long and big, as to be able to Convere with Women in the manner of Men. They are not of two Sexs as is commonly reported, only their Stones are placed in the Lips of the Privities, and their Clitoris is preternaturally extended: But in mot it does not appear unles the Lips are drawn aide: It is a little, long and round Body, it lies under the fat of the hill of Venus, and puffs up in Venery, and traightening the Orifice of the Sheath makes it embrace the Virile Member the more cloely: Its outward end is like the Glans of a Men's Yard, and as the Glans in Men is the eat of the greatet pleaure in Copulation; o is this in Women: There is as it were a hole in it, tho indeed there is really no uch thing, mot of it is covered with a thin Membrane from the Conjunction of the Nymphs: It has two pair of Mucles, the upper are round and pring from the bones of the Hip; thee by traitening the roots of the Nervous Bodies, that arie on each ide from the bunching of the Os Ichium detain the Blood and Spirits in them, and o erect the Clitoris, even as
thoe in Men do the Virile Member; the other rie from the Sphincter of the Fundament, and thee erve to traiten and narrow the Orifice of the Sheath: It has Veins, and Arteries, and Nerves, which are omewhat large. In ome Eatern Countries the Clitoris is wont to be o large, that for its deformity, and the hindrance it caues in Copulation, they ued to cut it quite out, or to ear it, to hinder its growth.

The Sheath is o call'd becaue it receives the Virile Member like a heath, it is oft and looe, uneven and wrinkly, of a nervous but omewhat pongy Subtance, which is puft up in Copulation to embrace the Yard the better: Its about even fingers breadth long, and as wide as the trait Gut; but the length and width differ in repect of Age, and as the Woman is more or les provoked to Copulation: The wrinkles are much more numerous and cloe in Virgins, than in thoe that have Born many Children, and in Whores that ue frequent Copulation, and in Women that have had the Whites a long while.

It has very many Arteries and Veins, ome whereof inoculate one with another, and others not. By the Arteries that open into it, the Coures ometimes flow in Women with Child, that are full of Blood. Thee Veels bring plenty of Blood to it
in Copulation, which by heating and puffing up the Sheath increaes the pleaure, and hinders the Man's Seed from cooling, before it is conveyed to the Womb. All along the Sheath there are abundance of Pores, from whence a thin Humour always flows, epecially in Copulation, and increaes the pleaure of the Woman, and is that which is uppoed to be her Seed. Near its outer end, under the Nymphs, in its upper part, it receives the Neck of the Bladder. In Virgins its paage is o narrow, that at their firt Converation with a Man, they have commonly more pain than pleaure, by reaon of the extenion of it by the Virile Member, which breaks ome mall Veels, from whence Blood iues.

The Hymen is a thin nervous Membrane, interwoven with flehy Fibres, and endowed with many little Arteries, and Veins, behind the inertion of the Neck of the Bladder, with a hole in the midt, that will admit the top of ones little finger, whereby the Coures flow, it is alo called the Girdle of Chatity. But it is broken and bleeds at the firt Copulation, and never cloes again. But tho' a Man when he finds thee igns of Virginity, may certainly conclude he has Married a Maid; yet if they are wanting, it does not necearily follow that Virginity is wanting;
for the Hymen may be corroded by harp Humours flowing through it with the Coures, and from other Caues; or, if a Maid be o indicreet as to become a Bride while her Coures flow, or within a Day after, then the Hymen and the wrinkled Membrane of the Sheath are o relaxed, that the Virile Member may enter without any obtruction, and o give upition of Unchatity, when there is really no occaion for it. Sometimes in old Maids the Hymen is o trong that it cannot be penetrated without difficulty; and in ome it is naturally quite cloed up, and o their Coures are topt, which much endangers their Life; if it be not opened with a Chirurgical Intrument.

The Myrtle-berry Caruncles lie cloe to the Hymen, the larget of 'em is uppermot, tanding jut at the Mouth of the paage of the Urine, which it huts after making water; oppoite to this at the bottom of the Sheath there is another, and in each ide one. But of thee, there is only the firt in Maids, the other three being made by the broken Hymen. Thee three when the Sheath is extended diappear in Labour, and cannot be een till the Sheath is contracted to its natural traitnes.

The Sheath near its outer Orifice, has a Sphincter Mucle about three fingers broad
that contracts it as the cae requires; and therefore Men and Women need not doubt but that their Genitals will be proportionable, for the Sheath is o artificially made, that it can uit with every Penis.

The Womb is eated in the lowet part of the Belly, betwixt the Bladder and traight Gut, its hindmot part is looe, that it may be extended as the Child increaes, but its ides are tied fat by two pair of Ligaments. Its ubtance is whitih, nervous, and compact in Virgins, but a little pongy and oft in Women with Child. It has two Membranes, the outer is trong and double ariing from the Peritoneum, the inner being proper is Fibrous and more Porous. Betwixt thee Membranes, there is a certain flehy and fibrous contexture, which in Women with Child, together with the aid Membranes, imbibes o much of the nutritious Humours, that then flow thither, that the more the Child increaes, the more flehy, fibrous, and thick does the Womb grow, o that in the lat months it is an inch thick, and ome times two fingers breadth, tho' it be extended to o much greater compas, than it has when a Woman is not with Child, and yet within three weeks after Delivery it is as thin as before, and contracts o wonderfully, that it may be held in ones hand. In Virgins it is about
two fingers breadth broad, and three long; in thoe that have Copulated, it is a little bigger, it is like a Pear, only a little flattih above and below, but in Women with Child it becomes more round. In Maids its cavity is o mall, that it will hardly contain a large Hazel-nut; it is divided be a Line that goes length-ways, much like that in a Man's Cod. Its Arteries pring partly from the Spermatick and Hypogatrick; they run along the Womb, bending and winding, that they may be extended without danger of breaking, when the Womb is tretched with the Child. The monthly Coures flow by thee Arteries in greatet quantity into the Womb it elf: But in les quantity by the Branches that open into the Neck of the Womb, and a mall quantity of the Coures come out of the Sheath. It is much diputed what is the reaon of the Coures, whether they flow by reaon of too great quantity of Blood, or whether at et times; there is alo a fermentation of the Blood, which opens the orifices of the Arteries: But it is mot probable that it proceeds from a fermentation at appointed times, for if a Woman feeds high and o breeds much Blood, the Coures flow never the ooner, tho' perhaps they may be in a greater quantity; and if he ue the greatet abtinence and parenes
of Diet, they will not be the longer before they come, o that when through uch effervency the Blood flows plentifully into the Veels of the Womb, and the Veins of the Womb are not able to carry it all back again by Circulation, it flows out of the extremities of the Arteries o long, till the too great quantity of the Blood is leened, and the fermentation ceaes, which it does uually after three or four days. The Coures eldom flow in Women with Child, and the wanting of them is their firt item of having Conceived.

The Veins pring from the Preparantes, and from the Epigatrick, the Nerves from the greatet plexus of the meentery of the Intercotal Pair, and from the lowet plexus of the ame, and alo from the Nerves of the Os Sacrum, and the ame run alo to the Tetes or Ovaria. Thee plexus of Nerves are chiefly affected in Hyterick Fits, and are Convulive, and often happen when the Womb is not at all in fault; and the Ball that eems to rie from the bottom of the Belly in thee Fits, and to beat trongly about the Navel, which is uually uppoed to be the riing of the Womb, is nothing but a Convulion of thee Nerves; for ome Men are troubled with the ame Symptom.
The ue of the Womb is to receive into its capacity the principals of the formation of the Fetus, to afford it nourihment, and to preerve it from injuries, and at length to expel it.

The neck of the Womb eems to be a part of the Fundus, only it is much more narrower, for its cavity is no wider in Virgins than a mall Quill, and in Women with Child its inner orifice does either quite cloe its ides together, or is daubed up with a limy yellowih Humour, o that nothing then can enter into the Womb. It has the ame Membranes, and the ame Veels with the Womb.

The Spermatick Veels are of two orts; Arteries and Veins; the Arteries are two as in Men.
