They pring from the great Artery a little below the Emulgents (very rarely either of them from the Emulgent it elf) and pas down towards the Tetes, not by uch a direct coure as in Men, but with much twirling and winding among the Veins, with which they have no inoculation, as has been generally aid. But for all their Winding, when they are tretched out to their full length, they are not o long as thoe of Men. The Veins are two, ariing as in Men, the right from the Trunk of the Cava, a little below the Emulgent, and the left from the Emulgent it elf, but they are much horter than in Men; both the Arteries and Veins as they pas down are covered with one common Coat from the Peritoneum, and near the Tetes they are divided into two
Branches, the upper whereof is implanted into the Teticle by a Triple-root, and the other is ubdivided below the Tetes into three twigs, one of which goes to the bottom of the Womb, another to the Tuba and round ligament, the third creeping by the ide of the Womb, under its common Membrane ends in its Neck, where it is Woven with the Hypogatrick Veels like a net. By this way it is that the Coures ometimes flow in Women with Child, for the firt Months, and not out of the inner Cavity of the Womb.

The ue of thee Spermatick Veels is not to Miniter to the Generation of Seed, according to the Ancient Doctrine, but to the Nutrition of the Eggs in the Ovaria or Tetes, according to the new, and to the nourihment of the Fetus, and of the solid parts, and the expurgation of the Coures.

The carrying Veels that go traight from the Tetes to the bottom of the Womb, and were uppoed to emit the Seed from the Stones into the bottom of the Womb, are accounted by de Graef only Ligaments of the Teticles to keep them in their place; for they come not to the Inner Cavity of the VVomb. The Fallopian Tubes are very lender and narrow Ducts, nervous and white, ariing from
the horns or ides of the VVomb, and at a little ditance from it they become larger, and twit like the tendrel of a Vine, till nearer their end, where ceaing their winding they turn very large, and eem membranous and flehy, which end is very much torn and jagged like rent Cloths, and has a large Foramen, which lies cloed, becaue thoe jaggs fall together, but it being opened, they are like the utmot Orifice of a Bras Trumpet. Thee Tubes, according to Dr. Harvey, are the ame in VVomen, that the horns of the VVomb are in other creatures, for they anwer to thoe both in ituation, connexion, amplitude, perforation, likenes, and alo Office. The capacity of thee Ducts varies very much; for in the beginning, as it goes out of the VVomb, it only admits a Britle, but in its progres, where it is larget, it will receive ones little finger; but in the outmot extremity, where it is divided into jaggs, it is but about a quarter o wide. They are very uncertain alo in their length, for from four or five they ometimes increae to eight or nine fingers breadth long. Their ue is in a fruitful Copulation to grant a paage to a more ubtile part of the Maculine Seed, or to a Seminal Air towards the Tetes to bedew the Eggs contained in
them, which Eggs, one or more being by that means fecundated, and dropping off from the Tetes, are received by the extremity of the Tubes, and carried along the inner Cavity to the Womb. But it may be objected that the narrownes of the Tubes are not fit for uch a ue; yet
e that coniders the traitnes of the inner Orifice of the Womb, both in Maids and in Women with Child, and yet oberves it to dilate o much upon occaion, as to make way for the Birth of a Child, cannot wonder that to erve a neceary end of Nature, the mall duct of the Tubes, hould be o far widened, as to allow paage to an Egg, eeing its proportion to their duct is many times les, than of the Child to the uual largnes of the aid Orifice.

div.head: CHAP. XV.
Of Conception.
div.p:
COnception is nothing ele but an action of the Womb, whereby the prolifie Seeds of the Man and Woman are there received and retained, that an Infant may be engendered, and formed out of it.
There are two orts of Conception, the one true, according to Nature, to which ucceeds the Generation of the Infant in the Womb; the other fale, as a fale Conception, Mole, or any other trange Matter.
It is not abolutely neceary, that the Mans Seed hould be received, and retained entire; for a mall quantity of it may be ufficient, nay a meer team of it, to impregnat.

Conception may be known by the more than ordinary delight in the act, and ome few Months after, the Woman perceives a mall pain about her Navel, and ome little Commotions in the bottom of her belly. The inward Orifice of the Womb is exactly cloed, he longs for trange things, he is often troubled with Naueating and Vomiting, her Coures are topt, the Navel tarts, her Nipples are very obcure or dark coloured, with a yellowih circle round about, her eyes are dejected and hollow, the Whites of them dull and troubled, her Blood, when he has Conceived ome time, is always bad; the Belly is flat: Yet it mut be acknowledged that ome of thee igns are alo to be found upon an Obtruction of the Coures in Virgins; wherefore judgment upon Conception mut not be too
poitive, epecially, when the Woman is upon tryal for her life, for ome upon having their Coures have been judged not with Child, and yet after Execution have been found to be o.

The Infant moves it elf manifetly about the forth Month, ooner or later as the Woman is trong or weak. Some Women feel it from the econd, others about the third Month, and ome before that time. At the beginning, the firt motions are very mall, but grow greater proportionably, as the Infant grows bigger and tronger.

div.head: CHAP. XVI.
Of a Mole.
div.p:
A Mole is deformed and ueles Fleh contained in the Womb, and is occaioned by the corrupted Seed of the Man and Woman, for it is never generated without the ue of Copulation; it is covered with a Membrane and ticks to the Womb, the longer it is retained in the Womb the harder it grows, and is more difficultly expelled: Mot commonly there is but one, yet ometimes more; when it
is ejected in the econd Month it's called a fale Conception.

It's difficult to ditinguih a Mole, from being with Child, for the Coures are topt, the Belly grows big by degrees, and the Breats are increaed. But the firt ign of it is a leaden colour in the Face, the Belly is harder and orer than when a Woman is with Child, and it is very troubleome and painful to go with, and it falls on whatoever ide he turns; there is a great wearines in her Legs and Thighs, he finds a great heavines at the bottom of her Belly, and her Urin is obtructed; but it may be certainly known, if no motion be felt after four or five Months, or when her Reckoning is out. Some have a Mole two or three Years, and ometimes much longer.

As to the Cure, I hall peak only of that part of it which may be performed by Medicines, for if it tick much to the bottom of the Womb, or is very large, it will carce be expelled unles a Chyrurgeon extract it.

Give the Woman a Spoonful of Syrup of Mugwort Morning and Evening for three days following, either by it elf or mixt with an Ounce of Penny-royal-water; afterwards Purge her every other day, or every third day with the fetid Pill, two Scruples
or a Dram may be taken at a time early in the Morning, and let her leep if he can till they begin to work; let her be purged in this manner five times.
Things that looen mut be alo applied frequently to the Womb to open the paages likewie to the Belly, Groins, Loins, and Hips, with Spunges and Flannels; the following Fomentation is of excellent ue.

Take of the leaves of Marh-mallows and Mallows each one handful, of the roots of round and long Birthwort each one handful, of the leaves of Mugwort, Mercury, Feverfew, Sage, Hyop and Calaminth each half an handful, of the Seeds of Flax, Marhmallows, Fenugreek, Anie, Lovage, each half an Ounce, of the Flowers of Camomile, Melilote, Roemary, Broom, Mugwort, each one Pugil, of Bran one Pugil; hoyl them in a ufficient quantity of Water to five quarts; add of Oyl of Olives half a pint, of the Oyls of Camomile and weet Almonds each four Ounces, of the Oyl of Lillies two Ounces; foment the parts as above directed, and afterwards anoint them with Ointment of Marhmallows.

div.head: CHAP. XVII.
Of Superfoetation.
div.p:
THere is a great dipute whether a Woman, who hath two or more Children at once, conceived of them at one or everal coitions: Some will have this to be uperfoetation; but there are igns whereby we may know the difference, whether both Children were begotten at once, or ucceively one after another. Supefoetation, according to Hippocrates, is a reiterated Conception, when a Woman being already with Child conceives again the econd time. That which makes many believe, that there can be no Superfoetation is, becaue as oon as a Woman has Conceived, her Womb cloes, and is exactly firm, o that the Seed of the Man, abolutely neceary to Conception, finding no place nor entry, cannot, as they ay, be received, nor contained in it: But it may be anwered, that tho' the Womb be uually exactly hut and cloe, when a Woman has Conceived, yet it may be ometimes opened to let pas ome ferous limy Excrements, or epecially when a Woman is much delighted in the act of Copulation.
But this econd Conception is very rare; for we mut not imagine, that when a Woman brings forth two or more Children at once, there is a Superfoetation; becaue they are almot always begot in the ame act, by the reception of abundance of Seed into the Womb.

When a Woman brings forth one or more Children at a Birth, begotten at once, which are uually called Twins, it is known by their being both almot of an equal bignes and thicknes, and by having but one common after-birth, not eparated one from the other, but by their Membranes: But if there are everal Children, and a Superfoetation, they will not have a common burthen, nor will they be of an equal bignes.
To conclude, Of a hundred Women that have Twins, ninety of them have but one burthen common to them both, which is a certain ign they had no Superfoetation.

div.head: CHAP. XVIII.
Of the Womb-Cake, of the Membranes involving the Child, and of the Humours contain'd in them, of the umbilical Veels, of the parts of a Child that differ from thoe of the adult.
div.p:
THE Womb-Cake, otherwie called the Womb-Liver, for the likenes of ubtance, is oft, and has innumerable Fibres and mall Veels; it is two Fingers breadth, thick in its middle, but thinner near the edges, and a quarter of a Yard over from one ide to the other, when the Infant is near the Birth; on that ide next the Foetus, it is mooth and omething hollowih, like Navelwort, and is knit to the Chorion; but on that next the Womb, it is very unequal, having a great many bunchings, whereby it ticks fat to the Womb. VVhen there is but one Child in the Womb, it is but one; but if there be Twins there are two Womb-Cakes, and a particular rope of Umbilical Veels is inerted into each from each Child; it grows not out of the Womb originally, but its firt rudiments appear like a woolly ubtance on the outide of the outer Membrane that
invets the Embrio called Chorion, about the eighth or ninth Week, upon which in a hort while a red flehly and oft ubtance grows, but unequally and a little in knobs, and then it preently thereby ticks to the Womb, and is very conpicuous about the twelfth or thirteenth Week, till now the Infant is increaed and nourihed wholly by the appoition of the Critalline or albugineous liquor, wherein it wims looe in the inner Membrane, called Amnios, having no Umbilical Veels, whereby to receive any thing from the Womb-Cake. But when it grows bigger, and begins to want nourihment, the extremities of the Umbilical Veels begin to grow out of the Navel by little and little, and are extended towards the Womb-cake, that they may draw out of it a more nourihing juice, and carry it to the Infant, as Plants do from the Earth by their roots. It has Veels from the Womb and from the Chorion; the former are of four kinds, Arteries, Veins, Nerves, and Lympheducts; all which tho' they be very large, and viible in the Womb, and alo where the Womb-Cake is joyned to it, yet they end the mallet Capilaries to the Womb it elf. Thoe that come from the Chorion are Arteries and Veins. The Arteries and Veins that come from the Womb,
pring from the Hypogatricks, and alo that branch of the Supermaticks that is incerted into the bottom of the Womb; thoe that come from the Chorion are the Umbilical Veels of the Infant. The Womb-Cake after it is joyned to the Womb, ticks mot firmly to it for the firt Months, as unripe Fruit does to the Tree, but as the Infant becomes bigger and riper, and nearer to the Birth, by o much the more eaily will it part from the Womb, and at length it falls out of the Womb, and makes part of the Afterbirth.

Next to the Womb-Cake follow the two Membranes, viz. Chorion the outer, and Amnios the inner, wherein the Child is wrapt: Betwixt thee two after the Child is perfectly formed, there is a third, viz. Allantois. The Chorion is pretty thick, mooth on the inide, but without omewhat unequal and rough, and in that part of it which ticks to the Womb-cake, and by it to the Womb, it has very many Veels which pring from the Womb it elf and the Umbilical Veels. Twins are both incloed in one Chorion, but have each a particular Amnios; it invets the Egg orriginally, which Egg being brought to the Womb, and becoming a Conception, this Membrane imbibes the moiture that bedews
the Womb plentifully at that time. This Liquor that it imbibes, is thought to be the Nutritious Juice that ouzes out of the Capilary Orifices of the Hypogatrick and Spermatick Arteries, and is of the ame nature with that which afterward is eparated in the Womb-cake, and carried to the Infant by the Umbilical Vein; and with that alo which abounds in the Amnios even till the Birth.

The Amnios is the inmot Membrane that immediately contains the Child; it is not knit to the Chorion in any place ave where the Umbilical Veels pas through them both into the Womb-cake; it is very thin, oft, mooth, and pellucid, and encompaes the Infant very looly, it has Veels from the ame Origins as the Chorion. From a limpid Liquor contained in this Membrane, the firt lineaments of the Embrio are drawn. But becaue this Liquor is o very little, there weats through this Membrane preently part of that Nutritious Albugineous Humour that is contained in the Chorion, which it had imbibed out of the Womb, and by the addition of this Humour to the undicernible Rudiments of the Embrio, it receives its increae. But tho' the Amnios have its additional Nutricious Liquor at firt only by Tranudation, yet when the Umbilical
Veels, and the Womb-cakes are formed, it receives it after another manner, for then being eparated from the Mothers Arteries by the Placenta, and imbibed by the Umbilical Veins of the Infant paes directly to its Heart, from whence being driven a great part of it down the Aorta, it is ent forth again by the Umbilical Arteries, out of whoe Capillaries dipered plentifully through the Amnios, it iues into its cavity. A third Membrane which invets the whole Infant is the Allantoides; it has the ame Figure as the Chorion and Amnios, betwixt which it is placed in their whole circumference. Now, tho' it mut be uppoed that this as well as the other two is originally in the Egg, yet there is no appearance of it, till after the Umbilical Veels and the Womb-cake are formed, and the albugineous Liquor ceaes to be imbibed by the Chorion out of the Uterus; but as oon as the Infant begins to be nourihed by the Umbilical Veels, and the Urachus is permeable, then preently this Membrane begins to hew it elf, containing a very thin Liquor, which is the Urine of the Infant brought into it by the Urachus, and wherewith it is filled daily more and more till the Birth: It may be known from the Chorion and Amnios by this, that they have numerous Veels dipered through them;
but this has not the leat viible Vein or Artery; it is very hard to eparate the Chorion from it, but towards the Birth it becomes o turgid with Urine, that the Amnios which immediately contains the Infant, wims <> Liquor that it contains is the Urine <> brought hither by the <> oon as the Infant is perfect <> , its Kidneys mut needs perform <> Office of eparating the Serum from the Blood, for otherwie it would be affected with an Anarca; I ay, the Serum is eparated in the Kidneys, and glides down from thence into the Bladder, wherein there is a pretty large quantity when the Infant is five or ix months old: Now it flows not out of the Bladder by its orifice, becaue at that time the Sphincter is too contracted and narrow, and if it hould pas that way, it would mix with the nourihing juice wherein the Infant wims in the Amnios, and wherewith by taking it in by its mouth, it is partly nourihed, and o would defile and corrupt it. Nature therefore has provided it another paage by the Urachus inerted into the bottom of the Bladder, which tho it grows olid like a Ligament after the Child is Born, as the umbilical Vein does, yet while the Infant is in the Womb, it is open and conveighs the Urine into the Allantoides,
that is placed betwixt the Chorion and Amnios, where it is collected and preerved till the Birth.

The Naval-tring is membraneous, wreathed, and unequal, and aries from the Navel; it reaches to the Womb-cake; it is about half an Ell long, and a finger thick, The Veels contained in this tring, and covered with the common coat called Funiculus are four, one Vein, two Arteries, and the Urachus; the Vein is larger than the Aretries, and aries from the Liver of the Infant at the trunk of the Vena porta, and from thence paing out of the Navel it runs along the Funiculus to the Womb-cake, into which it is implanted by innumerable Roots; but before it reaches it, it ends ome little twigs into the Amnios. The umbilical Vein erves for conveying to the Infant the nutricious juice eparated in the Womb-cake from the Mothers Arteries; but together with this juice returns o much of the Arterial blood, that comes from the Infant, as is not pent upon the nourihment of the Womb-cake, or of the Chorion and Amnios.

In the Funiculus are included alo two Arteries, which are not both of them together o big as the Vein; they pring out of the inner Iliacal branches of the great Artery, and paing by the ides of the Bladder,
they rie up to the Navel, out of which they are conducted to the Womb-cake, in the ame common cover with the Vein and Urachus wherewith they are twined and wreathed like a Rope. Spirituous blood is driven from the Infant by the beating of its Heart to the Womb-cake, and the Membranes, for nourihment, from which, what Blood remains circulates back again to the umbilical Vein together with nutricious juice, imbibed afreh by its Capillaries dipered in the Womb-cake. But beides Arterial Blood, there flows out of the Navel by them part of the Nutricious juice, that was imported by the umbilical Vein, I ay flows out by thee Arteries, which by their branches, that are dipered through the Amnios, dicharge it by their little mouths into it. The fourth Umbilical Veel is the Urachus, or Urinary Veel, it is a mall, membranous, round Pipe indued with a traight cavity ariing from the bottom of the Bladder up to the Navel; out of which it paes along within the common cover and opens into the Allantoides. Thee four Veels, as has been aid above, have one common cover, which alo keeps each of them from touching the other; it is called Funiculus; it is membranous, round and hollow, indifferent thick, coniting of a double coat, the inner from the Peritoneum,
and the outer from the Paniculus carnous. It has everal knots, which Dr. Wharton thinks are little Glands, through which the nutricious juice ditills out of the capacity of the Funiculus into the cavity of the Amnios.

Midwives gues by their number how many more Children the Mother hall have, but without reaon. When the Infant is Born, its Navel-rope is wont to be tyed about one or two fingers breadth from the Navel, with a trong Thread cat about it everal times, and then about two or three fingers breadth beyond the Ligature to be cut off; what is not cut off is uffered to remain till it drop off of its own accord.

As to the way how the Infant is nourihed there has been great Diputes, ome affirm by Blood only, and that received by the Umbilical Vein, others by Chile only received in by the Mouth; but indeed according to the different degrees of Perfection, that an Egg paes from Conception to an Infant ready for the Birth, it is nourihed variouly. For, Firt, As oon as an Egg Impregnated decends into the Womb, it preently imbibes through its outer Membrane ome of that albugineous Liquor, that at this time plentifully bedews the internal Superfices of the Womb, o that as
oon as the firt Lineaments of an Embryo begin to be drawn, out of that Humour contained in the Amnios, they preently receive increae by the appoition of the aid Liquor filtrated out of the Chorion through the Amnios into its cavity; and this ame Liquor, that thus increaes the firt rudiments of the Embryo, Dr. Harvey calls Coliquamentum. But when the parts of the Embryo begin to be a little more perfect, and the Chorion becomes o dene, that not any more of the aid Liquor is imbibed by it, the Umbilical Veels begin to be formed, and to extend to the ide of the Amnios which they penetrate, and both the Vein and Arteries pas alo through the Allantois and Chorion, and are implanted into the Womb-Cake, that at this time, firt gathering upon the Chorion joins it to the Womb; and now the Hypogatrick and Spermatick Arteries, that before cat the nutricious Juice into the cavity of the Womb, open by the orifices into the Womb-cake, where they depoite the aid juice, which is aborded by the Umbilical Vein, and by it conveyed, firt to the Liver, then to the Heart of the Infant, where the thinner and the more pirituous part of it is turn'd into Blood; but the more gros and earthy part of it decending by the Aorta enters the Umbilical Arteries, and
by thoe branches of them, that run through the Amnios, is dicharged into its cavity.

The groer nutricious Juice being depoited by the Umbilical Arteries in the Amnios, as oon as the Mouth, Gullet, and Stomach, and the like are formed o perfectly, that the Foetus can wallow, it ucks in ome of the aid Juice, which decending into the Stomach and Intetines, is received by the Lacteal Veins, as in grown Perons. The Infant therefore is nourihed three everal ways, but only by one Humour: Firt, by appoition of it, while it is yet an imperfect Embrio, and has not the Umbilical Veels formed: But after thee are perfected, it then receives the ame nutricious Juice by the Umbilical Vein, the more Spirituous and thin part whereof it changes into Blood, and ends forth the groer part by the Umbilical Artery into the Amnios, which the Infant ucks in at its Mouth, and undergoing a new Concoction in its tomach, is received out of the Intetines by the Lacteal Veins, as is done after the birth.

A Child in the Womb differs from an adult Peron in many parts, the parts are les, the colour of the whole reddih, the Bones oft, and many of them gritly and flexible in the Head: There are everal
differences: Firt, the Head, in repect to the proportion of the ret of the Body, is bigger, the Crown is not covered with Bone, but only with a Membrane; the Bone of the Forehead is divided, as alo of the under Jaw, and the Os Cuneiforme is divided into four. The Bone of the hinder part of the Head is ditinguihed into three, four or five Bones. The Brain is ofter, and more fluid, and the Nerves very oft. The Bones that erve the Sene of Hearing are wonderfully hard and big; the Teeth lie hid in the little holes of the Jaw-bone; the Dugs well, and out of them in Infants new born, whether Male or Female, a erous Milk iues forth ometimes of its own accord, and ometimes with a gentle preure: The Vertebrae of the Back want their pinous procees, and each of them made of three ditinct Bones: The Heart is remarkably big, and its Auriculae large: There are two Unions of the greater Veels, that are not conpicuous in grown Perons: Firt, the Foramen ovale, by which there is a paage open, out of the Cava into the Vein of the Lungs, jut as each of them are opening, the firt into the right Ventricle, and the latter into the left Ventricle of the Heart, and this Foramen, jut as it opens into the Vein of the Lungs has a Valve
that hinders any thing from returning out of the aid Vein into the Foramen: Secondly, the Arterial Channel, which two fingers breadth from the Bais of the Heart joyns the Artery of the Lungs to the Aorta; it has a pretty lage Cavity, and acends a little obliquely from the aid Artery to the Aorta, into which it conveys the Blood, that was driven into the Artery of the Lungs, out of the right Ventricle of the Heart, o that it never comes into the left Ventricle, as the Blood that is ent out of the left Venticle into the Aorta never came in the right, except a little that is returned from the nutrition of the Lungs, but pat immediately into it out of the Vena Cava by the Foramen ovale, o that the Blood paes not through both the Ventricles, as it does after the Child is born. You may know whether Infants killed by Whores, and which they commonly affirm were till-born, were really o or no, by putting the Lungs of the Infant in Water; for if they were till-born the Lungs will ink, if alive, o as to breath never o little while, they will wim. The Gland Thymus is very large, and conits as it were of three Glands; the Umbilical Veels go out of the Abdomen; the Stomach is narrower, but pretty full of a whitih liquor: The Caul is carce viible, the
Guts are eventimes longer than the Body; the Excrements in the mall Guts are flegmatick and yellow, but in the thick omewhat hard and blackih, ometimes greenih; the Caecum is larger than uual, and often fill'd with Faeces: the Liver is very large, and extends it elf into the left ide, and covers all the upper part of the Stomach, it has a paage, which is not in grown Perons, called the Veiny Channel, which ariing out of the Sinus of the Porta, carries the greatet part of what is brought by the Umbilical Vein directly, and in a full tream into the Cava above the Liver: But this paage preently cloes, as oon as the Infant is born, and turns to a ligament, as doth the Urachus and the two Umbilical Arteries. The Spleen is mall; the Gall-bladder is full of yellow or green Choler; the Sweet-bread is very large and white; the Kidneys are bigger and unequal in their Superficies; the Renes Succenturiati are exceeding large; the Ureters are wide, and the Bladder tretched with Urine; in Females the VVomb is depreed, the Tubes long, and the Tetes very large; the little Bones of the VVrits and Intep are gritly, and not firmly joyned together.

Its Knees are drawn up to the Belly, its Legs bending backwards, its Feet acros,
and its Hands lifted up to its head, one of which it holds to the Temple or Ear, the other to the Cheek, where there are white pots on the Skin, as if it had been rubbed upon; the Back-bone turns round, the Head hanging down towards its Knees, its Face commonly towards the Mothers Back; but near the birth, ometimes a VVeek or two before, it alters its ituation, and tumbles down with its Head to the Neck of the VVomb, and its Feet upwards; then the VVomb alo ettles downwards, and its Orifice relaxes, and opens; and the Infant moving up and down tears the Membrans wherein it is included, and the waters flowing into the Sheath; but ometimes the Membranes come forth whole; at the ame time the neighbouring parts are looened and become fit for ditenion, and the Bones near are o much relaxed in their Joynts, that they make way for the Infant, and the motion of it o much diturbs the VVomb, that the Fibres of it and the Mucles of the Belly contract altogether to expel it.

div.head: CHAP. XIX.
Of the Management of a Woman with Child.
div.p:
THE Woman ought to be kept in a good moderate and clear Air, and he mut Eat what he likes bet, and be ure not to Fat too long; only he mut oberve not to eat too much at a time; and to comfort the Stomach, which is always weak in this condition, he may Drink a little Wine, or for want of it trong Beer at Meals. As to Sleep, a Woman with Child requires more leep than he does at other times. As to Exercie and Ret, he mut order her elf according to the different times; for at the beginning he ought to keep her elf quiet, and not to ue Copulation: Riding on Hore-back, or in a Waggon, or indeed in a Coach is not afe at any time of her being with Child, epecially when he is near her time, for uch Exercies often caue Micarriage. But he may Walk gently, or be carried in a Chair. She mut not carry or lift heavy Burdens, or lift up her Arms too high, and therefore ought not to dres her own Head. Let her Exercie be gentle walking in low-heel'd
Shoes; but he had better Ret too much than Exercie too much, for more hard Labours are occaioned by violent Exercie than by any other thing. Moreover, it is convenient that the Woman hould abtain from Copulation the lat two months, for the Body is very much moved, and the Belly compreed in the action, which caues the Child to take a wrong poture.
If the Belly be bound, as it is often at this time, Prunes tewed, or Veal Broath may be often ued, or the following Gliter may be ued.
Boyl an Handful of Mallow Leaves, in three quarters of a Pint of Milk, let the Milk jut boyl up, add to it two Ounces of brown Sugar, and a little freh Butter, train it for ue.

She mut moderate her Paions, and great care mut be taken that he be not Frighted, and that Melancholy News be not uddenly told her, but you mut endeavour to keep her as chearful as poibly you can, the udden urprizes of joy mut be alo avoided, for excees on either hand are prejudicial. The Cloaths of a Woman with Child hould it eaie, for any immoderate preure is apt to make the Child deformed, and hurts the Breats, and very often caues micarriage. Unneceary Bleeding mut be avoided, o mut all trong Purges
but if Purging is requiite, only uch things as Purge gently mut be ued, as Caia, Rubarb, and Manna. The Caia is bet ucked out of the Canes, the Rubarb may be chewed, and an Ounce and a half or two Ounces of Manna may be diolved in Poet-drink, and ued upon occaion in the Morning.

Vomiting often afflicts Women with Child, but if it be moderate and at the beginning and without great training it is beneficial; if it continues longer than the third or fourth Month it ought to be remedied; in order to which let the Woman ue good food, and a little at a time, and let her ue with her meat the juice of Oranges, he may eat now and then Broth mixed with the yolk of an Egg, for it's very nourihing and of eaie digetion, and after meals let her eat a little Marmalade of Quinces, and he may drink a Glas of Claret; he mut forbear fat meat and Sauces, and weet and ugar'd Sauces. But if the Vomiting continues notwithtanding this regular Diet till the Woman is above half gon, he mut take the following Purge.

Take of Tamarinds half an Ounce, of Sena one Dram, of Rubarb one Dram and an half, boyl them in a ufficient quantity of water, in three Ounces of the trained Liquor diolve an Ounce of Manna, and an Ounce of Syrup of
Succory with Rubarb; make a purging potion to be taken in the Morning. It may be repeated once or oftener upon occaion.
And it may be proper for the Woman in the Winter time to were a Lambskin or the like upon her Stomach and Belly.

If pains of the Back, Reins and Hips are violent, the Woman mut be blooded, and take at bed-time ixteen drops of the Liquid Laudanum mentioned at the latter end of the Chapter of Hyteric Dieaes in a glas of Canary Wine, or in any thing ele he likes, and he mut keep her Bed till the pain abates; if the pain is continual, the Belly mut be upported with a Swaith fitted for the purpoe.

If after the third or fourth Month the Breats are very painful, 'tis convenient the Woman hou'd bleed in the Arm, if he be full of blood, and ue a Diet that is moderately cooling and nourihing; but if the pain comes at the beginning, we ought to leave the whole buines to nature, only the Woman mut have a care that he receives no blows on thoe parts, nor mut he be trait laced, for fear the Breats hou'd impotumate.

If incontinence or difficulty of Urin be occaion'd by the weight and bignes of the Belly, the Woman may remedy it, and eae her elf, if when he wou'd make water,
he lift up with both her hands the bottom of her Belly, or he may wear a large Swaith fitted for this ue, to bear up the Belly, but the bet way is to keep her in Bed.
If a harpnes of Urin caues an Inflammation on the Neck of the Bladder, it may be appeaed by a regular cooling Diet, and emulions of the cold Seeds ued Morning and Evening.

Take of blanched Almonds number twelve, of the four greater cold Seeds each one Dram and an half, of the Seeds of Lettice and white Poppies each half a Dram, beat them in a Marble Mortar, and pour on them gently three quarters of a pint of Poppy Water, make an emulion for two does, add one Ounce of Syrup of Violets and half a Dram of Sal Prunella.

If the Inflammation and Sharpnes of Urine be not removed by the things above-mention'd, a little Blood may be taken from the Arm, and the neck of the Bladder may be bathed with the following Decoction, with Flannels dipt in it and preed out.

Take of the roots of Marh-mallows one Ounce, of the Leaves of Mallows, Marh-mallows, Pellitory, and Violets, each one handful, of the Flowers of Melilote one handful, of the Seeds of Flax and Fenugreek each two Drams, boyl them in a ufficient quantity of Water to a pint and half.
But if the Woman notwithtanding he oberves thee directions cannot make water, it mut be drawn out with a Catheter by an Artit.

If the Woman be troubled with a violent Cough he mut be blooded in the Arm at any time of her being with Child, for this is apt to occaion micarriage, and all alted and piced meat and harp things mut be forborn. She may now and then ue juice of Liquorih, Sugar Candy, and Syrup of Violets, and if the Body be bound a Gliter of Milk and Sugar may be injected. The following Syrup is very proper in this cae.

Take half a pint of Claret Wine, one Dram of Cinnamon, half a Dozen Cloves, and four Ounces of Sugar, burn the Wine, and boyl it to the conitence of a Syrup, whereof let the Woman take three poonfuls at Bedtime.

The Woman mut go looe in her Clothes, and if the Rheum be very thin, and the Cough tickles much, Sixteen drops of the Liquid Laudanum mentioned in the Chapter of Hyteric Dieaes mut be now and then taken at bedtime in ome liquor he ues to drink.

If the Legs and Thighs well and are painful, they mut be waithed with a Swaith three or four Fingers broad, beginning to waith from the bottom; but in
this cae 'tis bet for the Woman to be kept in Bed; if there be igns of fulnes of blood, he mut be blooded in the Arm.

If the big bellied Woman be troubled with the Piles, and abound with Blood, he mut be blooded in the Arm, and if her Body is Cotive, the emollient Glyter mentioned above mut be ued, and afterwards to eae the Pain they mut be anointed often with Populean Ointment mixt with a few Grains of Opium: For intance,
Take of Populean Ointment one Dram, of Opium five Grains, beat them well together in a Mortar, and anoint the Piles with it twice or thrice a day.
But if the Inflammation and the welling are much, you mut apply Leeches to the part affected, and let her keep her Bed.

If the Piles bleed of themelves immoderately (for if the Flux be moderate at this time the Woman being full of Blood he may be relieved thereby) a cooling and thickening coure of Diet mut be order'd, as three parts of Fountain water, and one of Milk boyl'd together and drank cold, roated Apples, Barly-broths, and the like, alo thickning and cooling Juleps and Emulions.

Take of the Waters of Plantain and Cinnamon hordeated each four Ounces, of ditilled
Vinegar half an Ounce, of True-bole and Dragons-blood each half a Dram, of the Liquid Laudanum mentioned in the Chapter of Hyteric Fits thirty drops, of Syrup of Myrtles one Ounce and an half, mix them and make a Julep, let her take four or five Spoonfuls every night at Bed-time.

Take of the four greater cold Seeds, each one Dram and an half, of weet Almonds number four, of the Seeds of white Poppies two Drams, Plantain Water eight Ounces, of red Poppy Water four Ounces, of Cinnamon Water hordeated one Ounce and an half, make an Emulion, to which add three Drams of pearled Sugar, and half an Ounce of the Juice of Cevil Orange, mingle them, let her take four Ounces thrice a day.
Bleeding in the Arm is alo proper in this cae to turn the Flux.

If a loones comes upon a Woman with Child, and continues above five days, he mut ue Food of eaie digetion and little at a time, and let her Drink be Claret Wine mixt with Water, wherein Iron has been quenched, and now and then Milk boyl'd with thrice the quantity of Water, or the white Decoction made in the following manner.

Take of Calcined Harts-horn powder'd two Ounces, of Fountain water two quarts, boyl it till half is conumed, train it gently through
a linnen rag, and add to it three Ounces of Syrup of Quinces.
And before Meals he may eat a little Marmalade of Quinces. But note, that before he ues thee atringents, it will be convenient to purge off the ill humours with the following Potion.

Take of Rubarb one Dram and a half, of Sena two Drams, boyl them in a ufficient quantity of Water, to three Ounces of train'd Liquor, add one Ounce of Syrup of Succory with Rubarb, and two Drams of Cinnamon-water. Let it be taken in the Morning.

But if the Loones turn to the Bloody-flux, the cae is very dangerous, and therefore after the ue of the purging Potion above mention'd, if the Woman has trength enough to bear it, you mut immediately give ixteen drops of the Liquid Laudanum o often mentioned in this Treatie, in two or three Spoonfuls of Cinnamon-water hordeated or the like, which mut be repeated every night at bedtime, and in the Morning too, if the Flux continue violent, and to keep up the trength four or five Spoonfuls of the following Julep may be taken often.

Take of the Waters of Black-cherries and Strawberries each four Ounces, of Epidemic water and Compound Scordium-water, and of Cinnamon-water hordeated each one Ounce, of
Pearls prepared one Dram and an half, of Chrytaline Sugar a Sufficient quantity, make a Julep.

The VVomans Drink in this cae mut be the Milk water, or the white Decoction above decribed, and when he is very weak, he may take for her ordinary Drink, a quart of Fountain water boyl'd with half a pint of Sack; and he may eat ometimes Panada, and ometimes Broth made of lean Mutton, and he mut be kept in Bed: Moreover a Gliter made of half a pint of Cows Milk, and an Ounce and an half of Venice-treacle mut be injected daily.

If the VVoman has her Coures after the fourth or fifth Month of her being with Child (for ome VVomen have them till the Fifth Month, without any manner of prejudice to themelves or their Children) you mut endeavour to top them then, and before too if you uppoe they low by reaon of the heat and acrimony of the Blood, or the weaknes of the Veels, and not from an abundance of Blood, which may be known by her having her Coures much when he was not with Child.

To top this Flux, the VVoman mut be kept in bed, and forbear all things that may heat the Blood, epecially anger; he mut ue a trengthening and cooling Diet, feeding on Meat that breeds good blood
and thickens it, as Broths made of Poultry, Necks of Mutton, Knuckles of Veal, wherein may be boyl'd cooling Herbs; he may eat new lay'd Eggs, Gellies, Rice-milk, Barly-broth, and the like, and Iron mut be quenched in her Beer, and he mut forbear Copulation, and the Belly mut be bathed about the region of the VVomb with Tent, wherein Pomegranate-peel, Provence Roes and Cinnamon has been boyl'd.

But if the VVoman be taken with Flooding, the cae is extreamly hazardous, and if it continues violent, he mut be deliver'd without delay, for otherwie death will necearily follow: Yet it is to be noted, that it mut not be done preently as oon as the Flux is perceived, becaue ome mall Floodings have been ometimes uppreed by keeping quiet in bed, by bleeding in the Arm, and the ue of Remedies above mention'd: If therefore the Blood flows, but in a mall quantity, and continues but a little while, he mut not be delivered; but if it flows in o great abundance that he falls into Convulions and Faintings, the Operation mut not be deferred, whether he has pains and throws or not.

And becaue in Floodings, weaknes and faintings ever follow, we mut endeavour to preerve that little trength the VVoman
has left, and to increae it if poible, that o he may be able to bear the Operation; to which purpoe there ought to be given her from time to time good trengthening Broths, Gellies, and a little good VVine, he mut always mell to Vinegar, and have a warm toat dipt in VVine and Cinnamon appli'd to the region of her heart, which do her more good than olid Food, and to prevent the Blood from flooding in great abundance before he can be delivered, a Vein in her Arm may be open'd to turn the coure of it, and Napkins dipt in VVater and Vinegar may be apply'd all along her Reins.

If the Woman be troubled with a bearing down of the Womb, her bet way is to keep in Bed; but if he cannot conveniently do o, he mut wear a broad Swaith to keep up her Belly; but if the bearing down proceeds from humours that relax the Ligaments of the VVomb, he mut be kept to a drying Diet, her Food being rather roated than boyl'd, and mut refrain from Copulation and mut not be trait Laced.

If the lips of the Privities are much welled, by reaon of watery humours falling upon them, you mut carifie with a Lancet all along the Lips, that the humours may ditil out, and you mut foment
the Parts with the following Decoction.

Take of the leaves of Bays, Sage, Roemary, and of the Flowers of Camomile each one handful, boyl them in a Sufficient quantity of Fountain water; to a pint and half of the train'd Liquor, add a quarter of a pint of Brandy, and bath the parts affected often with a Spunge dipt in the hot Liquor.

div.head: CHAP. XX.
Of Micarriage.
div.p: TO prevent Micarriage, all indipoitions of the Body which are wont to occaion it mut be removed, as fulnes of Blood, ill humours, and peculiar Dieaes of the VVomb, as Swellings, Ulcers and the like.
Fulnes of Blood opens the Veins of the VVomb, or Strangles the Infant, and therefore the VVoman mut be Blooded, and o much Blood mut be taken away, as will ufficiently dicharge nature.

If an ill habit of body and ill humours are the caue of Micarriage, the VVoman mut be frequently purged, and a mall
quantity of Blood may be taken away, and betwixt the Purges, uch things mut be ued as correct the indipoition of the Bowels, and the harpnes of the humours, and the humours mut be thickened if they are too thin. And if Flegmatick humours abound, they mut be carried off by Sweats and uch things as force Urin: Iues in the Arms and Thighs are alo very proper to prevent Micarriage, whatever ill humours abound in the body.

The peculiar Dieaes of the VVomb, as over great Moiture, Swellings, Ulcers, and uch like, mut be cured by their proper Remedies: And firt, if Moiture abound, let the Woman be purged with two Scruples of the Pill Coch-major twice a week, and when he does not Purge, let her drink Morning and Evening of the following Decoction.

Take of the roots of Saraparilla four Ounces, of China two Ounces, of white and red Sanders each half an Ounce, of the raping of Harts-horn and Ivory each three Drams, infue them, and boyl them in eight pints of Fountain water till half is conumed; add a quarter of pound of Raiins of the Sun, and if the Woman be of a Flegmatick contitution, intead of China, add two Ounces of Guiacum raped. Let her drink half a pint Morning and Evening.

Take of Franckincene, Myrrh, Matich, Storax, Calamite, Gum of Juniper, Ladanum, each one Ounce, with a ufficient quantity of Turpentine make Troches, and let one or more of them be cat on live Coals, and let the fume be received into the Privities through a Funnel.

If a Swelling be the caue, you mut make application according to the nature of the humour, and the time and other Circumtances of the welling; if it be hot and made by fluxion, which may be known by the pain and uddennes of the welling, as alo by the Tenion and Pulation, and by being accompanied with a Fever, Bleeding mut be ued in the firt place, and the Woman mut be frequently purged with the purging Potion mention'd in the foregoing Chapter, made of Tamarinds, Sena, Manna, and the like, and after Evacuations you mut apply cooling and repelling things to the Reins and the lower part of the Belly, as Oyl of Roes wahed in Vinegar and the like, and the following Decoction may be injected into the Womb.

Take of the leaves of Plantain, Water Lillies, Night-hade, and Endive each one handful, of red Roes two Pugils, boyl them in three pints of Fountain water till a pint is conumed, add to it of Oyl of Myrtles one Ounce, of Vinegar half an Ounce.

But note you mut not ue cooling and repelling things too long, let the Tumour be hardened thereby and turn to a Scirrhus, and therefore oon after the beginning of the Swelling, emollient and reolving things mut be mixt with Repellents, Mallows, Marhmallows, Mugwort, Fenugreek, Camomile and Melilote; and if the pain be violent, you mut inject into the Womb Goat or Sheeps milk, with Opium and Saffron each three or four Grains, to which may be added a little Roe Water.
But if the welling cannot be reolved and tends to Suppuration, it mut be furthered by the application of the following Pultis.

Take of the roots of Marhmallows, of the Flowers of Camomile and Melilote, of the Seeds of Flax and Fenugreek each one Ounce, of fat Figs number eight, boyl them to the conitence of a Pultis, then add the yolks of four Eggs, of Saffron half a Scruple, of Oyl of Lillies and freh butter each one Ounce, make a Cataplam.

If the Swelling be made by congetion, it is low and without pain, and generally cold, and the matter of it is either thin and erous, or thick and flegmatick and apt to grow hard. In this cae Steel Medicines ued as directed in the Chapter of
Hyteric Dieaes do good, but purging mut go before: Iues in the Legs are alo proper, and emollient and reolving Medicines mut be apply'd outwardly in the following manner.

Take of the Roots of Marhmallows and Lillies each two Ounces, of the leaves of Mallows, Violets, Marhmallows, and Bearsbreech each one handful, of the Seeds of Flax and Fenugreek each one Ounce, of the leaves of Mugwort and Calamint half a handful, of the Flowers of Camomile and Melilote each one Pugil, boyl them in three pints of Fountain water till a third be conumed, and foment the region of the Pubes and Groin with a Spunge dipt in it and preed out: Of the ame Decoction the doe of the Simples being increaed, a bath may be made, which is very effectual in this cae, and more powerful than the Fomentation Gliters alo and Injections may be made of the ame Decoction, and frequently ued, whereunto may be added the Oyls of Lillies, Camomile, and weet Almonds.
But thee Medicines mut be ued with great caution, let the welling hou'd degenerate into a Cancer, and indeed 'tis to no purpoe to ue Medicines when the Swelling is without pain and of a tony nature.

But if an Ulcer be the caue, the cure of it mut be performed by topping the Fluxion of the humours, and by cleaning and conglutinating the Ulcer; and firt if the Body abound with Blood, or if the Ulcer be accompanied with an Inflammation, a Vein mut be opened in the Arm, and Bleeding mut be repeated as often as there is danger of a new Fluxion, epecially at the times of the Coures, to leen them, for they are wont to increae the matter of the Ulcer, and to promote the Flux of other humours to the Womb. Purging is alo very neceary to cleane the Body from ill humours, but it ought to conit of gentle Catharticks, as of Sena, Rhubarb, Tamarinds, Myrobolans and the like, or the Purging Potion of Tamarinds may be ued but if the Woman Vomits eaily he may take the following Vomit or the like.

Take of Vinum benedictum ix Drams, of the Water of Carduus Benedictus one Ounce, of Oxymel of quills half an Ounce, mingle them, make a Vomit, let it be taken about four in the afternoon, and he mut drink a large draught of Poet Drink after every time he Vomits.
The days the Sick does not Purge, a Vulnerary Decoction mut be ued a long while in the following manner.

Take of the leaves of Agrimony, Knot-gras, Burnet, and Plantine, each one handful, of the roots of China three Drams, of Coriander one Dram, of Raiins half an Ounce, of red Sanders one Scruple, boyl them in Chicken broth, train it, let the Sick drink it Morning and Evening.

If there be a Fever, and if a great quantity of matter be evacuated, Whey is very proper, half a pint or more being taken in a Morning with a little Honey of Roes, and if there is an Hectick Fever and the Body begins to wat, Aes milk mut be taken with Sugar of Roes for a whole Month.

Turpentine wahed in ome proper water for the Womb, as in Mugwort or Feverfew water, or in ome water proper for the Ulcer, as Plantain or Roe water, and taken with Sugar of Roes cleanes and heals the Ulcer.

To cleane dry and heal the Ulcer various injections are propoed, but they mut not be ued till the Inflammation is taken off, and till the pain is quieted, and therefore upon account of the Inflammation an Emulion of the cold Seeds, or the Whey of Goats Milk, or Milk it elf may be injected firt, and if neceity requires, a Decoction of Poppy heads and tops of Mallows may be injected. Some Practitioners
ay, the Sick may be much relieved by injecting frequently warm water, and when the heat and pain is quieted, we may ue uch things as cleane, beginning with the gentle, and proceeding gradually to the tronger. The gentle are Whey with Sugar, a Decoction of Barly with Sugar, or Honey of Roes, but Simple Hydromel cleanes mot. But if the Ulcer be very ordid, the following Decoction may be ued.

Take of the roots of Gentian, Rhaponticum, Zedoary, and round Birthwort each one Ounce, of White-wine three pints, boyl them to the conumption of a third part; in the train'd Liquor diolve half a pound of Sugar, and keep it for ue; a little nguentum Aegyptiacum may be added to it if there be occaion to cleane more.
If the Ulcer be deep, the fume mention'd above may be ued; when the Ulcer is very obtinate, Cinnabar mut be added, which is of excellent ue.

If thee Dieaes happen when a Woman is with Child, the difficulty is greater, becaue bigbellied Women cannot o eaily bear all kind of remedies, yet let being detitute of all help they hou'd remain in extream danger of Micarriage and Death, ome kind of Remedies are to be ued; therefore if he be too full of
Blood, he mut have a Vein opened, tho he be with Child, epecially in the firt Month, and o twice or thrice if need be, but much Blood mut not be taken away at a time. And when there is abundanee of ill humours, gentle purging mut be ued and repeated, epecially in the middle Months, and in the mean while thoe atringent and trengthening Medicines mut be ued all the time the Woman is with Child, that are proper to hinder Micarriage.

Take of Kermes Berries and Tormentil roots each three Ounces, of Matich one Dram and an half, make a Powder, whereof give now and then half a Dram, or as much as will lie on the point of a knife, or let her take every Morning ome grains of Matich: Or

Take of conerve of Roes two Ounces, of Citron Peel Candied ix Drams, of Myrobolans candied, of the Pulp of Dates each half an Ounce, of Coral prepared, Pearl prepared, and havings of Harts-horn each one Dram, with Syrup of Quinces make an Electuary, of which let the Woman take often the quantity of a Nutmeg.
The following Lozenges are very good for they trengthen, and by little and little free the Body from Excrements, tho they do not enibly purge ometimes.

Take of Mace, of the three Sorts of Sanders, Rubarb, Sena, Coral, Pearl, each one Scruple, of Sugar diolved in Roe-water four Ounces, make all into Lozenges weighing three Drams apeece; let her take one twice a Week by it elf, or diolved in a little Broth.
The following Plater may be apply'd to the Reins.
Take of the Plater ad Herniam and de Minio each equal parts, pread it on Leather, and apply it to the mall of the Back.
But Platers mut not be worn long together, let they hould caue an heat of Urin, and the Stone in the Kidnies.
In the ue of thee things, the Woman mut keep her elf as quiet as poibly he can, both in Body and Mind, and mut abtain from Copulation.

But if notwithtanding the Medicines aforeaid, by reaon of the Vehemence of the caue, whether it be outward or inward, the Sick be ready to micarry, we mut do the bet we can with the following remedies, and in the firt place o oon as Pains and Throws hall be perceived in the lower part of the Belly, and in the Loins, we mut endeavour to allay them both by Medicines taken inwardly and outwardly apply'd according to the variety of the Caues, and if Crudities and
Wind are the caue, as they are mot uually when the caue is within, a Powder mut be given made of Aromaticum Roatum and Coriander Seeds, and we may give of the Imperial Water if Flegm and Wind abound.

At the ame time let Carminative Medicines be apply'd below the Navel of the Patient, uch are Bags of Anie Seeds, Fennel Seeds, Fenugreek Seeds, Flowers of Camomile, Elder, Roemary and Stechas, mixt together, or a Roe Cake fryed in a Pan with rich Canary, and prinkled with Powder of Nutmegs and Coriander Seeds, or the Gaul of a Wether new kill'd or his Lungs lay'd on warm. If by thee means the pains ceae not, let a Gliter be injected made of Wine and Oyl, wherein two Drams of Philonium Romanum may be diolved, or Narcoticks may be given inwardly in a mall quantity to allay the Violence of the humours and wind, as we are wont to do in pains of the Colick. But if Blood begins to come away, Frictions and painful Ligatures of the upper parts mut be ued to turn the coure of the Blood, and if the Woman be full of Blood, it will not be amis to take ome Blood from her, epecially before it begins to low, but it mut be taken away at everal times a little at once.

And if the Flux of Blood continues we mut proceed to an atringent and thickening Diet and Medicines, as mentioned above. Atringent Fomentations may be alo ued outwardly made of Pomgranate-peels, Cypres Nuts, Acorn Cups, Balautines, and the like, boyl'd in Smiths water and Red wine: Or a little bag full of Red Roes and Balautines may be boyl'd in Red Wine and apply'd hot to the Womans Belly: And the Plaiter above mentioned may be ued. It is believed, that the two following Medicines will certainly retain the Child in the Womb if they be ued before it is torn from the Veels of the Womb.

Take of leaves of Gold, Number twelve, of Spodium one Dram, the Cocks treading of three Eggs not addle, mix all very well till the Gold be broken into mall peeces, afterwards diolve them in a draught of White Wine, and give it three Mornings following.
At the ame time let the following Cataplam be applied.

Take of Male Frankincene powdred two Ounces, the whites of five Eggs, let them be tirred together over hot Coals, add Turpentine to make them tick, then pread them upon Tow, and lay them upon her Navel as hot as he can poibly endure them twice a
day Morning and Evening on the three days afore-aid.

div.head: CHAP. XXI.
The Signs that precede a Natural and nnatural Delivery.
div.p: THE igns preceding a natural Labour a few days before, are inking down of the Belly, which hinders a Woman at that time in walking as eaie as he ued to do, and thence flows from the Womb limy humours, appointed by nature to moiten and moothen the paage, that its inward Orifice may the more eaily be dilated, when it is neceary, which beginning to open a little at that time uffers that lime to flow away.

The igns accompanying preent Labour are, great pains about the Region of the Reins and Loins, which coming and redoubling by intervals, anwer in the bottom of the Belly with reiterated Throws, the Face is red and inflamed, becaue the Blood is much heated by the continual endeavours of the Woman to bring forth
the Child, as alo becaue that during thee trong Throws, her repiration is ever intercepted, for which reaon much Blood hath recoure to the Face, her Privy Parts are welled, becaue the Infants head often thruts, and caues the Neighbouring Parts to ditend outwards; upon which account they appear well'd in this manner; he is often ubject to vomiting, which makes many believe, who know not the caue of it, that the Women are for this reaon in danger: But it is generally the ign of a peedy delivery, becaue the good pains are then excited and redoubled every moment, until the buines is finihed.

When the Birth is very near, Women are troubled with an univeral trembling, and chiefly of the Legs and Thighs, with the heat of the whole Body and Humours, which then flow from the Womb, and they are often dicoloured with Blood, which with the igns above mentioned is an infallible ign of the nearnes of the Birth. This the Women uually call hows, and if one then puts up their Finger into the Neck of the Womb, they will find the inner Orifice dilated, at the opening whereof, the Membranes of the Infant containing the Waters preent themelves, and are trongly forc'd downwards with
every pain the Woman has, at which time one may perceive them to reit the Finger, more or les as the pains are tronger or weaker. Thee Membranes with the Waters in them, when gathered (that is, when they are advanced before the head of the Child, which makes the Midwives call it the gathering of the Waters) preenting themelves at this inward Orifice, do then reemble very well to the touch of the Finger, abortive Eggs which have yet no hell, but are only covered with a imple Membrane. After this the pains redoubling continually, the Membranes are broken by the trong impule of the Waters, which incontinently flow away, and then the head of the Child is eaily felt naked, and preented at the opening of the inward Orifice of the Womb: now all thee or the greatet part of them meeting together, at what time oever of a VVomans going with Child it be, whether at the full time or no, one may be aured he will oon be delivered: But great care mut be taken not to haten her Labour before the neceity of it be known by thee igns; for that would but torment the VVoman and Child in vain, and put them both in danger of their lives:

Labour contrary to nature is when the Child comes in an ill Figure and Situation, as when it preents any otherwie than the Head firt; as alo when the Waters flow away a long time before it is born; alo when the After-burthen comes firt. The Labour is alo grievous when accompanied with a Fever, or any other coniderable Dieae which may detroy the Child in the Womb; alo when pains are mall and come low with long intervals and little profit, upon which account the Woman is extreamly tired; but the wrong poture of the Infant is mot commonly the caue of difficult Labour. As oon as it is known that the Woman is certainly in labour by the igns above mentioned, then mut all things neceary to comfort the Woman in her Labour be got ready, and the better to help her, care mut be taken that he be not trait laced; a pretty trong Gliter may be given her, or more than one, if there be occaion, which mut be done at the beginning, before the Child be too forwards, for afterwards it is very difficult for her to receive them in the mean while all things neceary for her Labour hould be put in order, as well for the Woman as the Child; her Midwifes Stool, or rather a Pallet-bed girted
placed cloe by the Fire, if the Seaon require it; the Pallet ought to be o placed, as to be turned round about when there is occaion, the better to help the Woman. If the Woman be full of Blood, it may be convenient to Bleed her a little, for by this means her Breats being diingaged, and her Repiration free, he will have more trength to bear down her pains, which may be done without danger, becaue the Child being about that time ready to be born, hath no more need of the Mothers Blood for its nourihment, which has been often practied with good ucces. Beides, this Evacuation often hinders her having a Fever after delivery, and to preerve her trength, it will be convenient to give her ome good Gelly Broaths, new laid Eggs, or ome Spoonfuls of burnt Wine from time to time, or a Toat dipt in Wine, avoiding olid Food. Above all he mut be perwaded to hold out her pains, bearing them down as much as he can, at the intant when they take her. The Midwife mut from time to time touch the inward Orifice with her Finger, to know whether the Waters are ready to break, and whether the Birth will follow oon after; he mut alo anoint all the bearing place with emollient
Oyls, Hogs greae or freh Butter, if he perceive it can hardly be dilated; and all the while he mut be near her Woman to oberve her getures diligently, her complaints and pains; for o he may gues pretty well how the Labour advances, without being obliged to touch her Body o often. The Woman may by intervals ret her elf on the Bed to refreh her elf, but not too long, epecially if he be a little hort thick Woman, for they have always wort Labours, if they lie much on their Beds in their Travail, epecially of their firt Children, than when they are prevailed with to walk about the Chamber; (but they mut be upported under the Arms, if it be neceary) for by this means the weight of the Child caues the inward Orifice to dilate ooner than in Bed. When the Waters of the Child are ready and gather'd, the Midwife ought to let them break of themelves, for the breaking of them before the Infant be wholly in the paage prolongs the Labour; for by the too haty breaking of thee Waters, which ought to help the Child to lide forth with greater eae, he remains dry, which hinders afterwards the Pains and Throws, o that they cannot be o effectual in excluding
the Child, as otherwie they would have been: It is therefore better to let them break of themelves, and then the Midwife may eaily find the Child bare by the part which firt preents, and o judge certainly whether it comes right, that is with the Head, which he will find hard, big, round, and equal; but if it be any other part, he will perceive omething unequal and rugged, and hard or oft, more or les according to the parts; immediately let her dipatch to deliver her Woman, if he be not already, and ait the Birth, which ordinarily happens oon after, if natural, in the following manner.

After the Waters be broke of themelves, as above-aid, let the Woman be preently placed on the Pallate provided for her to this purpoe, near the Fire, or he may, if he like it better, be delivered in her ordinary Bed; for all Women are not accutomed to be delivered in the ame poture, ome will be delivered on their Knees, others tanding, leaning with their elbows on a Pillow, upon a Table, or the ide of a Bed, and others lying upon a Quilt in the midt of the Chamber. But the bet and uret way of Delivery is in Bed, to avoid the inconvenience
and trouble of being carried thither afterwards, in which cae it ought to be Furnihed rather with a Quilt than a Feather-bed, having upon it Linnen and Cloaths in many folds, with other necearies to be changed upon occaion, that the Woman may not be incommoded afterwards with the Blood, Waters, and other filth, which is voided in Labour. The Bed mut be o made, that the Woman being ready to be delivered, hould lie on her back upon it, with her Head and Breat a little raied, o as that he be neither lying nor etting; for in this manner he breaths bet, and will have more trength to help her pains, than if he unk down into her Bed; being in this poture he mut pread her Thighs abroad, folding her Legs a little towards her Buttocks, omewhat raied by a mall Pillow underneath, and her Feet mut be taid againt ome firm thing; moreover let her hold ome By-tanders with her Hands, that he may the better tay her elf during her pains. Being thus placed near the ide of her Bed, with her Midwife by to help upon occaion, he mut take courage, and further her pains the bet he can, bearing them down, when they take her, which he may
do by holding her Breath, and forcing her elf all he can, jut as when he goes to tool. In the mean while the Midwife mut comfort her, and peruade her to endure her Labour bravely, and put her in hopes of a peedy delivery. The Midwife, with her Hand anointed with Oyl or freh Butter, may gently dilate the inward Orifice of the Womb, putting her Fingers ends into its entry, and tretching them one from another, and thruting by little and little the ides of the Orifice towards the hinder part of the Childs Head, anointing thee parts alo with freh Butter. When the Infants Head begins to advance to the inward Orifice, it is commonly aid it is crown'd, and when it is come o far, that the extremity begins to appear manifetly without the privy Parts, it is then aid that the Child is in the paage, and the Woman in Travail imagins, tho it is no uch thing, that her Midwife hurts her with her Fingers, finding her elf as it were cratched, and pricked with Pins in thoe parts, by reaon of the violent ditenion, which the bignes of the Childs Head caues there.

When things are in this poture, the Midwife mut eat her elf conveniently
to receive the Child, which will oon come, and with her Fingers ends, her Nails being cloe paired, endeavour to thrut, as above-aid, this crowning of the Womb, back off over the Head of the Child; and as oon as it is advanced as far as the Ears, or thereabouts, he may take hold of the two Sides with her two Hands, that when a good pain comes, he may quickly draw forth the Child, taking care that the Navel-tring be not then intangled about the Neck, or any other part, let thereby the After-burthen be pulled with violence, and poibly the Womb alo, whereunto it is fatened, and o caue Flooding, or ele break the tring, whereby the Woman may come to be more difficultly delivered. It mut alo be oberved, that the Head be not drawn forth traight, but haking it a little from one ide to the other, that the Shoulders may ooner and eaier take place, immediately after it is pat, which mut be done without loing any time, let the Head being pat, the Child be topt there by the largenes of the Shoulders, and be in danger of being uffocated in the paage: But as oon as the head is born, if there be need, the Midwife may lide in her Finger under the Arm-pits, and
the ret of the Body will follow without any difficulty. As oon as the Midwife has in this manner drawn forth the Child, he mut put it on one ide, let the Blood and Waters, which follow immediately after hould choak it; afterwards let her be very careful to examin that there be no more Children in the Womb, which he may know, if putting her hand up the entry, he finds there another Water gathering. If it be o, he mut have a care not to go about to fetch the After-burthen, till the Woman be delivered of all her Children; wherefore the firt tring mut be cut, being firt tied with a Thred three or four double, and the other end mut be fatened with a tring to the Womans Thigh.

As oon as the Child is born, before the Navel-tring is tied or cut, the Woman mut be freed of the After-burthen. To perform this, the Midwife having taken the tring mut wind it once or twice about one or two of her Fingers of her left hand joined together, the better to hold it, wherewith he may then draw it moderately, and with the right Hand, he may only take a ingle hold of it above the left near the Privities, drawing likewie with that very gently, reting
the Fore-finger of the ame Hand extended, and tretched forth along the tring towards the entry of the Sheath, always oberving to draw it from the ide, where the burthen cleaves leat. Above all things care mut be taken, that it be not drawn forth with too much violence, let by breaking the tring, you are obliged to put the whole Hand into the Womb to deliver the Woman, or the Womb be drawn down forth with it; alo by drawing it out with too much violence, a great flooding may thereby happen. To facilitate the expulion, the Woman may blow trongly into her Hands hut, or he may put her Finger into her Throat, as if he would provoke Vomiting, or he may trive as if he were going to tool, bearing always down, and holding her breath. When all thee circumtances have been oberved, if you meet with difficulty, you may, if need be, after that you know on which ide the After-birth is ituated, command an experienced Nure-keeper to pres the Belly lightly with the flat of her Hand, directing it gently downwards by way of Friction; above all being careful not to do it too violently; but if all this be in vain, then mut the Hand be directed
into the VVomb to looen and eparate it.

As oon as the VVoman is delivered of both Child and Burthen, it mut then be conidered whether there be all, and care had, that not the leat part of it remain behind, not o much as the skirts or clods of Blood, which ought all to be brought away with the firt; for otherwie, being retained, they caue great pains. When the Woman has two Children, you mut not fetch the Burthen, as was aid before, till both the Children are born, and then it may be done without danger, haking and drawing it always gently ometimes by one tring, ometimes by the other, and ometimes by both together, and o by turns till all is come. When the Infant comes right and naturally, the Woman is brought to Bed, and delivered with little help, for which the meanet Midwifes are capable, and oft-times for want of them, a imple Nurekeeper may upply the place. But when it is a wrong Labour there is a great Mytery belongs to it; for then the skill and prudence of a Surgeon is for the mot part requiite.

Immediately after the Woman is delivered, and the Burthen come away, care
mut be taken that the looening of it be not followed with a Flooding; if it be not, a oft cloure mut be immediately applied to the Womb, five or ix times double, to prevent the cold Air entring in and topping the Veels, whereby the Womb hould cleane by degrees when the VVomb is o cloed: If the VVoman was not delivered upon her ordinary Bed, let her preently be carried into it by ome trong Body or more if there be need, rather than to let her walk thither; which Bed mut be ready warmed and prepared, as is requiite for the cleanings. But if he were delivered on it, which is bet and afet to prevent the danger and trouble of carrying her to it, then all the oul Linnen and other things put there for receiving the Bloud, VVaters, and other filth, which comes away in Labour, mut be removed, and he mut be placed conveniently in it for her eae and ret, which he much wants to recover her of the Pains and Labour he endured in Travail, he mut be placed with her Head and Body a little raied for to breath the freer, and to cleane the better, epecially of that Blood which then comes away, that o it may not clod, which being retained caues very great pains. All this
will happen if they have not liberty to come freely by this convenient Situation, in which he mut put down her Legs and Thighs cloe together having a mall Pillow for her greater eae, if he deire it under her Hams, upon which they may ret a little. Being o put to Bed, let her lie neither on one ide nor the other, but jut on the middle of her Back, that o the VVomb may repoes its natural and proper place.

It is an ordinary cutom to give the VVoman, as oon as he is delivered, two Ounces of Oyl of Sweet Almonds, and as much Syrup of Maiden-hair, which is good to weeten and temper the inide of the Throat, which was heated, and hoare by her continual cryes, and holding her breath, to bear down her Throws during her Labour; it is alo good to prevent the Grips; but this Potion goes o much againt the Stomachs of ome VVomen, that being forced to take it with an averion, it may do them more hurt than good; therefore let none have it, but thoe that deire it and have no averion for it: But good Broath taken after he is a little etled may be more beneficial.

Having thus accommodated her, and provided for her Belly, Breats, and lower
parts, leave her to ret and leep if he can, making no noie, the Bed-Curtains being cloe drawn, and the Doors and VVindows of her Chamber hut, that o eeing no light, he may the ooner fall aleep.

As oon as the Bed is cleaned from the foul Linnen and other impurities of the Labour, and the Woman therein placed, let there be outwardly applied all over the bottom of her Belly and Privities, the following anodyne Pultis made of two Ounces of weet Almonds with two or three new laid Eggs yolks and whites, tirring them together in an earthen Pipkin over hot Embers till it comes to the conitence of a Pultis, which being pread upon Cloath, mut be applyed to thoe parts indifferently warm, having firt taken away the Cloures which were put to her, preently after her Delivery, and likewie uch clods of Blood as were there left. This is a very fit Remedy to appeae the Pains which Women commonly uffer in thoe Parts, by reaon of the violence then endured by the Infants Birth; it mut lie on five or ix hours, and then be renewed a econd time, if there be occaion. Afterwards make a Decoction of Barly, Lineed, and Chervil, or with Marh-mallows
and Violet Leaves, adding to a Pint of it an Ounce of Honey of Roes, wherewith, being luke-warm, Foment three or four times a-day, for the firt five or ix days of Child-bed, the bearing place, cleaning it very well from the Clods of Blood and other Excrements which are there emptied. Some Perons only ue for this purpoe luke-warm Milk, and many Women only Barly-water. Great care mut be taken at the beginning that no topping thing be given to hinder the cleanings, but when ten or twelve Days are pat, and he has cleaned ufficiently, Remedies may then be ued to fortifie the Parts, for which purpoe a Decoction is very proper made of Province Roes, Leaves and Roots of Plantain and Smiths water, and when he has ufficiently and fully done Cleaning, which is uually after the eighteenth or twentieth Day, there may be made for thoe that deire it, a very trong atringent Lotion to fortifie and ettle thoe parts which have been much relaxed, as well by the great extenion they received, as by the Humours, wherewith they have been o long time oak'd; this Remedy may be compoed with an Ounce and an half of Pomgranat Peel, an Ounce of Cypres Nuts, half an
Ounce of Accorns, an Ounce of eal'd Earth, an Handful of Provence Roes, and two Drachms of Roch-allom, all which being infued in a Quart and half a Pint of trong Red-wine, or that it may not be too harp, ome Smiths water may be mixed with the Wine, afterwards boil it to a Quart, then train it, queezing it trongly; and with this Decoction Foment the inferior parts Night and Morning to trengthen and confirm them. But they will never be reduced to the ame tate they were in, before the Woman had Children. A mall Plaiter of Galbanum, with a little Civit in the middle may be alo applyed to the Womans Navel. As for Swaiths they need not be ued the firt Day, or at leat very looly, epecially if there has been hard Labour, becaue the leat compreion of the Womans Belly, which is then very ore, as the Womb alo is, proves a great inconvenience to her; wherefore let her not be waithed until the econd Day, and that very gently at the beginning. The ue of Swaiths and of a good large quare Bolter over the whole Belly may be continued the firt even or eight Days to keep it a little teady; but they mut be taken off and removed often to anoint the Womans Belly
all over, if it be ore, and if he has After-Pains, with Oils of weet Almonds and St. Johns-wort mixed together, which may be done every Day. But after that time they may be degrees begin to waith her traiter, to contract and gather together the parts which are greatly extended, during her going with Child, which may be then afely done, becaue the Womb by thee former cleanings is o diminihed, that it cannot be too much compreed by the Swaiths.

Proper Remedies may be applied to the Breats to drive back the Milk, if the Woman will not be a Nure; but if he intends to be a Nure, it will be ufficient to keep her Breats very cloe, and well covered with gentle and oft Cloaths to keep them warm, and to prevent the curdling of the Milk; and if there be danger of too much Milk being carried thither, anoint the Breats with Oyl of Roes and a little Vinegar beat together, and put upon them ome fine Linnen dipt in it, oberving that if the Woman do Suckle the Child, he give not the Breat the ame day he is brought to Bed, becaue then all her Humours are extreamly moved with the pains and agitation of the Labour; therefore let her defer it at leat till the next
day; and it would be yet better to tay four or five days or longer, to the end the fury of the Milk, and the abundance of the Humours, which flow to the Breat at the beginning, may be pent, in which time another Woman may give it Suck.

Although a Woman be naturally Delivered, yet notwithtanding he mut oberve a good Diet, to prevent many ill accidents which may happen to her during her Child-bed, at the beginning whereof he mut be directed in her Meat and Drink almot in the ame manner as if he had a Fever, that o it may be prevented, in as much as he is then very ubject to it; for this reaon he mut be regular in her Diet, epecially the three or four firt Days, in which time he mut be nourihed only with good Broaths, new-laid Eggs, and Gellies, without uing at the beginning more olid Meats: but when the great abundance of her Milk is a little pat, he may with more afety eat a little Broath at Dinner, or a mall piece of boyl'd Chicken, or Mutton; afterwards, if no accident happens, he may be degrees be nourihed more plentifully, provided that it be a third part les than he was accutomed to take in her perfect health, and that her Food be of good and eaie Digetion; as
for her Drink, let it be a Ptian made of Liquorih, Figs, and Annieeds, boyled in Water: She may alo, if he be not Feverih, drink a little white Wine well mixed with Water, but not till after the fifth or ixth Day. But it is to be noted that laborious Women of a trong Contitution require a more plentiful feeding; yet notwithtanding, if they do not change the quality, they mut at leat retrench the quantity of their ordinary Food.

The Child-bed Woman mut likewie keep her elf very quiet in her Bed lying on her Back, with her Head raied, and not turning often from ide to ide; that o the Womb may be the better ettled in its firt Situation: She mut free her elf at that time from all care of Buines, let her talk as little as may be, and that with a low Voice, and let no ill News be brought to her, which may affect her, becaue all thee things do caue o great a commotion of the Humours, that Nature not being able to overcome them, cannot make the neceary Evacuation of them, which has been the Death of many. The Woman ought always to keep her Body open with Gliters, taking one once in two Days, which not only evacuate the gros Excrements, but alo by drawing downwards
caue her to Cleane the better.
