When he has oberved this Rule a Fortnight or three Weeks, which is very near the time of having Cleaned ufficiently, that thoe Parts may be throughly cleaned before he goes abroad, and begin upon a new Score, let her take a gentle Purge of Senna, Caia, and Syrup of Cichory, with Rubarb, which is good to Purge the Stomach and Bowels of thoe ill Humours Nature could not evacuate by the Womb: This Purge may be repeated upon occaion.

Women in their firt Labours have many times bruies and rents of the outward parts of the Womb, and they mut never be neglected, let they degenerate into malignant Ulcers; for the heat and moiture of thee Parts, beides the filth which continually flows thence, eaily contributes to it, if convenient Remedies be not timely applied; wherefore as oon as the Woman is laid, if there be only imple contuions and excoriations, apply a Pultis made of yolks and whites of new-laid Eggs and Oil of Roes eethed a little over warm Embers, continually tirring till it be mixed, and then pread it upon a fine Cloath, and apply it very warm for five or ix Hours, when being taken away, lay ome fine Rags dipt in Oil of St. Johns-wort on each ide
the bearing place, and renew them twice or thrice a Day. Foment thee parts with Barly-water and Honey of Roes to cleane them from the Excrements which pas, and when the VVoman makes water, let them be defended with fine Rags to hinder the Urine from cauing pain and marting. Sometimes the bruies are o great, that the Bearing-place is inflamed, and a very coniderable abces follows, in which Cae it mut be opened jut below the Swelling in the mot convenient place; and after the Matter is evacuated, a deterive Decoction mut be injected into the Cavity, made of Barly-water and Oyl of Roes, to which Spirit of Wine may be added, if there be any danger of Corruption, and afterwards the Ulcer mut be Dreed according to Art.

Sometimes it happens that the Perineum is o rent, that the Privities and the Fundament is all in one; in this cae, having cleaned the Womb from uch Excrements as may be there with Red-wine, let the Rent be trongly titched together with three or four tiches, or more, according to the length of the eparation, taking at each tich good hold of the Fleh, that o it may not break out, and then dres it with Linimentum Arcaei, or the like; claping
a Plaiter on, and ome Linnen above to prevent, as much as may be, the falling of the Urine, and other Excrements upon it, becaue the acrimony of them would make it mart, and caue Pain; and that thee parts may cloe together with more eae, let the Woman keep her Thighs cloe together, without the leat preading until the Cure be perfected: but if afterwards he happens to be with Child, he will be obliged to prevent the like michief to anoint thoe parts with Emollient Oyls, and Oyntments, and when he is in Labour, he mut forbear helping her. Throws too trongly at once, but leave Nature to perform it by degrees, together with the help of a Midwife well Intructed in her Art; for uually when thee parts have been once rent, it is very difficult to prevent the like in the following Travail, becaue the Scar there made does traighten the parts yet more; wherefore it were to be wihed for greater ecurity againt the like accidents, that the Woman hould have no more Children.

div.head: CHAP. XXII.
Of hard Labour.
div.p:
MAny Caues may be aigned that occaion hard Labour, as the natural weaknes of the Mothers Body, or her Age, he being too Young or too Old; or it may be occaioned by Dieaes that he had with her big Belly, leannes or too much drynes of the Body, or Fat compreing the paages of the Womb, the ill conformation of the Bones encompaing the Womb, as in thoe that are Lame, may alo occaion it; Wind welling the Bowels, a Stone or Preternatural Tumour in the Bladder that prees the Womb may be the occaion; o may the ill contitution of the Lungs, or of the parts erving repiration, for the holding of the Breath conduceth much to the Excluion of the Child. Various Dieaes of the VVomb may alo render the Delivery difficult, as wellings, Ulcers, Obtructions, and the like. The hard Labour is occaioned by the Child, when by reaon it is Dead, or Putrified, or any way Dieaed it cannot confer any thing to its own excluion; alo
when the Body or Head is too large, or when there are more than one; o Twins mot commonly caue hard Labour, or the ill ituation of the Child is the caue, or when the Hands or the Feet offer firt, or when one Hand or one Foot comes out firt, or when it is doubled, or when the Membranes break too oon, o that the VVater flows out and leaves the Orifice of the VVomb dry at the time of Excluion, or when the Membranes are too thick, o that they cannot be eaily broken by the Child.

Cold and dry Air and a North-wind are very injurious to VVomen in Labour, becaue they bind the Body and drive the Blood and Spirits to the inner parts, and they are very injurious to the Child coming from o warm a place. And hot Weather diipates the Spirits, and weakens the Child. Crude Nourihment and uch as is difficultly concocted and binds taken in a great quantity before Labours renders it difficult, the Stomach being weakned, and the common paages contracted, which ought to be open in this Cae. Drowines hinders the action of the Mother. The uneaonable motion of the VVoman much retards the Delivery, as when he refues upon occaion to tand, walk, lie, or it, or lings her elf about
unadviedly o that the Child cannot be Born the right way, being turned prepoterouly by the retlenes of the Mother. Urine in the Bladder, or Excrements in the right Gut, or the Piles when they are much well'd hinder Natures endeavours, by narrowing the Neck of the VVomb. Fear, Sorrow, Anger make the Labour difficult. A Blow, a Fall, or a Wound, may alo much obtruct the Labour. Want of good aitance to lift the Woman up jut at the time of Delivery, and an Ignorant Midwife who orders the Woman to endeavour an expulion, and to top her breath when the ligaments of the Fetus tick firmly to the Womb, o that the Woman is tired before the time of her Delivery.

In hard Labour Women commonly give a Spoonful or two of Cinamon-water, or Cinnamon powder'd with a little Saffron, or half a Dram of Confection of Alkermes in Broth, or half a Scruple of Saffron alone in ome Broth, or every hour a lit-VVine.
If thee things are not ufficient the following may be ued which have been frequently found very effectual.

Take of Dittany of Creet, and both the Birthworts, and of Troaches of Mirrh each half a Scruple, of Saffron and Cinnamon each Twelve Grains, of confection of Alkermes half a Dram, of Cinnamon-water half an Ounce, of Orange-flower-water, and of Mugwort-water each one Ounce, make a Potion. Oyl of Amber and of Cinnamon, and extract of Saffron are very effectual in a mall quantity, namely five Grains of extract of Saffron, four or five drops of Oyl of Cinnamon, twelve or fifteen drops of Oyl of Amber in Wine, Broth or ome other Liquor; and let the Woman take Sneeing Powder for it hatens delivery.

The Midwife mut frequently anoint the Womb with the Oyls of Lilies or of Sweet Almonds, and the Belly mut be fomented with a Decoction of the Roots of Marhmallows and Lilies, of the Leaves of Mallows, Violets, Mugwort, of the Seeds of Fenugreek and Flax, of the Flowers of Camomile and Melilote. Sharp Gliters mut be alo injected to timulate the Womb, and to carry off the Excrements. Anoint the Navel with Oyl of Amber.

If the Child begins to come forth prepoterouly, as with one Arm or Foot, the Midwife mut thrut them back, and turn the Child right, which may be done by placing the Woman on her Back upon a Bed with her Head low and Feet high.

div.head: CHAP. XXIII.
Of a dead Child.
div.p: WHEN the Child is dead the motion of it ceaes, which either the Woman felt before in the Womb, or the Midwife with her Hand; a ene of weight with pain afflicts the Belly, and the Child falls like a Stone from ide to ide; the Belly feels cold, the Eyes are Hollow, the Face and Lips pale, the extream parts cold and livid, the Breats flaccid, and at length the Child putrifying, tinking matter Flows from the Womb, and an ill and trong mell exhales from the Womans Body, and her Breath tinks. If the Secundine be excluded firt, it is a certain ign that the Child is dead.
The whole cure conits in the excluion or extraction of the Child.

Take of the Leaves of Savine dryed, of the roots of round Birthwort, of the Troches of Myrrh and of Cator each one Dram, of Cinnamon half a Dram, of Saffron one Scruple, mingle them make a Powder, whereof let her take one Dram in Savine Water.
Foment the Pubes, Privities, and Perineum, with an Emollient Decoction made of the Leaves of Mallows, and Marhmallows, and the like and let a Peary be put up the Privities.
Take of the Roots of round Birthwort, Orris, Black Hellebore, of Coloquintida and Myrrh each one Dram, of Galbanum and Opopanax each half a Dram, with Ox Gall, make a Peary.
If after having tried Medicines a long while, the Child cannot be ejected, it mut be extracted by a Surgeon, either with Intruments, or with the Hand alone.

div.head: CHAP. XXIV.
Of the Caearian Delivery.
div.p:
THE Caearian Delivery is a dextrous extraction of a Living or Dead Child from the Mothers Womb, which cannot be other ways excluded, and that without endangering the Life of both, or of either, and without poiling the Faculty of conceiving; and by this Art the firt Scipio Africanus of the Romans was cut out of his Mothers Womb, and therefore was called Caear. This Caearian Section is thought to be neceary, when the Mother and the Child are o weak, that they cannot be preerved any other way. The ue of it is twofold, one, that a living Child may be extracted; the other, that the Mother may be preerved alive; and tho' it is very hazardous, yet in a deperate cae it is better to do omething than nothing; epecially when a confederacy is like to be broken by the death of a Wife; or when a Family is like to be extinguihed; or ome Kingdom or Principality is like to be lot. In this manner we find in the Annals of Spain,
the King of Navar was preerved; for his Mother being wounded in the Belly by the Saracens, as he was Hunting, a Noble Man coming to her help, aw the Child put its hand out of the Wound, and drew it forth, and educated it privately; and afterwards, when the Nobility was contending about the Election of a Prince, he brought out the young King, and o the Controverie ended.

The caues which require this operation are, a too great Child, or Twins, or more that endeavour to be born together; or if a flehy Mole join to the Child, the ill poture of it, and if it cannot be reduced to a better, either by its own help, or the help of others; or becaue it is dead, or o much well'd by a Dieae, that the Naturall paage is too narrow: But in this cae, it is bet to take it away peece-meal. The caues on the Mothers part are the narrownes of the paages, either naturally, by reaon he is too young, or too old; or becaue the VVomb is hut, either by a Cicatrix or a Callous. Moreover many tumours in the Womb, or the Mouth of it may be the caue: In thee caes, tho it be very dangerous, yet it is very neceary to ue Section, and the operation may be happily
performed, as may appear by everal Experiments to him that reads Rouel.

But before you enter upon this Operation, you mut conider, whether the Child can be Extracted any other way that is afer and eaier. You mut moreover conider whether there are Signs of Death, and if o, you mut not enter upon the Operation, let the Womans Death be laid upon the Section, and your rahnes: But when you have througly weighed all things, if the Woman be of a trong Nature, tho by reaon of the Labour he is weak, you may venture upon the Operation.

But it is to be noted, that Mauriceau much diapproves this cruel Operation, and ays it ought not to be performed until the VVoman is dead, for that the VVoman always dies in the operation, or preently after.

div.head: CHAP. XXV.
Of the Secundine retained.
div.p:
IN a natural Birth the Secundine is uually excluded preently after the Child; and when it is not, the Life of the Woman is much indangered. It is retained by the too great thicknes of the Coats, the welling of them, and by an afflux of Humours occaion'd by hard Labour; alo by the trutting of the Mouth of the Womb after the excluion of the Child. The External Caues are, Coldnes of the Air, whereby the Secundine is repelled, and the Orifice of the Womb hut. Certain perfumes, whereby the Womb is allured upwards, violent paions of the Mind, as Fear, and udden Frights, the perverenes of the Woman, who will not abide in uch a poture, or ue uch endeavours as are requiite, the weight of the Child, whereby the Navel is broken, the After-birth remaining within, the unskilfulnes of the Midwife who cuts the Veels of the Navel too oon, or does not hold them in her Left Hand as he ought, for if he let them go, they are drawn
back into the Womb, and are hid there with the Secundine.

It is eaie to know when the Secundine is retained in the VVomb, but ometimes a piece of it is eparated and remains in the Womb, which is not o eaily perceived, yet it may be known, becaue the Womb after Delivery endeavours to eject omething; but tho its endeavours are but mall, a ene of heat and pain is perceived in the Womb, and after a few days a cadaverous mell exhales from the Womb. The retention of the Secundine is very dangerous, and if it continues ome days, an acute Fever, Naueounes, Faintings, difficulty of Breathing, Coldnes of the extream Parts, Convulive Fits, and at length Death follows.

The Secundine retained, is expelled by the ame remedies, which are propoed for a dead Child, to which may be added ome Specificks deliver'd by Authors. Rulandus ays, he has given with ucces thirty drops of Oyl of Juniper. Some order the Woman to bite an Onion three or four times and to wallow the Juice, and preently after to drink a mall draught of Wine. The Juice of green Lovage drank in Rhenih-wine is alo commended. Sneeing is alo good; but the bet way is
to have it drawn out by a skilful Chyrurgeon, before the Inflammation is increaed. If the Secundine cannot be ejected by any means, but ticks firmly to the Womb, and putrifies there, Suppuraratives mut be injected; to this purpoe Bailicon may be diolved in the following Decoction.

Take of the Leaves of Mallows with the roots three handfuls, of the roots of both the Birthworts each ix Drams, of Flax Seeds and Fenugreek Seeds each half an Ounce, of Violets one handful, of the Flowers of Camomile, and the leer Centory each half an handful, make a Decoction in Water mingled with Oyl, if you would have it uppurate much, but to cleane add a little ngentum Aegyptiacum.

div.head: CHAP. XXVI.
Of the Flooding of a Woman new laid.
div.p:
FLooding is a more dangerous accident than any other which may happen to a Woman newly laid, and which dipatches her o oon, if it be in a great quantity, that there is not often time to prevent it; wherefore in this cae convenient Remedies mut be peedily applied to top it; to which purpoe it is fit to conider what caues the Flooding, and if it be a fale Conception, a piece of the burthen or clodded Blood remaining behind, all diligence mut be ued to fetch them away, or to caue a peedy expulion of them. But if when nothing remains behind in the Womb, the Blood notwithtanding continues to flow, you mut Blood in the Arm to make diverion, and let her Body be laid flat, and not raied, that o the Blood may not be ent down to the lower Parts. Let her keep
her elf very quiet, and not turn from ide to ide; the upper part of her Belly mut not be Swathed or Boltered, and her Chamber mut be kept a little cool, and the Coverings of the Bed mut not be many, that o the Flooding may not be promoted by the heat.

But if notwithtanding all this the Blood flows continually, the lat remedies mut be tryed, which is to lay the Woman upon freh Straw, with a ingle Cloath on it, and no Quilt, that o her Reins may not be heated, applying along her Loins Cloaths wet in cold Vinegar and Water, unles it be Winter, and then it mut be a little warmed; and to the end her trength may be preerved, which is extreamly wated, let her take every half Hour a little good trong Broath with a few Spoonfuls of Gelly, and between whiles the Yolk of a new laid Egg; but too much Food mut not be given at a time, becaue her Stomach cannot diget it. Her Drink mut be Red Wine with a little Water wherein Iron has been quenched; and if there is the leat appearance of Excrements contained in the Guts, make no Scruple to give a Gliter to evacuate them. But if notwithtanding
the Blood continues Flooding, then the Woman will often have Fainting Fits, and be in great danger of loing her Life, becaue we cannot apply in thoe places the Remedies fit to top the opening of the Veels as we can in another.

div.head: CHAP. XXVII.
Of a Suppreion of the Child-bed Purgations, and After-pains.
div.p: THE Suppreion of the Lochia is one of the wort Symptoms that can befall a Woman in Child-bed, epecially if they happen to be totally and uddenly topt the firt three or four days, which is the time they hould come down plentifully.

To bring the Lochia well down, let the Woman avoid Paion, and all diturbances of the Mind, which may top them; let her lie in Bed with her Head and Breat a little raied, keeping her elf quiet, that o the Humours may be carried downwards by their natural tendency. Let her oberve a good Diet, omewhat hot and moit, and apply an Hyteric Plater to her Navel.

Take of the Conerves of Roman Wormwood and Rue each one Ounce, of the Troches of Myrrh two Drams, of Cator, Englih
Saffron, Volatile Salt of Armoniac, and of Aa fetida, each half a Dram, with a ufficient quantity of the Syrup of the five opening Roots, make an Electuary. Let her take the quantity of a Large Nutmeg every third Hour, drinking upon it three or four Spoonfuls of the following mixture.

Take of the Water of Penny royal and Balm each three Ounces, of Compound Briony water two Ounces, of Syrup of Mugwort three Ounces and an half, of Saffron two Drams, of Cator tied up in a rag and hanged in a Glas one Scruple, mingle them.

If thee things are ued preently upon the Suppreion, they generally take it off but if they have been ued o long that all the quantity is taken, and the Lochia are till topt, in this cae we may ue Laudanum for once, but it is bet to mix it with Heterick things: For intance, take ixteen drops of Liquid Laudanum in a Spoonful of Compound Briony, or Water. But it mut be carfully noted, that if after having once taken it, the buines is not done, Opium mut not be repeated again, but having waited a while, to ee what it will do, we mut return again to Emmenagoges mixt with Hytericks, and afterwards we mut inject a Gliter; but what
was aid before of Opium, is to be taken notice of in repect of Gliters, for unles the firt bring down the Lochia, nothing is to be hoped for from more.

Thee things therefore being done, it is afet and the duty of a prudent Phyician to wait and ee what time will do, for if the Woman live over the twentieth day, he will be in a manner out of danger, and then he will be able to bear uch a method as is proper and effectual enough to force the Lochia.

If the After-pains are more than uual, you mut Swath the Womans Belly gently, that it may ubide, and not move hither and thither, as it often happens after delivery, upon o udden an evacuation, and then give three Ounces of Oyl of Almonds freh drawn, mixt with one Ounce and an half of Syrup of Violets.

And Gliters may be injected made of Milk and Sugar, and yolks of Eggs, and the Belly mut be anointed with the Oyl of Dill, or of Rue, or of Jamine. A Fomentation may be alo made of a Decoction of Mugwort, Feverfew, Baulm, of the Leaves of Bays, and Calaminth, of the Seeds of Daucus, Cummin, and Carraways, of the Flowers of Camomile
and Wall-flower, made in Water and White-wine, or in Milk. It is alo proper to cover the Belly with a Sheeps-skin, freh flead off, and appli'd hot. The following Powder taken preently after delivery preerves the Woman from Pain in a wonderful manner; and ome think if the Woman takes it in her firt lying in, he will never be troubled with thee Pains.

Take of Comfry dryed one Dram, of the Kirnels of Peach tones, and of Nutmegs, each two Scruples, of Amber half a Dram, of Ambergrie half a Scruple, make a Powder, whereof let her take a Dram with Whitewine, and if there be a Fever with Broth.

If the Woman after delivery be troubled with a pain in the Groin, it may be taken off by applying a Plater of Galbanum and Aafetida to the Navel, in the middle whereof ome Grains of Musk mut be placed.

div.head: CHAP. XXVIII.
Of acute Dieaes of Women in Child-Bed.
div.p: A Putrid Fever eies Child-bed Women at various Seaons, and upon everal occaions, ometimes preently after delivery, epecially if it has been difficult and hard, ometimes on the firt, ometimes on the econd, third, or fourth day, but the later it begins, the better it goes off.

It begins and proceeds mot commonly in the following manner, after a previous indipoition, the Fever begins mot commonly with a haking and hivering, which Heat preently follows, and after that Sweat, the firt or econd day fits of Heat and Cold ucceed one another, and then all the Blood being inflamed, the Lochia if they were not uppreed before, flow but little, or quite top; if the Dieae be acute, and of quick motion, it comes to its height the third or fourth day; the Heat is violent, and the Thirt
very much, the Pule vehement and quick, watchings obtinate, there is a great retlenes, that the ick tumble from one ide of the Bed to the other continually; the Urin is thick and red, and there are many other grievous Symptoms; when the Fever is in its tate, no Criis is to be expected, for I never aw this Dieae go off by a critical Sweat.

The acute Dieaes of Women in Child-bed are ometimes accompanied with a Quinie, Pluriie, Peripneumonia, Bloody-flux, Small-pox, and the like; of thee a Quinie, Pluriie, and Peripneumonia, by reaon of the great Smilitude of the Caue, and Analogy of the Cure, may be conidered together; preently at their firt beginning we mut endeavour that the Blood fixed any where, and beginning to be extravaated be retor'd to Circulation, let an Impothume hould be occaioned; wherefore internal remedies which free the Blood from Coagulation mut be ued, of which ort are Diaphoreticks abounding with Volatile Salt, as Spirit of Harts-horn, of Soot, and Urine, alo Tetaceous and Bezoartick Powders, Lapis Prunella, Decoctions and a Julep made of Vegetables that force Urine and the Coures, with all which mut be mixt
uch things as have been found by experience to be proper for Uterine Dieaes. Moreover dicutient Medicines, which dipere the matter impacted, uch are Liniments, Fomentations, and Cataplams, mut be carefully applyed to the parts affected; in the mean while the violent Motion and immoderate effervecence mut be driven far from thence, and the filth mut be driven as much as is poible downwards; to this end Frictions, Ligatures, Epipaticks, and if there be occaion, Cupping Glaes, mut be applied about the Legs and Feet. If the Dieae be very violent Bleeding is indicated, and unles there be a Plethora in the whole Body, and the Inflammation be very acute in the part affected, it were be bet to open a Vein in the Foot, or to apply Leeches to the Hemorrhoidal Veins; but if neceity urge, we may bleed in the Arm, and afterwards, if it can be admitted, in the Foot; but you mut take notice, that Bleeding mut be cautiouly ued in thee Caes, for unles it does good, which I have eldom found, the Sick is in a wore condition, being render'd weaker thereby.

The Bloody-flux is very often deadly, and o much the rather, becaue uch
things as qualifie the Blood, and that moderately bind, are indicated; but the Flux of the Lochia forbids them, wherefore in this cae till he has been well Purged by a long Flux of the Lochia, the fiercenes of the Symptoms mut at preent be only appeaed.

The Indications in the Small-pox are not only contrary to thoe above decribed, but alo to one another; for the Flux of the Lochia mut be moderately retrain'd; but in the mean while the efflorecence of the Blood, and gentle Sweating mut be continued, wherefore uch things as are of an Alexipharmic and Atringent Nature mut be boyl'd in their Broths, as the Roots of Tormentil and Bitort; and in this cae the Woman mut not eat Fleh, or the Broths of it, nor mut he rie, but be kept as quiet as is poible, and the whole buines mut be left in a manner to God and Nature

All Women in Child-bed have an inbred Venom, and they ought to be careful of it, and to avoid it as much as the greatet Malignity; wherefore they ought to ue an exact coure of Diet, whereby the impurities of the Blood and Humours may be purged in Child-bed without the
danger of a Fever, and that the diorders of the Womb may be healed, and their trength weakned by delivery may be retored, to which end three things are to be minded, firt an exact coure of Diet mut be ordered, viz. That they be fed for a Week at leat with Water-gruel, ometimes made with Beer, ometimes made with Water mixt with White-wine, or with Panada, and other things of eaie Digetion: Secondly, They mut take great care that they do not catch cold, whereby the Pores and the Lochia may be topt; wherefore let them continue in Bed at leat till the tenth day: Thirdly, The Lochia mut be gently provoked; to this end Midwives when after hard Labour, there is danger of the toppage of the Lochia, give Sperma Ceti, Irih Slates powdered, or White-wine Tinctured with Saffron, and they make the Gruel with Water and White-wine, wherein as alo in Poet-Drink they boyl Marygold Flowers, the Leaves of Penny-royal, or Mugwort.

div.head: CHAP. XXIX.
Of the Melancholy, Madnes, Delirium, and Epilepie of Women in Child-bed.
div.p:
THee Dieaes happen in Child-bed, for want of a ufficient evacuation, by reaon of the fault of the Blood, the Suppreion of it, or too great an Evacuation; or by Fevers, an ill Vapour ruhing upon the Brain, whereof Luitanus mentions an obervation of a very Beautiful Lady, that preently after delivery fell Melancholy, and was mad for a Month, but by the ue of a few Medicines recovered her Senes; and I, ays Rodericus a Catro, have often cured a Dutch Merchants Wife who was frequently ditracted after delivery. Thee Dieaes are thus ditinguihed, Melancholy is a Delirium without a Fever, occaioned by a Melancholy humour poeing the Seat of the Mind. Madnes is more outragious, and a hot Intemperies is the occaion of it; whereas Melancholy proceeds from a cold Intemperies:
An Epilepie is a Convulion of all the parts of the Body, not perpetual, but by intervals, with a depravation of Sene and Jugdment. Latly, a Delirium is an alienation of the Mind, and proceeds mot commonly from a bilious Fever, and therefore is not a Dieae, but a Symptom.

Thee are the general Indications; if thee Dieaes proceed from an immoderat Flux, it mut be topt, the trength mut be kept up, and the cold and dry Intemperies mut be corrected. If they proceed from a Suppreion of the Child-bed Purgations, they mut be forced; if they are occaioned by a fault in the Blood, they mut be treated as the Melancholy of Virgins and Widows.
The mot Grievous Symptom of thee Dieaes are obtinate Watching; in this cae apply often to the Temples the following Oxyrrhodine.

Take of the Waters of Roes and Plantain, each four Ounces, of Oyl of Roes, three Ounces, of Vinegar of Roes one Ounce, the Powder of Red Sanders, one Drachm, mingle them, apply it in a Rag, or Populeon Oyntment mixed with Oyntment of Roes, three Grains of Opium, and one Scruple of Saffron;
or a live Pigeon cut in two may be applied hot to the Head. And if thee things do not do, one Dram of Philonium may be given in Lettice Water and a little Wine at Bed-time. Note that in an Epilepie the Oxyrrhodine above mentioned is not o proper, becaue it cools the Head too much, and in Melancholy uch things mut be added to it as moiten more.

div.head: CHAP. XXX.
Of driving away the Milk, of Tumors from Milk, of want of Milk, and of Chaps of the Nipples.
div.p:
IF the Milk flow too freely into the Breats, a Thin and Spare Diet mut be ordered, and the Breats mut be often ucked to prevent the Inflammation of them, and the immoderate effervecence of the Blood; and if it be not thought convenient that the Woman hould give uck it is cutomary on the firt or third day of Lying in, to apply over the Breats moderately atringent Cerecloths, or the Populean Oyntment, and Galens cooling Cerate equally mixt, and pread on Linnen; ome ue Linnen dipt in Luke-warm Verjuice, wherein a little Allom has bin diolved, that o it may be more atringent; but great care mut be taken in the application and change of thee things, that the Woman catch not the leat cold, as alo that no Inflammation or Impotume be caued, intead of driving back the
Milk: Wherefore things are to be applyed according to the variety of the cae.
But the bet way to drive away the Milk is the cauing an ample Evacuation of the Lochia, which is much further'd by keeping the Belly open with Gliters.

Milk is the occaion of many tumours of divers kinds: The differences may be thus enumerated; if the Ferment of the Breat be over active, it eparates the Milk with too great violence, cauing thereby an over Fermentation in the part, which uually produces a Tumor called a Phlegmon, if the Serum be hot, or partakes much of Blood; otherwie it raies a Tumor called an Oedema; or if the matter be dipoed to Coagulate, the Kings Evil: And thee are the mot frequent Species of Tumors generally reputed to arie from Milk, and either of them may degenerate into a Scirrhus, and that Scirrhus into a Cancer. The Signs are Viible; if the firt happen, there are all the Symptoms of a Phlegmon, Heat, Rednes, Tenion, Pulation, and the like; if the Second, large ditenion with pain, but no heat; if the Kings Evil, then hard Kernels are eaily felt.

Swellings made by the over eagernes of the milky Ferment go eaily off, if no other Symptom attend them. Sucking and drawing the Breat for the mot part dicharges the Milk, as fat as it can be generated, and then all goes off well. But if the Fermentation produce any diorder in the Blood, there is more or les danger according to the quality of the Tumor produced, viz. A Phlegmon is apt to occaion a Fever, Oedematous Tumors are apt to grow Ulcers, and ometimes Scrophulous, and Scirrhous, and require a long time for their Cure. Becaue it frequently happens to Women in Child-bed, that their Breats do well extraordinarly by reaon of abundance of Milk, which flows into them, and occaions Inflammations, Impotumations, and the like; therefore their Diet ought to be lender, and of uch a quality as may les dipoe the Humours to ferment, as Water-gruel, Panado, and the like. But if the Inflammation be not violent, or the Patient weak, Chicken Broath may be allowed with Wood-orrel, Purlain, Lettice boiled in it, or a boiled Chicken, a Potched Egg, and uch ort of Meats of eaie digetion. The Medicines proper to diminih the Milk, are Lettice, Purlain,
Endive, Succory, Smallage, and the like, the Seeds of wild Rue, Cummin, Bail powdered and given to the quantity of one Dram daily in Broath, will dry up the Milk, as Authors write.

The Milk is uually drawn out of the Breats by the Infants ucking them: But if the Child be o weak, it cannot uck, or does not dicharge them enough, ome body ele mut do it, or young Whelps may uck them, or the Mother may draw her own Breats her elf by an Intrument old for that purpoe.
The welling made by the Milk is retrained by the application of Night-hade, Lettice, Plantain, Vine-tops, Bramble-buds, Hore-tail, and the like, or with the Oyl of Myrtles and Vinegar.

It may be dicued by the application of Mints, Catmints, Rue, the Seeds of Fenugreek, Cummin, Fennel, and the like, or dried up by applying Cloaths dipt in Lime water, or a Solution of Sacharum Saturni in the Water of Frogs Spawn; during which time fine Tow may be prinkled with Cerus, and applied to the Armpits: But thee things mut be only ued at the beginning of the Fluxion.

But if the Inflammation be gon too far towards Suppuration, then it mut be promoted
with Suppuratives, and opened by Inciion or a Cautick.
Where the welling has been hard, and not inflamed, ue the following Cerat.

Take of the tops of Wormwood powdered two Drams, of the Seeds of Fenugreek and Fennel, each one Ounce and an half, of the Juice of Henbane and Hemlock, each three Ounces, of Oyntment of Marh-mallows two Ounces, of Ducks Fat, and Gooe Greae, each one Ounce, of Deers Suet two Ounces, of Liquid Storax half an Ounce, with a ufficient quantity of Wax, make a Cerat.

Hemlock boyled in Wine, and beaten up with Hogs Lard reolves the hardnes of the Breats. Green Mints, or Chickweed are common applications, and of good ue, either alone or mixed with other Medicines, in all the hard Swellings of the Breat occaioned by Milk. All Platers applied to the Breats mut have a hole niped in them for the Nipples, let they be fretted by them, epecially that the Milk may be drawn forth whilt the Medicines lye on.

But it is bet to prevent uch Swellings at the beginning by procuring an ample and large Evacuation of the Lochia. For
the Chaps and Excoriations of the Niples, Rags dipt in Plantain-water may be applied, or the Oyntment called Diapompholigos may be ued: But great care mut be taken that nothing be applied to digut the Child; wherefore ome only ue Honey of Roes: But if the Excoriation and Pain be much, the Woman mut forbear giving the Child uck.
If the Child has wholly ucked off the Nipples, the Milk then mut be quite dried away, that o the Ulcers which remain may be the ooner healed.

div.head: CHAP. XXXI.
Of want of Milk.
div.p: THE caue of want of Milk is a Vice of the Blood, the weaknes of the Body, or of the Child, the mallnes of the Breats, the narrownes of the Veels, any immoderate Evacuation by another part, as by the Mouth, by the Coures, by the Notrils, or by the Hemorrhoids, by immoderate Cold, ill Diet, Fating, great Labour, or Sorrow.

The whole Cure in a manner conits in Diet. If therefore it be occaioned for want of Blood, or by a dry Intemperies, from whence it chiefly proceeds, it mut be cured by a hot and moit Diet, and the Air mut be moit and moderately warm. Sleep is better than immoderate Watching. The Bread mut be Wheaten and well fermented. Goats or Sheeps Milk boil'd with Yolks of Eggs, and weetned is good; o is Rice boild with Milk and Honey, Potched Eggs, Chicken Broath, Mutton or Veal Broath, or Broath
of Pheants, or the Fleh of them with a Sauce made of Rocket and Honey; the Udders of Animals are alo good. Of Fihes, a Trout, Mullet, a Salmon, Soles, Place, Pikes, and the like are good; and for the econd Coure, Sweet Almonds, Raiins of the Sun, Pitaches, Pine Nuts, Rocket, Parnips roated under the Embers, or prepared with Honey. Diacorides and Avicenna commend Fennel and Smalage; Lettice is alo good, o are Cabbage, Wild Thime, Leeks, Rocket, Fennel. Let her drink be weet Wine, or White-wine, or Barley water with the Seeds of Fennel, or Ale; wherein if you boyl Butter, Sugar, and Bread, you'll Scarce find a better Diet for this purpoe. The German Women ue this for their Meat and Drink almot all the time they give uck. All things that are acid, acrid, bitter and very hot mut be avoided. But if this defect proceed from heat or choler, you mut ue cooling things, and the Body mut be purged according to the Nature of the Humour: But if the Blood be Flegmatick, and the Veels obtructed, you mut open the Obtructions and attenuate the Blood; therefore you mut give hot things, as Smallage, Dill, Penny-royal with Wine: But you mut be
careful not to give things that are too hot; for they dry up the Milk. And as thoe things which Moderately provoke the Coures breed Milk, o thoe that violently force them leen it.

Blood is never to be drawn, nor are trong Purges to be ued: But if it be neceary to ue Purging by reaon of the fault of the Humours, the Nure mut take four days before uch things as increae the Milk, and uch Medicines mut be given as increae the Milk. As

Take of thee Seeds of Fennel, of Leeks, and Rocket, each two Drams, of Mace one Dram, of the Leaves of Mallows half a handful, boyl them in Chicken Broath, and let her take ix Ounces of the Broath, and wah the Breats with the Broath.

But if the want of Milk proceeds from the mallnes of the Breats, foment them with a Decoction of Fenugreek, and Camomile made in Wine, or with hot Beer and Butter. But if thee things do not good, you mut chue another Nure; but you mut try all things firt, for change of Milk is very injurious to the Child.

div.head: CHAP. XXXII.
Of a Woman uckling her own Children, and of chuing a Nure.
div.p:
THE Mothers Milk is fittet for the Child, becaue it is mot agreeable to it Nature: Beides the Mother will be more vigilant and careful than a hired Nure; for none can love, the Child o well as the own Mother, who upon the account of her affection is unwearied in the attending of the Child, and thinks he never does enough for it, and is preently awaked by its crying; whereas mercenary Nures often overlay Children and uffocate them. Moreover the Body, and the dipoition of the Mind are more framed by the Milk and Nourihment, than by the nature of the Seed; and as you often oberve that the Child is purged when the Nure is Purged; o the Body and Humours are in a manner the ame with hers, as Trees partake of the nature of the Soil they are planted in. Beides, it is the duty of a Mother to nure
her own Child; for thoe that do not are but half Mothers, and to be ure cannot love them o well as thoe that do. Upon this account a Roman Youth of the Family of the Gracchi, returning Rich and Victorious from the Wars, being met by his Mother and his Nure, gave his Mother a Silver Ring, and his Nure a Gold Chain; whereat his Mother being offended; You, aid he, nourihed me only Nine Months in the Womb, and then rejected me, this Woman received me into her Arms, and uckled me two Years, and taught me to be orderly. The Water nourihes what is bred in the Water, and the Earth nourihes what is bred in the Earth: Nor is there any Beat o cruel, as not to nourih its young ones. Tygers, Lions, and Vipers take care of their young ones, and only Man makes Foundlings of his: Oh! incredible and execrable Villany, what can be more cruel, than to expoe a tender Infant that implores his Mothers help, as oon as poibly he can get rid of it? But God in his Providence often punihes their Inhumanity; for their Milk often curdles in their Breat, and occaions dreadful pains, o that thoe Breats, which were denied their Children are forced to be uckt by
Puppies; nor is this all, for their Breats are often Inflamed and Suppurated, and mut be cut with Knives, or burnt with red hot Irons, or becoming Cancerous, the rotten Fleh drops from them piecemeal. But ome will object in their excue, that they are either too young or too weak, yet without doubt if they are able to Conceive, they may Suckle too; for God never gave them Breats full of Milk to no purpoe. But if they have not Milk enough, which is the only real excue, a Nure mut be choen, who ought to be of an age betwixt twenty and thirty; he ought to be of a trong Contitution, well Coloured, not too Fat, nor too Lean; he mut not have rotten Teeth, nor a tinking Breath, nor be affected with Scabs, Ulcers, the French-Pox, Gout, Conumption, or any other Dieae. Thirdly, Her Manners are to be conidered; for the Child ucks them in with the Milk; whereof the Nure ought to be good tempered; he mut not be ubject to violent Paions, nor wholly without Paion, nor of a weak Judgment; he mut not be quint eyed, let the Child hould be o; he mut be Chat, and not have Converation with her Husband, let her Coures hould flow, or the
Blood be diturbed, and conequently the Milk; or be with Child, whereby the Milk would be leened, and become vitious: but ome think that the Coures flowing moderately does not vitiate the Milk, but rather cleanes the ret of the Blood. Fourthly, we mut conider the time from Delivery; for he mut not give uck too near Delivery, nor too long from the time of it. She mut not give uck until he be free of the Child-bed Purgations; the time mot approved of, is from the Second Month to the Sixth, and he hould have Nured a Child before. Fifthly, The Breats are to be conidered, which ought to be moderately full, not looe and hanging down; but olid and firm, of a moderate bignes and hardnes, and the Veins of them hould look blew, and dipered into many treams, moderately elevated, that they may contain the more Milk; for if they are dene, and the Milk is bound up in them, and as it were uffocated, the Child can carce draw it, and o either takes a ditate, or if it uck on, the Noe is flattened by the preure. Sixthly, The Paps mut not be o hort as that the Child cannot take hold of them with his Lips, nor o long and
thick, as to fill the Infants Mouth, o that it cannot readily ue its Tongue to uck or wallow. Seventhly, The nature of the Milk mut be conidered, which, beides the clearnes and weetnes of it, which are the firt requiits, mut be alo weet-ented, not too thick nor too thin, which may be tried by dipping a hair in the Milk, hanging it up, if the Milk lide off, it is naught, but if it compas the whole hair it is good. Eightly, chue a Nure which was lat delivered of a Male child. Ninethly, Such an one as is not wont to micarry. Tenthly, She mut not be with Child. The Nure o decribed on the firt days he begins to uckle mut ue a imple Diet, let too much Milk hould overwhelm the tender Infant. Afterwards let her have good Meats: She mut not Drink exceively, he mut abtain from Wine, and from alt, harp, and a tringent Meats, and Leeks, Onions, Garlick, Rocket and Spices. She mut avoid all perturbations of Mind, and Copulation; let her moderately exercie her Arms and upper Parts. Latly, Her Diet mut be uch, as the Nature and Contitution of the Infant requires; if the Child be of a hot Contitution, he mut ue a cooling Diet; but if the Infant
be of a cold Contitution, a little Wine and Spices mut be allowed, and tronger exercie, and if the Nure be not well, he mut be purged, and Diet mut be ordered according to the faults of the Milk, and the diorders of the Child. The Nure mut be always chearful, and laughing, and inging with the Child. She mut keep it clean. She mut peak ditinctly. She mut ait the Child in ucking by preing gently her Breats; but he mut not let the Child uck too much at once.

div.head: CHAP. XXXIII.
Of Wrinkles in the Belly and Breasts after Delivery.
div.p: WHen the Child in the Womb grows big, it tretches the Belly, or maks it chap, o that after Delivery Wrinkles remain in the Belly, and her Breats grow mall after the Milk goes away for the ame reaon. The Chaps may be prevented, if after the fourth Month of being with Child, a Linnen cloath dipt in the Oyl of weet Almonds be applied to the Belly. The Wrinkles left after Delivery may be taken off by two orts of Remedies.
Firt therefore, If the Womans Month be not out, apply to the Belly the following Oyntment.
Take of Sperma Ceti two Drams, of Oyl of Sweet Almonds, and St. Johns Wort, each one Ounce and an half, of Goats Suet one Ounce, of new Wax a ufficient quantity, make an Oyntment.
Secondly, After the Womans lying in, uch things may be ued as gently bind, and render the Belly olid and firm.

Take of the ditilled Water of Mallows, and Marh-mallow, each one Quart, of Roe-Water a Pint and half, two Lemons peeled and liced, of unripe Sloes one Pound; infue them together two days, and then ditil them in a Glas Alembick with a gentle fire, and bath the Womans Belly with it. But the following makes the Belly more olid.

Take of Figs one Pound, of the Meal of Barley and Beans, each half an Ounce, of the Meal of Rice two Ounces, of Galls, and Cypres Nuts, each one Dram, of Matich, and Myrrh, each one Dram and half, of the Seeds of Fennel one Dram; boyl them all in Smiths Water till they are a little thick, then apply them to the Belly; or after bathing with a Decoction of the foreaid things: apply the following Pultis to the Belly.

Take of the Meal of Beans, Rice, Acorns and Almonds, each two Ounces, of Bricks powdered one Ounce, of Bole-armenick two Drams, of Dragons Blood one Dram, of Cypres Nuts half an Ounce, of Kermes three Drams, of Galls half an Ounce, of Oyl of Myrtles ix Ounces, of the Waters of Medlars,
and Sloes, each one Pint, of Roe-water one Pint and an half; boyl them to the conitence of a Pultis, apply it to the Belly.

It alo makes the Breats olid. But let the Breat and Bowels hould be offended by its frigidity and binding quality, add of Matick two Drams, of Nutmegs three Drams, of Florentine Orris half an Ounce. Myrrh mixed with thee, the Decoction of it, or ued any other way renders the Belly mooth and firm, and the Breats hard compact and mall, and narrows the Privities, and is accounted a great ecret in this cae.

div.head: CHAP. XXXIV.
Of traitning the Privities after Delivery.
div.p: AFter Delivery the Privities are lax; and hence Barrenes, and a falling of the Womb are ometimes occaioned. The Cure is performed by two orts of Remedies.
Firt, if the Privities are too moit, uch things mut be ued as dry; the following Uterine Gliter is very proper.
Take of Galls number four, of Spodium two Spoonfuls, powder them very fine, and add Six Ounces of Stiptic-wine; afterwards put up the following Peary.

Take of the Bark of the Pine two Drams, Allom one Dram, of Cyprus one Pugil, boyl them in Wine to the conitence of a Pultis, apply them often with a rag: Or infue Galls in Rain-water eight days, and with oft Wool prinkled with Sulphur, and dipt in
this Water and dried without preing, make a Peary.

But Secondly, And chiefly you mut ue Atringents, Foment the Genitals with the Water or Decoction of Acorns, unripe Sloes, and of Hore-tail; or Foment the Parts with Allom-water, or with Stiptic-Wine, that is, red and rough Wine boyl'd with Galls, Leaves of Myrtles, Red Roes, Pomgranet-peel Balautines, and Cypres Nuts: Or,

Take of Cypres Nuts and Galls, each one Pound, of Roch-allom, and the filings of Iron prepared in Vinegar, each half a Pound, boyl them in a ufficient quantity of the Waters of Galls, which Tanners ue, and Foment the Parts often with it.
The following Water is counted excellent.

Take of Galls, and of Cypres Nuts, each half a Pound, of Allom ix Drams, Bolearmonick half a Pound, of the Meal of Acorns, and of old Beans, each half a Pound, the Whites of twelve Eggs, of Powder of Brick one Pound; let them be all finely powdered, and infue them three Days in Smiths
Water, or in a decoction of Sloes, Medlars, or Hore-tail, with half a Pint of Roe Vinegar; then Ditill them in a cold Still with a gentle Fire; add to the Water that comes off, of the Powders of Matick, Myrrh, and Dragons Blood, each two Drams. Set the water in the Sun in the Summer for ten days, this traitens the Privities, moothens the Belly, and makes the Breats olid.

div.head: CHAP. XXXV.
Of Abcees and Corroive Vlcers ariing from Ditempers of the Womb in Childbed.
div.p:
THE Womb is ometimes terribly affected in Child-bed, and produces Fevers of very Malignant and Venomous Natures, which oon caue Phlegmons, and wore Tumours, in the Womb it elf, and ometimes in other parts of the Body, there being none of them on which the Uterine Ferment has not an influence. The Exhorbitances or Degenerations of that, whether from an hurt in Labour, from part of the Afterbirth left behind, from cold taken, or the Lochia topt, oon produce uch Virulent Ditempers in the Blood as make it cat out a Tumor, either upon the part it elf, or ele outwardly upon the Mucles of the Body, where when they
light, they prove corroive, ometimes eating out the Fleh in which they lodge, which falls off in whole pieces, without that change of colour in the Skin, which is in Gangreens, o that ometimes the Bone it elf is laid bare by them.
The Caues are hard Labour, the Womb hurt, or part of the Secundine left behind; Cold taken in Child-bed, and a predipoition in the Humours, by reaon of their peccancy in quantity or quality.

The Prognotick may be taken from the largnes, or other qualifications of the Abces, and the Symptoms that happen to the Body thereupon. If the Tumor happens only from ome little diturbance in the Womb of a Peron otherwie of a good habit of Body, the cure is hopeful. If part of the After-birth be retained, there is no hope's of Cure till that be removed, nay if it tay o long, as to induce Putrefaction of the part, it will be too late then to remove it.

If the Body be of an ill Habit, the Tumours are apt to Degenerate into very Venomous and Malignant Abcees, which if they do not uddenly kill, do at leat produce ill conditoned Ulcers, hard of Cure, and for the mot part mortal in the long coure of the Dieae.

In the Cure of thee Abcees, you are to inform your elf how the Womb is diturbed, and appeae that; and if any part of the After-birth be left behind, to endeavour the bringing that away, and by good Sudorificks, Cordials and the like, to expel the Venom, and fortifie the Spirits againt the Malignity that is thereby contracted, and to attemperate the heat, and the Acrimony by Julips and Emulions.
The Swellings ariing from thee require to be treated in their beginning with moderate Repellents and Dicutients afterward, according as the Matter prepredominates, make way for its dicharge.

A young Woman after Child-bed was eized with a great Pain and Swelling in her Groin, with a Fever. Bleeding and Lenient Purgatives to Evacuate the Humours were precribed, alo Cordial Juleps, and the like, to attemperate the Heat, and fortifie the Spirits; and Moderate Repellents mixed with Dicutients in Fomentations, and Platers with Bandage were ued, which dipered the Humor in the Thigh, and retored that part to its former temper: But in the mean time the Tumor increaed in the Groin, and was uppurated after the manner of a Bubo; it was opened, and a deterion was endeavoured; but the Sinus reaching down the Twit, the Matter could not be dicharged without laying it more open, as in Sinous Ulcers, by which method it was cured.

A Gentlewoman in Child-bed was eized with a Fever, and the Ninth Day complained of a pain in her Foot. Dicutients were precribed, together with things proper for the Fever to breath out the impacted Matter in her Foot; but the pain increaing, the upper part of the Foot from the Intep to the Toes
were Oedematous; but from the inide of the Ancle to the middle of the Sole of her Foot inflamed, and eeming to apotumate. The ill conequences of an Apotumation in that part amongt the Tendons and Bones, and where the Skin is uually o hard and tough, that our tronget Cauticks could difficultly penetrate, being feared; It was reolved to endeavour the retraint of the Influx, and o to dry up the Humour affecting the part; to which purpoe was applied the following Plater.

Take of Barley Meal Six Ounces, of Flax Seeds powdered Six Drams, of the Flowers of Camomile and Elder, each three Drams, of the Flowers of Red Roes and Balautins, each one Ounce; thee with the addition of Honey of Roes and Oyl of Myrtles were boyled to the conitence of a Plaster in red Wine, and at Bed-time an Anodyne Draught was given to caue ret.

The next Morning the Patient was omewhat relieved, and when the Dreings were taken off, the Tumor and Inflammation eemed les. This way of
dreing was continued with Compres and Bandage, and the Humour was in few Days dried up, and the Foot eemed well; but there appeared again a Swelling on the Foot, and Apotumated in the Sole of the Foot in three everal places, which were opened with a Cautick, to prevent the increae of the Matter, and the Echars were divided to give a vent, and they were dreed with Bailicon and the Plater as before, and the flowing of the Matter was indeavoured to be hindred dayly by Compres and Bandage; but the Poition of the Foot gave way, and it unk lower, o that there was a neceity of applying another Cautick, which proved effectual to the Dicharge of it; o that the upper Orifices healed, but this lat Echar eparated lowly, and left the great Tendon bare; the Separation was furthered by the ue of Oyl of Turpentine with Bailicon applied warm, and the Tendon was incarnated with a Sarcotick compoed of a mixture of Powder of Orris, Myrrh, Sarcocoll, and Mercury precipitate, with Honey of Roes and Turpentine, and the Ulcer was cicatrized with the Epuloticks. After
it was cicatrized the Sole of her Foot was o relaxed and tender, that upon etting it on the Ground it became very much ubject to a pituitous Swelling: But by the ue of a Fomentation and a laced Stocking, the weak parts were trengthned, and he was cured.

div.head: CHAP. XXXVI.
Of the Falling of the Womb.
div.p: FOR the Cure of this Dieae, regard mut be had to two things; the firt is to reduce the Womb to its natural place; the econd is to trengthen and to keep it there.

If the Womb be quite out or turned, the Woman mut firt of all render her Urine, and a Gliter mut be given to Evacuate the gros Excrements that are in the right Gut, that o the Reduction may be the eaier performed: Then place her on her Back with her Hips raied a little higher than her Head, and then foment all that is fallen out, with a little Wine and Water luke-warm, and with a oft Rag put it into its proper place, thruting it back not all at once, but wagging it by little and little from ide to ide. In cae this be too painful, becaue it's already too big and well'd, anoint it with Oyl of Almonds, for the more eaie reduction of it; but wipe oft
the Oyl, as oon as it is reduced. But if it cannot be put up by reaon of the great Inflammation and Tumor, there is great danger that it will gangrene.

As to the econd part of the Cure, which conits in the retention of the Womb in its place, and the trengthening of it, let the Woman keep her elf in Bed upon her Back having her Hips a little raied, her Legs croed, and her Thighs joyned together to prevent the falling of it out again. But the bet way is to put up a Peary into the Neck of the Womb to keep it firm.

Take of Oak Bark two Ounces, boyl it in two Quarts of Fountain Water, add at the latter end an Ounce of Pomgranat-peel bruied, Red Roes, Pomgranat Flowers, each two handfuls, and then add half a Pint of Redwine; train it, and bath the part affected with Flannels dipt in it in the Morning two hours before the Woman ries, and at night when he is in Bed; continue it till the Symptom is quite gone.

div.head: CHAP. XXVII.
Of a Dropie and Inflation of the Womb.
div.p: THE Inflation and Dropie are confounded by almot all Authors; but they are to be ditinguihed; for there is a certain Inflation of the Womb which ought not to be called a Dropie, Viz. When the Womb is Inflated, and tretched uddenly by Wind ruhing in; upon which account a violent Pain is occaioned; this often happens in Hyterick Dieaes. Wherefore a Dropie of the Womb is two-fold, one from Wind, which is like a Tympany; another from a watery Humour, which is like a Dropie of the Belly.
As to the Diagnotick of thee Dieaes, many things are to be enquired into.
Firt, How they may be ditinguihed from an univeral Dropie.
Secondly, How the Species of it may be known, viz. Whether it proceeds from Wind, Water, or Flegm
Thirdly, If it arie primarily from the Womb, or be occaioned by the fault of ome other part.
Fourthly, Whether the peccant Matter be contained in the Cavity of the Womb, or within the Membranes of it, or in Bladders.
Fifthly, How it may be ditinguihed from other Tumours of the Womb.
Sixthly, How it may be ditinguihed from being with Child.
Seventhly, How it may be ditinguihed from a Mola.

Firt, It is ditinguihed from an univeral Dropie, for that in a Dropie of the Womb, the Tumour poees more the bottom of the Womb, and there is not o oon a palenes and wating of the whole Body, as in an univeral Dropie. Beides, in a Dropie of the Womb, the thirt and drines of the Tongue is not coniderable, and Wind breaks out by intervals, or a little Water flows out, which manifetly hew, that Wind or Water is contained in the Womb.

Secondly, The Species of Dropies in the Womb are thus ditinguihed, if it be occaioned by Wind, the bottom of the Belly ounds being truck; there are pricking pains in the Belly, which ometimes
run through the Diaphragm, Stomach, Loins, Navel, and other parts, and ometimes the Wind does evidently break through the Neck of the Womb; the Dieae grows wore upon eating and drinking, and they often belch, and are better after it; they ometimes perceive a pain in the Region of the Hypogater, o that they cannot bear an Hand laid on it; thee igns are alo in an Inflation of the Womb; but there is this difference, for an Inflation is but for a mall pace, and a Dropie from Wind continues much longer.

But if a Dropie of the Womb is occaioned by Water, that Region appears oft and flaccid, for Wind caues a tenion; there is a greater weight in the part, and a ound as it were of Water floating, and Water ometimes drops from the part. And if it proceed from Flegm, there is a greater oftnes and flaccidity of the part, which dayly increaes, and afflicts the neighbouring parts with oedematous Swellings.

Thirdly, If there be igns of the whole Bodies being ill affected, as by long or acute Fevers, by immoderate Hemorrhagies, by weaknes of the Stomach, welling of the Liver or Spleen,
or by other obtinate Dieaes of thoe parts, by which the Dropie of the Womb began, and increaed with them; there is good reaon to conjecture that the Matter of the Dropie is received in thoe parts; but if when the whole Body is well, uch a Tumour happens, and ucceeds particular Dieaes of the Womb, as hard Labour, uppreion of the Coures, or too large an Evacuation of them, or Ulcers and Tumours, we may gues that the Dropie of the Womb proceeds from them.
Fourthly, The Matter which is contained in the cavity of the Womb caues a much greater Tumour than when it is contained within the Membranes.

Fifthly, a Dropie of the Womb may be ditinguihed from Tumours that proceed from a Phlegmon, or an Eryipelas, becaue in thee there is a Fever and Pain upon the leat touching; it may be ditinguihed from the Scirrhous, or Cancerous Tumour by the hardnes that reits the Finger.

Sixthly, When a Woman is with Child, the Tumour is not equal and depreed, but thruts it elf out above the Navel; and when a Woman is with Child, after ome Months he is mot
commonly better; but the longer a Dropie lats, the wore it grows, and the motion of the Child is plainly to be felt after the third or fourth Month; yet in a Dropie that aries from Wind, a palpitation may be ometimes perceived in the Womb, and when a Woman is with Child, the Breats well, but in a Dropie they wax mall.

Seventhly, In a Mole there is a weight felt in the Body, which is not perceived in a Dropie of the Womb, and when the Sick lies on either ide, a weight is perceived, as if a Stone rolled thither. Moreover, in a Mole there are violent Fluxes of the Coures by intervals, namely, every third or fourth Month, which does not happen in a Dropie of the Womb; and latly, in a Mole the Breats well, and have Milk in them ometimes, but there is no uch thing in a Dropie.
As to the Prognoticks, a Simple Inflation of the Womb is not dangerous, but if it continue long, it may turn to a Dropie.
If Wind or Water is contained in the cavity of the Womb it is eaier cured than when it is included in the Membranes, or in Bladders.

This Dieae is cured much the ame way as a Dropie or Green-icknes is; but ome things peculiar to this Dieae mut be added: If the Dieae be new, and occaioned by an Obtruction of the Coures, and if there be a fulnes of Blood, Bleeding may be proper, otherwie it is injurious; but Purging is always neceary, and mut be often repeated, and after ufficient Purging, Aperitives, Diureticks, and uch things as move the Coures mut be ued, to which may be added the following.

Take the Roots of Smallage, and Madder, each half an Ounce, of the Leaves of Savin, Feverfew, and Penny-royal, each one Pugil, of the Seeds of Daucus, one Dram, boyl them in the Broaths of young Pidgeons, and let her take it trained in the Morning for many Days. But before he takes the Broath, let her wallow one of the following Pills,

Take of the bet Cator, Myrrh and Madder, each half a Dram, of Saffron one Scruple, with the Juice of Lemons, make nine Pills; after the ue of which Medicine, violent Exercie mut be ued, that thereby the Excrements bred in the Bowels, and in
the habit of the Body may be diipated, and alo all that which is contained in the Womb, the Skins being broken by the violence of the Exercie, and if the Woman Vomit eaily, it will be proper to Vomit her twice a Week. The following Bolus is very effectual to dicus the Humour contained in the Womb.
Take of Mineral Borax, half a Dram, of Saffron half a Scruple, with the Juice of Savin, make a Bolus, to be taken twice a Week.

Sudorificks are alo very proper; in the mean while the heat of the Stomach mut be trengthened by things taken inwardly, and outwardly applyed. The Womb mut alo be trengthened by proper Topical Medicines: Firt by Fomentations and Baths made of a Decoction of the Roots of Briony, and wild Cucumber, of the Leaves of Dwarf Elder, Mercury Elder, Wild-marjoram, Calaminth, Wormwood, Rue, Sage, Marjoram, Thym, Bays, Penny-royal, Mugwort, of the Seeds of Broom, Daucus, Cummin, Anie, Fennel, of the Berries of Lawrel and Juniper, of the Flowers of Camomile, Melilot, Roemary, of which may be made Bags to be boiled in Wine.
But that the forementioned Fomentation may ucceed the better, you mut apply it before and behind, and the Sick ought to Sweat, if he can, in the Bed or in a Bath.
In a windy Dropie dry Fomentations are more beneficial, with Bags made of Grommel, Salt, Cummin and Bran, torrified in a Frying-pan, and prinkled with Wine.
After the Fomentation, anoint the lower Belly with the Oyls of Nard, Dill, Rue, Worm-wood, Southern-wood, and if they are Chimically prepared they will be the more effectual.

After the Anointing the Belly, apply the Plater of Lawrel-berries, or a Pultis made of Cows-dung, Sheeps-dung, of the Seeds of Smallage, Parley, and Cummin boyled in Honey. Gliters mut be frequently injected, made of a Decoction of Wormwood, Wild-marjoram, Penny-royal, Rue, Centaury, and the like; or of the Oyls of Rue, Nutmeg, Dill, and Whitewine, or in Malago Sack, wherein mut be diolved Benedictum Laxativum, Diaphenicon, Hiera diacolocinthidos, Turpentine, Confection of the Lawrelberries, Honey of Roemary, and the like. Injections for the Womb may be
prepared in the following manner to evacuate the Humours contained in it.

Take of the Roots of Aara-bacca, three Drams, of the Leaves of Penny-royal, and Calaminth, each half an handful, of Savin, one Scruple, of Mechoacan, one Dram, of the Seeds of Anie and Cummin, each half a Dram, boyl them and train them, and in ix Ounces of the Liquor, diolve of Oyls of Orris and Elder, each one Ounce; make an Injection.
For the ame purpoe Pearies may be made thus.
Take of Elaterium, half a Dram, of Figs bruied a ufficient quantity.

When the Inflation proceeds from Wind a Fume from Nutmegs is very good, and is commended by Solinander in thee words, A VVoman in Child-bed by expoing her elf to the Air too oon, fell into intolerable Pains, nor
could be relieved by any means, at length an Old and Skilful Midwife was called, he ordered three Nutmegs to be groly beaten, which he put into a Chaffing-dih with live Coals, and placed the Chaffing-dih o, that the Fume of the Nutmegs by the help of a Funnel inverted, paed into the VVomans Privities, and he received the ame Fume into her Mouth and Notrils after the ame manner, and as oon as the Fumes had Penetrated, the Woman cryed out preently he mut go to Stool, and as oon as he had o poken a great noie was heard like the hooting of a Gun, and the Woman was Cured in the ame moment; and being encouraged by this Succes, I ued it, ays he, often in like Cae, and it ucceeded well.

A Cupping-glas with much Flame applyed to the Navel wonderfully dicues Wind: But when the Dieae is Humoural, Iues in the Legs evacuate by degrees the filth of the Womb. The Bath waters ued inwardly and outwardly are alo very good, if the Body be not very hot. Amatus Luitanus commends the VVater or Decoction of Camomile Flowers to eae the Pain of the VVomb: In this Cae he orders four
or five Ounces of it to be given at a time.

Latly, if the Inflation happens after Delivery, there is no need of any other Cleaning, than what is done by the Womb: But if it does not proceed well, it mut be helped with Pearies, and Cupping-glaes applyed to the Thighs, and with other Remedies decribed for the Suppreion of the Coures: And if there be VVind, the Fume of Nutmegs above propoed are very proper.

div.head: CHAP. XXXVIII.
Of a Cancer of the Breat and Womb.
div.p: A Cancer is the name of a Tumour ariing as it is thought from an adut, or atrabilious Humour. It is round, unequally hard, and if not inflamed, of a Livid or Brown Colour with exquiite pricking Pain, the Veins appear turgid in the Skin upon the surface of the Tumour.
The remote caue of this Tumour is either a fault in the original Contitution of the Body, or an acquired one, as by a Bruie, or the like; or by an error in Dyet.

The differences of Cancers are many; ome are with Ulceration, others not; ome are looe and moveable, and o hard that they have knocked one againt another like Peebles; ome are fixed to the Bones, and ome lie uperficially; other differences may be taken from the Humour to which they owe their Original. If the Matter be not very Corroive, their
growth is low, and they are not very painful. Thee are called the milder ort, and ome of them affecting the Breat have been palliated a long time with eaie remedies.

A Lady laboured many Years of an ulcerated Cancer, it eat deep into the left Breat, and was fixed to the Ribs, but not with much pain; in progres of time the Lips inverted, and united as it were, and lay covered with a cruty Scab, the Humour in the mean while pent it elf upon the Nerves and caued a Species of the Palie in ome parts of her Body, and the Gout in others. She lived long, and in her latter Age tolerably healthful; this is to be judged a Scirrhous Cancer, yet by ill management, or by an increae of acrimony, this and uch like frequently terminate in raging Cancers, and torment the Patient with exquiite darting pains; an intance or two whereof I hall et down, to make the Young Practitioner more cautious in undertaking the Cure of them.

A VVoman had a painful hard Swelling in one of the Glands of her Breat; he was advied to forbear the ue of all Cataplams and Platers that might heat her Breat, and to dres it with Valentia
Stramonij, but he was otherwie perwaded, and thereby increaed her Miery. About half a Year after he had a tinking ordid Ulcer with lips turned out, and the Breats fixed to the Ribs, with a hard unequal Swelling reaching to the Clavicle and ide of the Neck, Apotumated in ome parts and Ulcerated in others, from the pectoral Mucle it crept up to the Shoulder, and affected the Arm-pits, and by the compreion of the Veels the upper part of the Arm Swelled Scirrhous, from the Elbow downwards it was Oedematous to the Fingers ends, he made ue of many Eminent Phyicians and Chyrurgeons in the City, but dyed mierably.

There is alo a ort of Bleeding Cancers, which become uch either from the eruption of ome Veel, which makes the vent often at the Nipple or ome other Pin-hole, the Breat remaining whole, or ele from the preading of infinite capillary Veels in a Fungus, which in ulcerated Cancers is not rare. Thee do very much pend the Strength of the Patient, o that he oon Dyes exhauted and tabid.

Of all the Dieaes which afflict Mankind, the Cancer is the mot grievous and rebellious, and is generally Incureable by reaon of its corroive and malignant venome fermenting in the Humours, which o far as we can find, yields neither to Purging, Bleeding, Repellents, Dicutients, Suppuratives, nor any other Medicine, inward or outward. Thoe which lie uperficially under the Skin may be attempted by the Chyrurgeon's Hand, or if they rie from an External Caue, as a Bruie, or the like, tho they lie deeper they may be cut off or otherwie extirpated: But thoe that arie from a corroive quality in the Humours, though they may be cut off, or otherwie extirpated, yet the ucces is mot doubtful.
The Cure of a Cancer in general conits in thee Intentions,
Firt, in the Generation of good Blood.
Secondly, In Correcting and Evacuaating the Atrabilious Humours in the Body.
Thirdly, In preventing the Growth of the Tumour, and dipoing it to Dicuion.

We endeavour to perform the Firt intention by an exact regulation of Diet and way of Living, adviing to abtain from uch harp, alt, and gros Meats as may dipoe the Blood to acrimony and order uch as are Cooling and Moitning, of eaie Digetion and of good Nourihment.

The Second intention is to prepare and purge all the acrimonious Humours; and if there be a Plethora, or a Suppreion of the Hemorrhoids, or Coures, a Vein may be opened and a Gliter given, and the Humours may be alo evacuated by a convenient Purge. as

Take of the three Cordial Flowers, one Handful, of Sena three Drams, of Dodder of Thym, two Drams, infue them in Whey, and train it, add an Ounce of the Purging Syrup of Apples, and ix Drams of Manna; mingle them.
Traumatick Decoction are alo uually precribed.

Take of the Roots and Leaves of Avens, of the greater Celandine, of Burnet, Groundel, Gentian, Plantain, each one Handful, boyl them in two parts of Water and one of Wine to the
quantity of three Pints, weeten it with Sugar, and let a Pint be drunk thrice aday
The following Electuary is alo reckoned very good.

Take of the Powders of Frogs and Snails prepared, each half an Ounce, of the Powder of River Crabs, one Ounce, of the Bone of a Stags Heart, one Dram, of Citron Peel Candied, one Ounce, of the Conerve of Borrage and Wood-orrel, each two Ounces, of the Syrup of the juice of Citron and of Gilly-flowers, a ufficient quantity, make an Electuary. Take the quantity of a Chenut, Morning and Evening.
Emulions, Ditilled Milks, and Opiates are alo very proper to attemperate the Acrimony and to eae the Pains.

The Third intention is to retrain the growth of the Tumour, and to dicus it moderately. Whilt the Humours are are evacuating, we apply Repellents, and afterwards we add Dicutients; the Repellents ought to be of the milder ort, let they render the Humours too gros and unfit for reolution, as Lettice, Purtain, Plantain, Navel-wort, Night-hade
and Houleek: Lentils boyl'd in Vinegar, alo Clay tempered with Vinegar.
The Medicines ready Compounded are the White Oyntment, Nutritum Populeon of Tutty and of burnt Lead, and Lead it elf.

All the Oyntments precribed, mut be beaten up in a Leaden Mortar. Thin milled Lead is uually worn in this Cae; o are Plates of Gold. Oyl of Frogs is commended, and is made by Baking them with Butter in their Mouths. Frogs Spawn Water is proper to be ued in Summer, Cloaths being dipt in it and applyed, but they mut be hifted as often as they dry. But in the Winter the following Cerat is better.

Take of a green Frog, three Drams, of the Powder of River Crabs burnt, half an Ounce, of Lytharge of Gold, two Ounces, of burnt Lead and Tutty prepared, each two Drams, of Cerus, ix Drams, of the Juice of Night-hade and Plantain, each ix Ounces, of Vinegar, two Ounces, of Oyl of Frogs, and of Populeon Oyntment, each three Ounces, of the Suet of a Calf, four Ounces, of Wax a ufficient quantity, make a Cerat. Or,

Take of the Seeds of White Poppy, one
Ounce, of the Seeds of Henbane, half an Ounce, of Opium, one Dram, of Gum Arabick, half an Ounce, powder them, and with the Oyls of Roes and Myrtles, each three Ounces, of Wax a ufficient quantity, make a Cerat.

This is proper in cae of Pain, in the extremity whereof you may double the quantity of Opium, or in uch Caes you may Foment the Tumour with a Decoction of Poppy Heads, Flowers of Roes, and tops of Mellilot, and apply the following Oyntment.

Take of Old Treacle, one Ounce, of the Juice of River Crabs half an Ounce, of the Juice of Lettice, and of Oyl of Roes, each one Ounce and an half, of the Yolks of Eggs roated under the Embers number two, of Camphor, half a Dram, beat them in a Leaden Mortar

The Dicutients are Ceterach, Agrimony, Ducksmeat, Scabious, Thorn-apple, the Juice of Coriander, Frogs, Snails, River Crabs, Raiins of the Sun toned and beaten, with Rue and Garden Night-hade made into a Pultits are proper to reolve them.
Many uch Medicines are deigned to this purpoe, Cancers requiring variety of Applications.

If notwithtanding all your Endeavours, the Tumour increaes, and is like to ulcerate, you may do well to forewarn the Patient of the danger, and if it be looe, propoe the extirpation of it, propoe it to them, let afterwards they deire it when it is too late. But to undergo this Operation Succesfully, the Patient ought to be of a trong Contitution, and of a pretty good habit of Body, and not in declining Age, when the Coures are ceaed. It were alo to be wihed that the Cancer took its original from ome Accident or Bruie, and the like; and the Operation ought to be performed in the Spring or Autumn of the Year.
For a Cancer of the Womb Topicks mut be applyed, which moderately Bind and Cool.

Take of Oyl of Myrtles and of Roes, each two Ounces, of the Juice of Night-hade, and of Houleek, each one Ounce, beat them all in a Leaden Mortar with a Leaden Petle till they grow black, then add of Lytharge and of Cerus wahed in Scabious water,
each three Ounces, of Tutty prepared two Drams, of Camphir, ten Grains, make a Liniment, wherewith Anoint the Part three or four times a-day.
The following is aid to be better, and with it the Tumours of the Paps, which are counted Cancerous may be Cured.

Take of the Oyl of Yolks of Eggs, two Ounces, of the Juice of Night-hade and Speedwel, or of Houleek, each half an Ounce, of crude Mercury two Drams, stir them about in a Leaden Mortar with a Leaden Petle, till they acquire the conistence of a Liniment.
The foreaid Liniments are to be applyed to the Womb with a long Tent, or with a Wax Candle wrapt round with a Rag: But Injections may be much eaier ued.

Take of Barley water, half a Pint, of the waters of Night-hade and Plantain, each two Ounces, of the water of peedwel one Ounce, of the white Troches of Rhais, two Drams, of Sacharum Saturni one Dram, make an Injection.

If the Pain be very violent add to four Oounces of the Injection, one Ounce of Syrup of Poppies. If the Cancer be Ulcerated, the Doe of the Mercury to be added to the foreaid Liniment mut be increaed, and the Ahes of River Crabs may be conveniently added.

But all thee things are not ometimes ufficient to appeae the violent Pain, which ometimes will not uffer the Sick to leep or ret, o that we are forced ometimes to ue Narcoticks, and indeed, they are not injurious in this Dieae.
I knew a Woman, that was affected with a Cancer in her Breat, who took every Night for four Months, two or three Grains of Laudanum, and was much relieved thereby.
If much Blood flow from a Cancer ulcerated, as it often happens; inject into the Womb the Juice of Plantain with a little Frankincene.

Latly, Seeing a perfect Cure cannot be expected, whether the Cancer be ulcerated or not, we mut endeavour to hinder the breaking of it, and the increae of it, when it is broken, and in both we mut qualifie the violence of the Pain by uch things as evacuate the whole Body,
and by other Remedies which alter and evacuate the melancholy Humour, and hinder its growth, as by Bleeding in the Arm, the Hemorrhodial Veins, in the Foot, by the ue of Potions, Apozems, Juleps, Broath, Milk, Whey, Mineral Waters, and the like, which are commonly precribed; but Purging mut more epecially be repeated.

div.head: CHAP. XXXIX.
Of Worms, and of the Stone of the Womb.
div.p: THough many are of the Opinion that Worms are Generated only in the Intetines, yet it is manifet by Experience, and the Tetimony of Learned Men, that they are Bred in many other parts of the Body, as in putrid Ulcers in the Teeth, in the Ears, in the Reins, and in the Bladder, tho' rarely, by reaon of the acrimony and altnes of the Urine. In the Womb alo Worms are ometimes generated, tho' it be rare, becaue the paages of it are o open that they will not uffer the Humours, tho' they are gros and crude, to continue there o long as to generate Worms. They are mot commonly Acarides, and they are mot commonly in the Privities, or in the Neck of the Womb, they are very like thoe that are in the right Gut, perhaps they creep thither from the Anus.
The material caue of Worms, is a cold phlegmatick and crude Humour, which is apt to putrifie.

When there are Worms in the Womb, the whole Body is retles and uneaie, the Mouth of the Womb is always moit, the Women are thin and weak, and ometimes the Worms are expelled with the Coures, and ometimes they may be een, the Lips of the Privities being opened. Women o afflicted leep diturbedly, and often wake in a fright, they have diorderly Fevers, and all other Symptoms which appear in Worms of the Intetines.
As to the Cure, we mut endeavour to hinder the generation of them, and to kill them when they are generated; this may be done by three orts of Remedies.

Firt, By a thin hot and drying Dyet, by acid and bitter Meats, yet they mut conit of good Nourihment, and be eaily concocted, and that are free from all crudity; the fleh of Chickens, of Hens, of mall Mountain Birds, and the Broath of them with the juice of a Lemon are good: Among Fruits Oranges, Cappares, Olives with Vinegar: Among Herbs, Endive, Sow-thitle, and Groundel:
Let her Drink be a Decoction of Cinnamon, Rubarb, the Seeds of Purlain, the Roots of China, Scorzonera, or Saraparilla. All Meats of Milk, Fih, and whatever generates Flegmatick Humours mut be avoided, and full Feeding, and a diorderly coure of Dyet.

Secondly, Thoe things mut be ued which Concoct, and Purge off Phlegmatick Humours; as Syrup of Wormwood, Succory, Succory with Rhubarb, of the acid juice of Citron with the waters of the ame Herbs, or of Gras, Purlain, and Sorrel, and the Flegm mut be contantly Purged off with Pills of Matick, of Agarick, or the like.
Thirdly, Such things mut be ued as kill Worms, and uterine Gliters to that purpoe mut be injected made of a Decoction of Wormwood, Southernwood, and Centaury with Allom. Or,
Take of Mint, Calaminth, Penny-royal, each one Handful, boyl them till the third part of the Water is conumed, mingle Honey with it and inject it. Or

Take of the Decoction of Lupins ix Ounces, of Aloes three Drams, of Honey one Ounce, which may be injected alo with the
like quantity of Decoction of Mercury and Wormwood; or the following Peary may be ued.
Take of Bulls Gall, one Dram and an half, of the Powder of Lupins, two Drams, of Oyl of Wormwood, two Ounces, of good White-wine, half an Ounce, mingle them, and dip the Cotton for the Peary in it.
At the ame time apply to the Region of the Womb the following Oyntment.
