Take of the Leaves of Wormwood, Cotmary, and Calaminth, each one Handful, of Peach Leaves half an Handful; boyl them in the harpet Vinegar, or in Wine for the Womb, to the trained Liquor, add of Aloes and Agarick, each half an Ounce, of Coloquitida three Drams, of Oyl of bitter Almonds, and of Bulls Gall, each a ufficient quantity, with a little Wax, or without it, make an Oyntment. You may alo make a Cataplam of the ame Herbs boyled and bruied with the Meal of Lupins, Oyl of Wormwood, and Ox Gall, and the Pill of Aloes, or of Hiera, must be taken often, a Scruple at a time.

That the Stones grow in every part of the Body, Galen tetifies, as in the Bladder, Reins, Liver, Intetines, Lungs; and therefore it is no trange thing if they hould be generated alo in the Womb, as Aetius writes: but they are not altogether like the Stones of the Bladder, nor are they looe, for if o they could not continue in the Womb; but they grow to the Tunicks of the neck of the Womb. The caues of them are the ame, as of the Stone in the Bladder, namely, gros and vicid Humours. The igns of them are a dull pain in the Womb, and the Coures are inordinate, and a Finger being put up the Anus, the Stone may be elt. But if the Stone be in the neck of the Womb, the pain is great, and affects the neighbouring parts, and the Womb, and the Woman can not it without pain.

As to the Cure, an emollient and lubricating coure of Diet mut be ued, and the gros and vicid Humours mut be Purged off: But the chief part of the Cure is to be performed by extracting the Stone, but firt the parts mut be quieted by an emollient Gliter made of a Decoction of Mallows, Marh-mallows, Fenugreek, of the Seeds of Flax, and a great deal of
Oyl of Roes and of Lillies to make the Manual operation the eaier, which mut be performed in the following manner.

The Womans Thighs being pread, the Chirurgeon mut thrut up two of the Fingers of his Left-hand, and with his Right he mut pres the upper part of her Belly to force the Stone out, and this may be the eaier done, if the Stone be in the Neck of the Womb, but if it be in the Womb it elf, the Operation will be more difficultly performed: But if the tone grow to the mouth or neck of the Womb, and cannot be extirpated this way, it mut be cut out, the Woman being rightly placed, and the parts dilated with a Speculum Matricis, which being done, thoe things mut be injected into the Womb which cure Ulcers, firt, Atringents, and uch things as top Blood, and afterwards drying things, and an exact Coure of Diet mut be ordered, and the Woman mut be Purged twice in a Year, let the Stone hould grow again.

The Cure of the Stone in the Bladder in Women is to be managed much in the manner as in Men, but it eldomer happens, and is eaier Cured, becaue the
paage of the Urine is larger, and horter, and traighter in Women. But if it happen, and mut be extracted, the Chirurgeon mut put two of the Fingers of his Left-hand, (the VVoman being placed as above directed) into the Privities, and with his Right he mut pres the Bladder, and force the Stone to the neck of it, o as to make it pas the Mucle that huts the neck of the Bladder, and then a little above the wings of the Privities, at which place the Stone occurs he mut cut, o that the Stone may be extracted with a pair of Forceps. Latly, the Ulcer mut be Cured by Atringent, and Incarnating Medicines.

div.head: CHAP. XL.
Of a Condyloma, of the Hemorrhoids, Warts, Thymus, Acrocordo, and a Ficus, and of Scabs of the Privities, and of Chaps, and Clefts of the ame.
div.p: A Condyloma is a Tubercle ariing from an Inflammation, and reembles the Knucles when the Hand is hut. It is cured by four kind of Remedies, Firt by Diet and Purging Medicines that repect the antecedent caue; Secondly, By drying and repelling Topicks, if the Callus be newly bred, as by Baths and Vapours of a Decoction of Vervain, of the Leaves of Brambles, of Acacia, Ivy-leaves, to which mut be added, by reaon of the Pain, Camomile Flowers; and if the Condyloma be Inflamed uch things mut be ued as mitigate the pain, as the following decoction.

Take of the leaves of Melilot, Mallows, and Marhmallows, each half an handful, of the Seeds of Flax and Fenugreek, each three Drams, of the Flowers of Camomile two Pugils, boyl them, and to a Pint of the Decoction, add two Ounces of Roes, inject it by a Syringe; or warm Milk may be o injected. If the Condyloma being old is grown hard, and does not yeild to the foreaid Medicines, Aetius commends as a wonderful remedy Mineral Miy mixed with Turpentine; or intead of it Roman Vitriol, a Dram of the Troches of Steel reduced to powder, and mixed with the Oyls of Roes and Wax, and made into an Oyntment with half an Ounce of the Juice of Mullein is alo very good. The following is alo much commended.
Take of Tuty thrice burnt and wahed, of Cerus wahed, of the Froth of Silver wahed, each two Drams, of the Yolks of two roated Eggs, Wax, Sope and Oyl of Roes, each two Ounces; make an Oyntment.

But if thee things do no Good, it mut be cut off, and if there be many of them, they mut be burnt off, and the Ulcer mut be regularly cured: but cutting or
burning in thee parts is dangerous and mut not therefore be ued unles there be an abolute neceity.

If there be Hemorrhoids, they are either in the Mouth or Neck of the Womb, or in the Womb it elf, or in the Privities; they are as divers as thoe in the Anus, they are either blind or open; they are with or without Inflammation; they differ alo upon their bignes, Number and Figure; they are occaioned by Chaps, and by a Condyloma, but chiefly by gros and feculent Humours falling upon the Veins of the Womb, or by an inordinate defluxion of Mentruous Blood into thoe Veins. This Dieae may be known by a weight in thoe Parts, and Women o affected are weak and ubject to Spontaneous Laitude: But if the Hemorrhoids of the Womb, or Anus flow moderately, they cure and prevent many Dieaes, and the uneaonable topage of them occaions the Falling Sicknes, and many other Dieaes. They are cured as the Piles of the Anus.
There are four orts of Warts of the Womb and Privities.
The Firt are Acrocordones, which hang as by a Thred.
Secondly, Thymus which is a rough and oblong Tumour, and without pain, if it be gentle and white, or redih; but if it be Malignant it is livid and painful.
Thirdly, Ficus or Maricae, which differ from a Thymus only in bignes.

The Fourth is Clavus, which is a hard white and round prominence like the Heads of Corns. Thee Tumours in general are of a Scirrhous nature, and come by immoderate Copulation, and are ometimes Malignant, by reaon of the French-Pox. The gentle are known by their white or redih colour, and by the abence of pain, the Malignant by their hardnes, leaden colour and pain.
They are Cured by four orts of Remedies.
Firt, By a Diet that is not apt to breed gros Humours, and by Catharticks to Purge uch Humours off, and by Sweats, if they are obtinate.

Secondly, By dicuing Medicines, which are mot proper for the Thymus and Clavus as by dried Sage, with fat Figs, or Old-hoes burnt and powdered and mixed with Wine and applyed: But the Soles of Shoes and a dried Gourd powdered by themelves, and afterwards mixed and applied with Wine to Warts do very well, or you may take of Rue and Pennyroyal, each equal parts; let them be burnt and powdered; the Bark of Frankincene, the Leaves of Bail Wine and Vinegar, Shoomakers Ink, boyl them in the VVater that drops out of a Vine cut; moiten the part with this Decoction; this is reckoned an excellent Medicine.

Prick with a Needle the Eye of a Goat newly killed, and anoint daily the part with the Liquor that flows from it, and within Six Days, as Aetius writes; Myrmecies will be extirpated, which conit of broad Roots, and they itch.

Thirdly, Things that burn and eat are proper for Myrmecies and Acrocordos, as the juice of wild Cucumber with Salt, or the like: But corroding things mut
not continue long upon the part, for when they have been applied an hour or thereabout, the part mut be wahed twice or thrice with Atringent Wine; and the Neighbouring parts mut be defended by an Oyntment made with Bolearmenick, ealed Earth, Roe-water and Vinegar.
Fourthly, If they may be cut off, they ought to be o, but ome bind the root of thee with a Hore-hair; and traighten it daily till they fall off.

In the Privities and Mouth of the Womb, epecially in uch Women, as have the French-Pox, Putles arie; they often itch; they are occaioned by the abundance, and grones of a bilious and adut Humour, or by the French-Pox, they may be eaily een by a Speculum Matricis. They are to be cured by four orts of Remedies.
Firt, By Meats of good juice, and by abtaining from all acrid, acid and alt things.

Secondly, By Univeral Evacuations, as by Bleeding and Purging, and uch things,
as attemperate the Humour mut be ued, as Syrup of Borrage, Violets, Fumitory and Succory, and the like. Decoctions of Sara, or of Guiacum with Sweating are alo very proper, and Purges and Sudorificks mut be often repeated.
Thirdly, Topicks mut be applyed, and if the Putles are gentle bathing is proper, and afterwards wah the part with hot Wine and Nitre.
For Putles and Scabs the following Oyntment of has bin found very uccesful.

Take of the Roots Elecampane, Burnet and harp pointed Dock, each three Ounces, of Fumitory Water Six Ounces, of the harpet Vinegar, or of the best Wine, for Dieaes of the Womb, two Ounces; having bruied the roots well, infue them a day and a night, then boyl them, and pres them strongly; to the trained Liquor add half a pound of Turpentine, of Oyl of Roes three Ounces, of Wax half an Ounce, boyl them again to the Conumption of half, and add of Sulphur one Ounce and an half, of Cerus five Ounces, of Roch-allom half an Ounce, of Sal Gemma two drams, of Oyl of Eggs, ix Drams, mix them by beating of them well
together, then wah the whole Compoition in Fumitory Water.
But if the Putles are Malignant, and Obtinate, you mut ue tronger Deiccatives, which correct the Venom of the Putles, and at the ame time you mut ue udorific decoctions.

Take of Plantain and Roe Water each four Ounces, of Sal Gemma, Nitre, and Allom, each two Drams, of Sublimate one Dram and an half, boyl them till a third part is conumed; to the trained Liquor, add of Verde-greee one Scruple; after you have ued this two or three dayes, you mut forbear a while, and ue gentler things, and return again to the ue of it, till the Putles are quite taken off.
This moreover mut be added, which is of excellent ue, having firt bathed with a decoction of Fumitory, Lupins, Beans, and a little Salt.

Take of the Roots of Elecampane cut mall four Ounces, boyl them well in a ufficient quantity of Water with a little Vinegar or Wine, then beat them in a Mortar and Pulp them through a Sieve, and add of freh
Lard three Ounces, of Juice of ground Elder, and of Fumitory, each one Ounce and an half, of Quick-Silver extinguihed in fating Spittle, or in the Yolk of an Egg, half an Ounce, of Cerus and Lytharge, each one Ounce, of Brimtone one Dram and an half, tir them about for an hour, and mix the Powders by degrees.
But becaue Putles continue ometimes a long while, you mut make an Iue in the Leg, before they are quite dryed up.

Clefts and Chaps are ometimes in the Mouth of the Womb, as in the Anus, Hands, Lips, and Nipples, by reaon of violent Cold, a North Wind, and the like; they are mall, long and narrow Ulcers, ometimes deep, and ometimes only uperficial; they are alo ocaioned by hard labour, by Acrid and Corroding Humours, or by a great drynes in the Womb.

They are to be cured by five orts of Remedies; by a moitening and moothening Diet, avoiding uch things as are acrid, and top the Belly; therefore let the Woman eat Chicken, Mutton, Veal, and
Broaths made of Succory, Buglos, Burrage, Spinage, and the like; let her Drink be rather Beer than Wine, he mut avoid Cheee and Spices, Violent Exercie, and Copulation: And if Acrid humours be the caue, he mut be blooded, if there be a plenitude; afterwards he mut be Purged with Caia, Manna, and the like, and the Humours mut be attemperated with the Syrups of Succory, Roes, Violets, Borrage, Fumitory, and with the Waters of the ame Herbs. If they are occaioned by hard labour, and Bleed, the Blood mut be top'd by the following Uterine Gliter.

Take of the leaves of Plantain one handfull, of Roes four Pugils, boyl them in a ufficient quantity of Water till half is conumed. To ix Ounces of the trained Liquor add of the Powders of Dragons Blood, Bole armenick, Myrrh, Frankincene, Birthwort, each half a Dram.
If the Chaps are dry, hot, and itch, the part mut be Fomented with things that moiten, as the following Decoction.

Take of the fleh of Frogs, Snails, and River Crabs, each two Drams, of Barley two Pugils, of Mallows and Ducks meat, each one handful, of Flax Seeds one Ounce, boyl them in a ufficient quantity of Water, and let ix Ounces be injected in the manner of a terine Gliter, and anoint the part affected with the Oyntment of Cerue with Camphor; and if the pain and heat be much, anoint it with the following Oyntment.
Take of the Populeon Oyntment one Ounce, of Camphor two Scruples, of Cerus wahed in Roe Water one Scruple, and the white of one Egg, mingle them.

Oyl of Flax hot is alo good for Chaps of the Anus and Womb, o is Pomatum; Oyl of the Yolks of Eggs, or of Flax Seeds tir'd about in a Leaden Mortar is alo proper, and if they are occaioned by drines, Barly boyled in Water in Linnen Baggs, and applyed for nine days are very beneficial. But if the Chaps are malignant, apply the following.

Take of good Aqua vitae one point, of Sublimate powdered one Scruple, of Verdegreae half a Scruple, the Whites of three Eggs, tir them well together, and anoint the part every other day, and apply over a Plater of Diachylon.

div.head: CHAP. XLI.
Of the Melancholy of Virgins and Widows.
div.p: MElancholy befalls Virgins, Widdows, and Barren VVomen, oftner than other VVomen; there are two Caues of it.
Firt, the Nature of a Woman which is tender, and the Mind eaily dejected.
Secondly, Gros Blood.

The igns of it are a Pulation about the Back, which is a Symptom almot perpetual in VVomen o affected; the Skin is ometime qualid, wrinkley and rough, epecially in the Arms, Knees and joints of the Fingers; much Cogitation, Supicion, Shame-facednes, Dejection of Mind, diturbed Sleep, frightful Dreams, a prepoterous Judgment; the Breat is often very Hot and hath a Pulation in it, and when the Vapour ries upwards, there is a Palpitation of the Heart, or Fainting; there is a riing in the Throat,
as in Mother-fits, the Belly is mot commonly Bound, they are Thirty, and ubject to VVatchings, to Depair, and to VVeeping and Sorrow, and ometimes the Melancholy is o high, as that they grow almot Ditracted, and are ready to make away with themelves.
There are three Degrees of this Dieae, according to which the Danger is more or les, and the Cure is to be varied accordingly.
The Firt, Is when the Signs are mall.
The Second, when the Dieae has lated a long while, and has diordered the VVomans Mind o, as that he is continually Sorrowful and Sad.
The Third, Is when the VVoman, is o overcome with it, that he will not peak, nor give any anwers, and this is near to Madnes.

The Firt Degree of this may be removed by a paring Diet, by Exercie, and by variety of pleaant Company, and if he be not Married, he mut be Blooded in the Arm every third or fourth
Month, in the middle of the Month: But if he be mot Melancholy at the time of her Coures, he mut be Blooded in the Foot two or three days before or after them.
But if the Dieae be in the Second Degree, the Curative Indications are principally four.
The Firt, to hinder the Congetion of the Blood in the VVomb, by uch things as force the Coures.
The Second, is to expel the Melancholy that is heapt up.
The Third, Is to dicus the VVind.
The Fourth, To provide for the Head, Heart, Womb, and the whole Body.
It is to be Cured therefore by five orts of Remedies.

Firt, By a moitning Diet, as let the Dinner be of a boyl'd Chicken, with the Roots of Fennel, Parley, red Vetches, and Saffron: And the Supper of new-laid Eggs, roated, and tewed Prunes, or
Borrage prepared with Almond-milk, by reaon of Watchings, wherewith they are much troubled; or a Ptian with a little Annieeds and Cinnamon, to expel the Wind. Let the Drink be Rhenih or VVhite-wine with Borrage flowers in it, midling Beer medicated with Elecampane or Balm, or water boyled with the Herb Maiden-hair, with the Roots of Scorzonera, Lemon-peel, and Citroneeds. If the Belly be bound, ue the following Gliter.

Take of the Roots of Fennel and Parley, each one Ounce, of the Leaves of Mallows, one Handful, of Polypody of the Oak, one Ounce, of the Seeds of Batard Saffron, Flax, and Fenugreek, each one Dram, boyl them to a Pint, to the trained Liquor add of the Oyls of Dill, Camomile, Violets, and of Brown-Sugar, each one Ounce, of Diacatholicon, half an Ounce.
Secondly, Evacuations mut be ued, and if there be a plenitude, Bleeding mut be ordered, and purging Medicines frequently; but the Humour mut be firt prepared by the following Medicines, or the like.

Take of Syrups of Borrage, of Apples, and of Epithymum, each one Ounce, of the waters of Borrage and Balm, each two Ounces, mingle them, and when the Woman has ued this ix or eight Days, let her take every other Week one Dram of the Pills of Aloes, of Matick, or of Agarick; or rather becaue the Pills dry and heat, let her take three or four times in a Year a Bolus made with an Ounce of the pulp of Caia, and two Drams of the Powder of Sena: The following Syrup is much commended.

Take of the waters of Borrage, Succory and Hops, each ten Ounces, of the juice of Borrage clarified eight Ounces, of the juice of fragrant Apples, ix Ounces, of the Leaves of Sena three Ounces, of the Cordial Flowers, each one Pugil, of the Roots of Scorzonera cut mall, or of Angelica, two Ounces, boyl them over a gentle Fire till the twentieth part is conumed; to the trained Liquor add of choice Rubarb, and of Agarick trothicated, each four Drams and an half; after it has boyled gently, train it out, and add of the powder of the Stone called Lazulus prepared, and tied up in a rag two Drams, of Sugar a ufficient quantity, make a Syrup of a moderate conitence: The Doe is three or four Ounces.
The following Medicine is much commended.

Take of the Leaves of Spleen-wort, Penny-royal, Maiden-hair, Thym, Fumitory, Borrage, Mugwort, and Agrimony, each half an Handful, of the Roots of Succory, Endive, Smallage, Angelica, Fennel, Aparagus, and Eringo, each one Ounce, of the flowers of Borrage, Stechas, Roemary, Violets, each one Pugil and an half, of Epithymum, and of the leaves of Sena, each half an Ounce, of Doronicum, of the Seeds of Anie, Fenel, Bail, and Citron, each two Drams and an half, of Cinnamon half an Ounce, of all the Sanders, each half a Dram, boyl them in a ufficient quantity of Water to a Quart; at the end add of the Bark of the Root of black Hellibore, and of choice Rubarb, each four Scruples, of the tone called Lazulus tied up in a rag, one Dram, of weet melling Flag, of Zedoary, and of the Seeds of Peony decortiated, each half a Scruple, train it, and with a ufficient quantity of white Sugar make a clear Potion; aromatize it with one Dram of Diamoh. The Doe is five or ix Ounces.

But if thee things do no good, four
Grains of Stybium prepared may be afely given; but it is bet to begin with two Grains. But ome in a deperate Melancholy have not feared to give three four or five Grains of Vigo's precipitate with an Ounce of good Wine, or in Conerve of Roes.
Thirdly things that dicus Wind mut be ued, and the following Gliter mut be frequently injected.

Take of the Roots of Fennel, and Parley, each one Ounce, of the Seeds of batard Saffron, Anie, Flax, and Fenugreek, each one Dram, of the Leaves of Mallows, one Handful, of Polypody of the Oak, half an Handful, boyl them in a ufficient quantity of Water to a Pint; add of the Oyls of Camomile, and Dill, each one Ounce, and an half, of Lenitive Electuary, and of brown Sugar, each one Ounce; make a Gliter.
And it is convenient to anoint the Spleen with the following Liniment.

Take of the Decoction of Tamarick, Capers, and Spleen-wort, each two Ounces, of Oyl of Capers, and Lillies, each one Dram, of Treacle and Mithridate, each two Drams,
with a ufficient quantity of Wax make an Oyntment.

Fourthly, Such things mut be ued as caue Sleep, whereof there is o great want in this Dieae, that this Symptom often takes up the whole Cure; it happens by reaon of the iccity of the Brain, and therefore things that moiten are to be ued. To this purpoe, the Feet and Legs are wont to be wahed with a Decoction of Mallows, Roes, Camomile, Violets, and the Flowers of Lettice, and ometimes Henbane, and the heads of whith Poppies are added to it, and the Head is to be Embrocated in the following manner.

Take of the foreaid Decoction a Quart, of the Oyls of Poppies, and Roes, each three Ounces, mingle them, and pour them gently being warm upon the Head; but the Hair mut be firt haved off. Afterwards apply to the Head a Rag dipt in the Oyls of Roes and Camomile, or of Poppies, if the Watchings be very great, or in Womans or Goats Milk, and if thee things are not ufficient, anoint the Notrils with Populeon Oyntment; or take of Oyntment of Roes one Ounce, of Opium four Grains, mingle them, and anoint the
Notrils, the Temples, and the Palms of the Hands, and the Soles of the Feet, and the Pule, and let her take inwardly the following Emulion.

Take of Sweet Almonds blanched four Ounces, of the Seeds of Melons, and Gouras, each one Ounce, of the Seeds of Lettice, and Poppies, each two Drams, beat them in a Marble Mortar, and pour upon them a Pint of Barley water, and a little Roe water, weeten it with Sugar and make an Emulion; let it be taken just after Supper, and at Bedtime give the following Anodyne.
Take of Cowlip water, two Ounces, of Diacodium, one Ounce.
Latly, uch things mut be ued, as trengthen the Brain and Heart, apply the following Epithem to the region of the Heart.

Take of the waters of Balm, Orange flowers, and Borrage, each three Ounces, of good White-wine, two Ounces, of the Juice of fragrant Apples, one Ounces and an half, of the Powders of Diamock, Diambra, of the Bark of Citron, each half a Dram, mingle them; or anoint the region of the Heart with the
Oyntment of Flowers of Oranges, and let her Eat now and then Citron Bark Candied, or the Roots of Buglos, or Scorzonera Candied.

But if the Dieae be o high, that the Woman is plainly Delirious, which is the third Degree of this Dieae; the ame Remedies in a manner mut be ued, only the mot effectual mut be choen, and care mut be taken, that a cold and dry Intemperies be not contracted, and therefore les Blood mut be taken away, and he mut be Purged trongly with a Dram of the Pill De Lapide Lazuli, or with the like quantity of the following.

Take of Epithymum, ix Ounces, of Agarick, four Drams, of the Bark of black Hellebore, one Dram and an half, of the pecies of imple Hiera, four Drams, with Honey of Roes make a Mas. But the following Electuary is better.

Take of the Stone called Lazulus, one Dram, of the Leaves of Sena, one Dram and an half, of the bet Agarick two Drams, of the Syrup of Purlain, or of the Juice of Fumitory or of Hops, three Ounces, of Conerve
of Roes or of Violets, one Ounce, mingle them; let her take an Ounce once a Week.

And the Body mut be moitned by all means, by Baths and the like; wherewith, and with a moitning Diet Galen cured Melancholy, and uch things mut be ued as provoke the Coures; but if they will not flow, the application of Leeches to the Hemorrhoids is very proper, becaue Hippocrates and Galen ay that Melancholy Blood is drawn by thee Veins; they may be opened two ways; by rubbing the Fundament with a coure Cloth, and by Leeehes, which mut be of a moderate bignes, and they mut be taken from a clear and running Water, they mut not be green, pale, nor hairy; but reddih, and after they are taken they mut be preed, that they may Vomit up the Venom, if they have any; then they mut be kept in a Glas full of clear Water weetned with Sugar, and the Water mut be changed once a Week. When they are to be applied, you mut Foment the part with a Decoction of Camomile, Mallows, Mullein, and the like; then rub it, that the Mouth of the Veins may appear, and to each of them
apply a Leech; if they will not tick, anoint the place with Chickens Blood, or the like; and whilt they are ucking, let a hot Decoction of Camomile, Dill, Roes, and Mallows be put under them, that the vapour of it may comfort them. A ufficient quantity of Blood being drawn, they generally fall off of themelves; if they do not, pinch them by the Tails, or prinkle upon their Mouths Ahes, Salt, or Aloes. If the Blood low too long, apply Rags dipt in tiptick Wine, or the white of an Egg with ome atringent Powder.
